story:
Just days before her death Frida Kahlo wrote in her diary: 'I hope the exit is joyful and I hope never to return.'

  • Red Boot Productions Ltd. invites you to support us in bringing to the Stage, the World Premiere of 'Becoming Frida', a newly created Production about the death & life of Frida Kahlo; one of the most extraordinary and revolutionary surrealist artists of the 20th Century.
  • Help us to tell Frida's story in her own words as only she could have told you!
  • Our production motto is 'Theatre for the People, made possible by the People' which is why we are so committed to this platform for raising funds and it's a sentiment that Frida would, we believe, have been fully supportive of.
  • As Helen Keller once said; 'Alone we can do so little; together we can do so much' . Your contribution will make this happen.

 

Rebecca Grant - Actress, Book, Producer

A regular in award-winning BBC & ITV Drama's (Doctors, Midsomer Murders, Prisoners Wives, Emmerdale & Holby City), Rebecca has enjoyed a long and successful career to date. Her first appearance in Andrew Lloyd Webber's Bombay Dreams aged just 19 was followed by further London & Provincial Theatre success around the UK including her acclaimed performance in Eve Ensler's human trafficking monologue play; 'Avocado' at West Yorkshire Playhouse in 2015.

Her film-short, 'Safe Space', also about Human Trafficking, has garnered 21 film festival selections around the world and has won 6 awards so far. She was also recently awarded Best Actress for her performance in 'The Black Shuck' at Out of the Can Film Festival 2019.

Steve Scrivens - Producer

The former Theatre Programming Manager of the award-winning Royal & Derngate Theatre in Northampton, England now lives in Vermont, USA where he owns a Theatre & Music programming company, sits on the Board of Trustees for South Burlington City Center for the Arts and heads up a project to develop a touring arts venue in Vermont in consultation with the UK based Company; Studio Three Sixty.

Our immediate goal is to fund the development costs of this exciting production:

  • Promotional Video Trailer - £1,800
  • Staged Reading in London - £2,000
  • Script Development - £3,000
  • Music Development - £3,000
  • Costume Design - £2,000
  • Creative Team acquisition - £6,000
  • Stage & Scenery Design - £8,000
  • Lighting & Sound Design - £2,000
  • Rehearsal Studio booking -£5,000
  • Cast Soundtrack recording - £7,500

Each segment funded gets us closer to our ultimate goal and we'll keep you updated every step of the way with every milestone that we hit. This way, you'll know as a Supporter that what you give really matters because every segment above can be delivered if you contribute!

Your contribution, however small, will help us develop this production and fine tune it in time for what we plan to be the World Premiere performance in the Autumn of 2020. We have lined up some exciting rewards in exchange for your early support and all supporters will be regularly updated about our progress and future developments.

Don't worry if you're not based in the UK, we plan to tour the production in various locations after opening in the U.K. we hope to bring you news of our plans for a planned off-Broadway run in 2022 once the uncertainty surrounding Covid-19 has passed!

You can help our friends at Cardboard Citizens by making a donation that both helps us meet our financial goals, while also providing free tickets to Cardboard Citizens Members (people with lived experience of homelessness) to see our show when it is staged. We have also partnered with VAMOS a Vermont based non-profit that supports projects for the poor in Cuernavaca, Morelos, Mexico. Frida lived in Cuernavaca between 1929 & late 1930 and it's here that she sharpened her sense of Mexican identity and history leading her to begin wearing traditional indigenous peasant clothing to emphasize her mestiza ancestry. Please visit the websites of both of our non-profit organizations to discover more about their work. You may even feel inspired to make a donation to them directly when you discover what they do!

Making a Theatre Production happen is challenging and expensive. Our segment targets are designed to ensure with each goal we meet that we can deliver what you helped us to fund. All of these segments together will enable us to get the project in front of potential investors and on to the stage powered by the people who believed in us. YOU!  

Anything raised beyond our Global target through our stretch target will reduce the amount we have to raise from investors and help us maintain artistic control. We have a fabulous, passionate and dedicated team and we want you to be part of our family. Just think how exciting it will be to be part of making this happen. So, what can you do?

  • Make a contribution! Any amount helps.
  • Claim one of our exciting perks.
  • Share this campaign on your social media platforms and/or via email. Tell people why you're excited about our production and invite them to be part of making this production happen!.
  • Follow us on Instagram Twitter and Facebook!
  • Join our email list and stay in the loop - just visit our website and sign up there.

And that's all there is to it....except to say........

We want to thank everyone who contributes to this campaign whether it's through a donation, selecting one of our perks or by spreading the word about our campaign.

We'd also like to thank those companies that have helped us to provide such exciting benefits for our perks: Maison Assouline, Ella Canta Restaurant at InterContinental Park Lane and our non-profit organisations Cardboard Citizens and VAMOS.

The fabulous work of our support team has been invaluable so we want to make special mention of Josh Trett - Video filming, directing and editing, Elija Paul Villanueva -Stills photography of Rebecca as Frida at Victoria & Albert Museum, London during the 'Making Herself Up' Exhibition, Laura Francis - Stills photography, Anjali Mehra - Movement & Choreography, Eszter Hercsik - Hair & Make-up for Ms Grant, Crispin Buxton - The Norfolk Film Company for use of their filming Hangar, Concepcion Angeles and Angie Tindale - Child care for Flint & Rose, Walles Hamonde - Voice Coach, and Ellie Buchan, Richard White & Samuel Walpole - Runners.

Important Note: Associate & Executive Producer titles are honorary designations only and do not imply having an authoritative voice in the creation of the theatrical production.  By purchasing any perk, you agree that your purchase will be considered a donation, and not refunded, in the event our production does not get fully staged.

story:
Help Autumn Cravens and Helen Miller go to NYC and Edinburgh!

 

The Cause

Hitler’s Tasters, a contemporary play by Michelle Kholos-Brooks, just finished its successful NYC run in the fall of last year; however, a show with such a powerful message simply couldn’t stop there! The cast elected to bring the show to the Edinburgh Festival Fringe, the largest theatre festival in the world. With the go-ahead from New Light Theatre Project in New York City, the cast managed to raise enough money to go and experience this amazing festival. Under the direction of Sarah Norris, the play is being condensed to a one hour version of its New York run. Because Ashlee Wasmund, the choreographer for the show, is a professor at Western Carolina University, we were able to audition for an amazing opportunity: the chance to be a part of this journey!

We will be switching off as a 5th character role in Hitler’s Tasters and will each understudy two of the four lead roles. This is an incredible opportunity to experience theatre on a global scale, develop an understanding of our profession in an international context, and build a network that will hopefully last us a lifetime. However, a chance like this doesn’t come cheap. We need as much help as we can get to reach our goal! We’ve outlined our expenses below and will be updating them as our goals progress and milestones are reached.

 

The Cost

NYC:

Housing: $2,000

Flights: $350

Ground Transportation: $200

Food: $1,000

Incidentals: $200

City Total: $3,700

Edinburgh:

Housing: $5,000

Flight: $1,970

Food: $2,700

Ground Transport: $400

Fringe Fees: $358

Extra: $400

City Total: $10,828

Money We’ve Earned So Far:

Travel Grant: $2,000

Dean’s Grant: $5,000

Goal: $7,528

Stretch Goal: $8,000

 

The Perks

We thank you for taking the time to read about this opportunity and we hope you consider helping us achieve our goal to get to NYC and Edinburgh. Every little bit helps! We even have incentives for donations, which you can see along the side!

Note: The photo of a photo of you with us in Edinburgh can be taken at any of the locations listed below, or another one of your choice!

  • Arthur’s Seat: Beautiful hike right outside of the city
  • Elephant House: Birthplace of Harry Potter
  • Scott Monument: Monument in Edinburgh dedicated to the author Sir Walter Scott
  • Scottish National Galleries: Art museum in Edinburgh
  • Greenside @ Infirmary: "Hitler’s Tasters" venue for the festival!
  • Royal Botanic Garden: 70 acres of beautiful foliage in the middle of the city

Follow our journey on Instagram and Facebook @HTUnderstudies

story:
Rodadoras is a strong, physical and female driven work, responding to challenging themes of femicide and eco-feminism, specific cases like Los Feminicidios where women’s bodies were found in rivers and wastelands and the affects of violence towards women globally. Connecting the female form and the earth.

This is a fresh, exciting work; current in content and theme, the piece explores a specific and unique movement language. Drawing on contemporary dance and Capoeira, a highly physical and visually commanding aesthetic is created, alongside a rich rhythmical sound score. The soil creates an immersive texture and visceral quality to the work, and is enhanced by performing outdoors. The subtleties that nature allows, when the wind blows the dancers hair or a change of light, all cultivates a rich atmosphere and surreal imagery. 

This is my first independent creation where I have had the time, space and the support I needed to create the vision. I have been researching and developing ideas for this work for the last two years, gathering a creative team, supporters and partners, and now the piece is finished we want to take it abroad to international festivals and find performance opportunities. The piece was created over 3 weeks with 3 dance artists in Birmingham and we have so far performed at Hidden Door Festival, Edinburgh and Birmingham International Dance Festival,  with more to come in London at Greenwich + Docklands Festival and Spoffin in Amersfoort (Netherlands).

Rodadoras is  produced by Amy Sheppard, a freelance dance artist and producer who brings over 6 years’ experience across the dance, theatre and charity sectors. She gained excellent skills in producing, project management and coordination and artist management through her positions at IdeasTap and East London Dance. She is currently working in a freelance capacity as a dance artist and producer with the Royal Opera House, Royal Academy of Dance, Jeanefer Jean-Charles and ShepsDance. Together we have developed a wonderful partnership and with her support we secured funding from the Arts Council as well as some fantastic programming dates. 

Any contributions will greatly help us to achieve the best version of this show possible. With the money, we will be able to produce a show of the highest quality.

We have been invited to perform at our first International Tour dates at Festival Spoffin in Amersfoort, Netherlands. Festival Spoffin  is a particularly exciting place for us to present the work as many programmers, funders and promoters attend the festival looking for new works. This money will allow us to pay the dancers for their time in Amersfoort performing 7 shows where we expect to perform to over 1500 people for free.

This money is going directly to the performers and the costs of transport and travel.  As an artist, individual and company who cares about the environment and local community we do our best to be as green as possible when creating work. And so we are researching the most cost effective and environmentally friendly way of transporting or creating our set for the Netherlands.

These parts come together to create a specific aesthetic and value. We hope you will want to invest in this work the way we invest in people. As an outdoor piece the festivals and performances we will perform at will be mostly unticketed and free, so any money invested in Rodadoras will go back into the community through our performances. We want to share the work with you!

The creative team include Dancers; Eleonore Cabrera, Bethany Edwards and Sabrina Gargano and Music Composer Domenico Angarano.

£1200 will go towards the performers fees for 7 shows. 

£200 will go towards the travel costs and expenses

£200 will be spent on marketing and administration

£400 will go towards the tour for next year!

I am passionate about making dance for the outdoors because it creates visually exciting work and immerses the performers and audiences in their surroundings. This is magical and unique to each performance and very different to theatre based work. It also allows us to perform to many people especially those who may not have access to dance theatre.

Making and performing outdoor work is very rewarding and brings the art form to various communities because it's free and accessible. Therefore, we don't take any ticket sales and it makes putting work on very challenging so any help you can give will really help! 

Even £5 goes such a long way, but if you are unable to donate, that's ok! We encourage you to come see our production live. For more info contact info@beckynamgauds.com or follow us on facebook, instagram or twitter.

If you would like to support our campaign but are unable to donate then you can still help us by sharing the campaign via social media, email or word of mouth! Spreading the word and sharing our project with your friends will help us a lot.

The creation of Rodadoras is supported by Arts Council England, DanceXchange Choreography Award, East London Dance, Hofesh Shechter and the Offsite partners Appetite Stoke, Birmingham Hippodrome, Deda and Derby Feste. We need a further £2000 which will enable us to tour to international locations such as Spoffin in the Netherlands!

story:
We have already accomplished so much within the community and need your help to present these important stories to the public! Our campaign will support a culminating performance that brings these voices to life with professional dancers and musicians at Speyer Hall, University Settlement October 25th-28th. 

People Involved

Creative Traffic Flow (DawN Crandell, Jeesun Choi and Kristin Rose Kelly) is a theatre collective that creates ensemble driven performances that are socially just, equitable and inspire civil discourse. Formed at the inaugural National Institute for Directing and Ensemble Creation hosted by Pangea World Theater and Art2Action, CTF strives to present and perform at the highest level of artistic integrity while honoring multiple forms of expressions and perspectives.

We have selected six community performers, drawn from various University Settlement programs. We have participants from EXCEL Program, which serves young adults with special needs as well as new immigrants from Adult Literacy Zone, seniors from the 189 Allen neighborhood center and queer youth of color from The Door.

‘Duets of Difference’ will give the performers from The Door the opportunity to push their budding talents and interests in vogueing, modeling, and acting. Seniors at the 189 Allen neighborhood center have knowledge and wisdom to share and have more free time to interact socially and keep their minds and bodies active. The Excel students with special needs have been working all year with DawN Crandell in performance and dance and are excited to explore the form through their own stories.

This is an exceptional collision of experiences and passions. 

We are looking to create a performance that grows from the community performers’ life stories, personal values and community beliefs. The community stories will be accompanied by professional dancers and musicians.

Progress So Far

Since February 2018, we have had the pleasure of leading introductory workshops for the Adult Literacy and Excel Program. We had an overwhelmingly positive response from these sessions and have recruited committed community participants, who want to continue their work with us.

On May 29, 2018, we shared a mini performance of ‘Duets of Difference’ at the University Settlement’s City Stories Gala with two community performers from the Adult Literacy Program. They were excited to practice English in a supportive environment and in front of an audience, as well as to meet new people.

Beginning July 2018, we started having weekly ‘Duets of Difference’ rehearsals at The Door. We are in the process of ensemble building and creating the performance.

About University Settlement

More than 130 years ago, University Settlement launched an innovative movement that changed New York City and the country. With University Settlement leading, settlement houses established the idea that immigrants and low-income families deserve basic services like quality education, decent housing, access to open space for exercise and health, and support for the aging. They proved that with a little help, these families could get a foothold on the American dream.

Right now, University Settlement serves many different Lower East Side community members including but not limited to homeless and LGBTQ youth at The Door, English Language Learners in the Adult Literacy Program, Elderly at 189 Allen neighborhood center, and youth with special needs through the Excel Program.

Thank you for all your support! Please consider making a donation to our project to support civil discourse through theatre and dance!

Risks and challenges

Why We Need You!

Your contribution will allow us to compensate the leading artists, professional dancers and musicians as well as the community performers participating in the eight-week rehearsal and four public performances.

Pay the artists leading the four-week theatre dance workshop connecting community members across University Settlement to one another and their stores

Compensate the leading artists, community performers, professional dancer and musician for the eight-week rehearsal and four public performances

Equally pay all artists and community performers involved.

As a collective, we believe in honoring artists’ time and commitment to a project. Each community performer, professional dancer and musician must dedicate rehearsal and performance hours to make this new work come to life. This requires adjusting work schedules, finding child care, and lengthening commutes. As a theatre collective we believe in pay equity for everyone we work with.

Our current goal of $5,000 is minimally budgeted as follows:

Performance Stipend for Community Performers ($500 each) X 6 : $3,000 
Performance Stipend for Dancers ($500 each) X 2 : $1,000 
Performance Stipend for Musicians ($500 each) X 1 : $500
Lighting Designer Stipend: $500 

TOTAL: $5,000

Our campaign will support a culminating performance that brings these voices to life with professional dancers and musicians at Speyer Hall, University Settlement October 25th-28th. 
People Involved
Creative Traffic Flow (DawN Crandell, Jeesun Choi and Kristin Rose Kelly) is a theatre collective that creates ensemble driven performances that are socially just, equitable and inspire civil discourse. Formed at the inaugural National Institute for Directing and Ensemble Creation hosted by Pangea World Theater and Art2Action, CTF strives to present and perform at the highest level of artistic integrity while honoring multiple forms of expressions and perspectives.
We have selected six community performers, drawn from various University Settlement programs. We have participants from EXCEL Program, which serves young adults with special needs as well as new immigrants from Adult Literacy Zone, seniors from the 189 Allen neighborhood center and queer youth of color from The Door.
‘Duets of Difference’ will give the performers from The Door the opportunity to push their budding talents and interests in vogueing, modeling, and acting. Seniors at the 189 Allen neighborhood center have knowledge and wisdom to share and have more free time to interact socially and keep their minds and bodies active. The Excel students with special needs have been working all year with DawN Crandell in performance and dance and are excited to explore the form through their own stories.
This is an exceptional collision of experiences and passions. 
We are looking to create a performance that grows from the community performers’ life stories, personal values and community beliefs. The community stories will be accompanied by professional dancers and musicians.
Progress So Far
Since February 2018, we have had the pleasure of leading introductory workshops for the Adult Literacy and Excel Program. We had an overwhelmingly positive response from these sessions and have recruited committed community participants, who want to continue their work with us.
On May 29, 2018, we shared a mini performance of ‘Duets of Difference’ at the University Settlement’s City Stories Gala with two community performers from the Adult Literacy Program. They were excited to practice English in a supportive environment and in front of an audience, as well as to meet new people.
Beginning July 2018, we started having weekly ‘Duets of Difference’ rehearsals at The Door. We are in the process of ensemble building and creating the performance.
About University Settlement
More than 130 years ago, University Settlement launched an innovative movement that changed New York City and the country. With University Settlement leading, settlement houses established the idea that immigrants and low-income families deserve basic services like quality education, decent housing, access to open space for exercise and health, and support for the aging. They proved that with a little help, these families could get a foothold on the American dream.
Right now, University Settlement serves many different Lower East Side community members including but not limited to homeless and LGBTQ youth at The Door, English Language Learners in the Adult Literacy Program, Elderly at 189 Allen neighborhood center, and youth with special needs through the Excel Program.
Thank you for all your support! Please consider making a donation to our project to support civil discourse through theatre and dance!
Risks and challenges
Why We Need You!
Your contribution will allow us to compensate the leading artists, professional dancers and musicians as well as the community performers participating in the eight-week rehearsal and four public performances.
Pay the artists leading the four-week theatre dance workshop connecting community members across University Settlement to one another and their stores
Compensate the leading artists, community performers, professional dancer and musician for the eight-week rehearsal and four public performances
Equally pay all artists and community performers involved.
As a collective, we believe in honoring artists’ time and commitment to a project. Each community performer, professional dancer and musician must dedicate rehearsal and performance hours to make this new work come to life. This requires adjusting work schedules, finding child care, and lengthening commutes. As a theatre collective we believe in pay equity for everyone we work with.
Our current goal of $5,000 is minimally budgeted as follows:
Performance Stipend for Community Performers ($500 each) X 6 : $3,000 Performance Stipend for Dancers ($500 each) X 2 : $1,000 Performance Stipend for Musicians ($500 each) X 1 : $500Lighting Designer Stipend: $500 
TOTAL: $5,000

story:
Short Summary

Dalia Carella, international dance artist/artistic director of the Dalia Carella Dance Collective is excited to collaborate with stylist/designer/dancer Debbie Cartsos (D.Webb Designs) on an interactive and immersive dance production.  Ms. Carella's work transcends labels and genres as it explores themes of spirituality and mysticism, feminism, global diversity, and her dark and sultry cabaret stylings.  DCDC's collaboration with Mrs. Cartsos, whose extensive design and styling artistry provides a sophisticated urban direction to the program, will bring human fashion installations to life, merging the worlds of couture and dance while contributing to the artistic direction for the photography and videography for the production. Special thanks to New York City Photographer Monzeeki Photography for her amazing eye and helping us create the look for the show!

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our total expenses for the show are $18,000.  We are asking for $5,000 on Indiegogo to help offset some of the expenses towards costumes, theater rental and rehearsals.  We have raised over $2,000 and plan to fundraise through events, workshops and in-kind contributions this fall, but to realize our goals, we need your help as well.  In the past, DCDC has had four successful Kickstarter Campaigns, where we met our goals.  We are hoping for the same with Indiegogo!
  • If you donate to us during this campaign, you can earn some amazing perks.  Depending on how much you donate, our perks include shout outs, t-shirts, tote bags, beautiful note cards from DCDC's show "Cabaret de la Nuit", $100 gift certificate from D.Webb Designs, an Intuitive Tarot Reading by Dalia Carella, 2 Gala Tickets to Menagerie d'Arte and co-producer shout outs every night of the show! 

The Impact

We are so thrilled to be putting on a high-quality show at Teatro LATEA, a professional theater in downtown NYC.  This space will allow the Collective’s work to be professionally lit, incorporate intricate set design, and serve as a platform to film work samples for future production and touring opportunities.  Our goal is to tour this show in the US and abroad in 2019, inviting both domestic and international performers to participate.  Therefore, the better the original production the greater the chances the show will hit the road!

Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge of a small non-profit dance company is lack of funding.  Many deserving and special projects struggle to take off simply because there isn't enough money to fulfill the artistic vision.  In our case, even if our project is fully funded, we may still need to offset unexpected costs/difficulties by scaling down some of the artistic elements of our production.  This might mean choosing simpler (cheaper) costumes, lighting design or set design.  It might mean opting for a smaller press & social media campaign, which would ultimately limit our exposure and viewership.  It might even mean rehearsing fewer hours to save money when we’d rather take our time to develop the work.  These are the tough choices that we may have to make as we swing into the final phase of production.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute to this campaign, here's how you can help.

  • Get the word out and make some noise about our Indiegogo campaign and use the Indigogo share tools to tell them where to go and donate.  Also give us a shout out on your social media pages and follow our Instagram page: menagerie_d_arte
  • Come to our show on November 30 - December 2, 2018.  Go to http://www.daliacarella.com/menagerie-darte/ to purchase tickets.
  • We will be forever grateful indeed!

story:
About the Show

 

'Nothing in the world but work, even in your sleep you sweat' 

 

Missing Cat's 'Woyzeck' will be a radically pared down new adaptation of Georg Büchner's modern classic. Featuring a stripped back cast of three and a new translation of the original German text, Missing Cat explore the line between man and beast in a kaleidoscopic tale of love and jealousy. 

 

About Us

Joshua Silverlock and Saul Barrett are both RADA Foundation Graduates. In 2018 they founded Missing Cat Theatre. This will be their debut production.

In July 2018 they struck upon the idea of putting on Georg Büchner's modern classic 'Woyzeck'. The stripped back cast of only three will take on the 27 characters of the original text between them. 

 

"Woyzeck is one of my favourite plays, we both studied it at school, but for some reason it still isn't anywhere near as known as it should be - hopefully we can try to fix that" - Joshua.

 

Saul Barrett's new translation aims to distil the essence of the narrative whilst maintaining a searing relevance to today.

 

"Adapting the play for three actors has been challenging. I hope as a result it feels like a more intimate and focussed story." - Saul.

 

 

We have secured The Forest Theatre, a part of Greenside's Infirmary Street venue in Edinburgh. 

"Undoubtedly one of the most charming venues at the Fringe - Lyn Gardner"

 

We now need to raise the money to cover the variety of costs involved with taking a show to the Fringe. These include: 

  • Venue Hire
  • Rehearsal Space Hire
  • Production Costs (set/props/costume) 
  • Marketing 

 

The Show

Our production of 'Woyzeck' will be created as a company through an extended rehearsal period. Our first Research and Development period will begin two weeks from now in March - we will explore the ideas of the play and the various concepts we have for realising them.

Much of the show will remain open to change, however there are a number of guiding principles that we will adhere to:

  • 3 person cast
  • Actor-led production
  • Original music
  • Live sound design

 

Visual Touchstones

Images taken from: The Rite of Spring (Pina Bausch); Gundog (Vicky Featherstone -The Royal Court); Hedda Gabler (Ivo van Hove - National Theatre); Masurca Fogo (Pina Bausch); Grand Finale (Hofesh Shechter - Sadlers Wells)

 

Meet the Team!

Saul Barrett - Actor

Saul is a recent graduate of the RADA Foundation Course. He is also a member of the National Youth Theatre. He played the title role in Coriolanus and Platonov at RADA as well as appearing alongside graduating RADA students in a production of Journey's End by R.C. Sherriff, directed by Prasanna Puwanarajah at the George Bernard Shaw Theatre. He also acted in the 2014 feature film Fury and the music video Oceans for Seafret, directed by Jonathan Entwistle. He is a co-founder of Missing Cat Theatre. 

 

Emily Flo Carter - Actor 

Emily Flo Carter is a British/Ukrainian actress who graduated from the RADA Foundation Course. She is also a member of the National Youth Theatre. Recent acting credits include Volumnia in Coriolanus (RADA), Isobel in Insomniac (The Quarry Theatre), Magdalena in US (Camden People’s Theatre), Cassie in IC3 (Arcola-Scratch Night) and is currently working on an R&D with Contents May Differ. As well as acting, Emily produces theatre and performance art events and works as a model. 

 

Joshua Silverlock - Director

Joshua Silverlock is a recent graduate of the RADA Foundation Course. He has since worked both in film and theatre as a director. Most recently he directed Bear by Jamie Murphy at Katzpace. He has also assistant directed A Midsummer Night's Dream at the Etcetera Theatre, Camden. He is currently working on a modern adaptation of Aristophanes' The Frogs, premiering at The Stockwell Playhouse as well as a production of Teechers at the Wimbledon Studios. He has also directed a number of short films as well as a variety of new writing pieces whilst at RADA. He is a co-founder of Missing Cat Theatre. 

 

Johnny Edwards - Sound Designer 

Johnny is a graduate of The Royal Academy of Dramatic Art. Currently he is working at The Royal Court as the Sound Operator on Cyprus Avenue; Dir. Vicky Featherstone. He has worked as the Production Sound Engineer for Kenneth Branagh's production of Hamlet and Sound No. 1 on Sally Cookson's production of The Lion, The Witch And The Wardrobe. 

Previous Sound Designs include: Moorcroft by Eilidh Loan (Tristan Bates), In The Wake Of  by Michael Black (Lion and Unicorn), Journey's End (GBS Theatre), Stuff Happens (Vanbrugh Theatre) and The Winter's Tale (Vanbrugh Theatre).

 

Francesca Jones - Set & Costume Designer

Francesca is a British third year student studying BA Fine Art at the University of the Arts London, Chelsea College. She had her first professional experience at the BBC in 2014 assisting the Art Director with the second TV series of The Paradise. She returned again in 2015, with the second series of Atlantis. Last year, she was asked to return to work on the ITV film Born A King, where she was responsible for designing and sourcing props. Her debut as a Production Designer was for the month-long run of Precious Little Talent, a stage production by Ella Hickson at the Courtyard Theatre in 2018.

 

 

Leo Clasen - Head of Marketing 

Leo Clasen is a Psychology Graduate from the University of York as well as a graduate of the Drama Centre Foundation. During his time at University he was involved in a number of plays as an Actor, Director, Stage Manager and Assistant Producer. He is keen to apply the knowledge and skills from his degree to his passion for theatre in his role as Head of Marketing.

 

 

Costs of 'Woyzeck' 

Taking a show to the Edinburgh Fringe comes with quite a few costs. Here's what your money would go towards:  

  • Theatre hire                                                                      £2956.80
  • Production Costs (Set, props, costume etc.)       £600
  • Marketing/Flyers                                                           £150.00
  • Rehearsal Space Hire                                                   £500.00
  • Fringe Registration Fee                                                £295.20

   

Total:                                                                                          £4,502.

 

Our aim is to raise £3,000 to cover the costs of hiring our performance venue. If we surpass this amount we plan to continue fundraising in order to support the other aspects of the production. 

 

How We'll Say Thank You

If you are interested and want to donate, here are a few ways we'll be saying thank you!

  • A shout out on social media! 
  • A handwritten thank you note from all the cast!
  • A signed poster!
  • A signed script! 
  • Exclusive tickets to an open rehearsal!

Even if you can't contribute financially your support goes a really long way!

Follow us on Twitter (@AbsentPaws) Instagram (@missingcattheatre) and Facebook (Missing Cat Theatre) - like, share, retweet - word of mouth is invaluable!

story:
We’re gearing up for a big renovation to our lobby and we need your help!

The Seacoast Rep has come a long way in the past four years. We’ve settled more than $400,000 worth of debts, repaired relationships in the community, installed a brand new HVAC system that keeps our theatre comfortable and allows us to produce year round, we’ve expanded our programming, not only in number of performances, but in the quality of our productions. We’ve created a new Senior Repertory company that is thriving, re-vamped our Red Light series, and restructured our Portsmouth Academy of Performing Arts and now we’re teaching more students than ever before. We’ve grown our sales, our staff, and our budgets, all while paying down debt.

 

In the past four years we’ve thought a lot about what community means and how important it is to our theater and the role that theater plays in the community. Our community is built right into our mission. During these past four  years we’ve donated over $200,000 worth of tickets for use in local fundraisers and over $100,000 worth of tickets to our community partners such as Amy’s Treat, Krempels Center, The Chase Home, Haven, Cross Roads House, and more - bringing theatre into the lives of those who otherwise might have trouble experiencing it.

During these past four years we’ve employed hundreds of independent contractors, both locally and from around the country. We’re proud to have provided such a great experience that many of them have relocated to the area to work with us. We’ve been lucky to learn from many other great arts organizations in the Seacoast, while mentoring aspiring technicians, designers, and performers.

We consider ourselves a safe and welcoming organization where we strive to set standards in the entertainment industry and upholding those standards, as difficult as that may be at times.

We have more dreams, more goals, and so much more work to do. This doesn’t daunt us. It excites us. Some of these dreams and goals can wait as we prioritize our needs. Some needs, however, can’t wait.

We often get feedback along the lines of “You always seem to be fundraising. It’s a lot.” Believe us, we get it. We are. But the fact of the matter is, our team inherited hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of debt and decades of building maintenance that had, quite frankly, been put off. As much as we’d like to transition out of this sort of fundraising, we aren’t at that point quite yet. Every year we make progress and check things off of our to-do list. We’re now just a few years away from being debt free. We have about $200,000 more to go, and we’re trying our best not to incur any new debts.

We’ve already tackled some serious building issues such as rebuilding three flights of concrete and steel staircases, adding railings, adding emergency lighting, identifying and fixing a major leak in our women’s bathroom, and dealing with so many more tiny and mundane but important details. But the work isn’t done yet. The rest of the work that needs to be done at the theatre, as per the fire departments mandates, needs to be completed this year.

 

Here is where we are at:

We need to have a sprinkler system installed in our lobby. Working with the city, we had set a deadline of December 1st, 2018. However, as our engineers started to dig in, they discovered all sorts of obstacles - as one does with old buildings and old city plumbing. In short, they found that the deadline given, and the the initial estimate would not be feasible - the water pressure just isn’t enough to power all of the sprinkler heads we need to cover the space.

The sprinkler company we are working with, in conjunction with John Destefano from DeStefano & Associates, thoroughly researched all options to bring a sprinkler system in the lobby that would meet code. The least expensive option happens to be the best option for our neighbors as well, as it will not involve tearing up Bow st and wreaking havoc on that part of town. This option includes installing a suspended ceiling in our lobby. We know it sounds strange, but reducing the vertical square footage in our lobby allows us to install fewer sprinkler heads, which addresses a water pressure challenge we were facing before. That means we don’t have to pay the City to tear up Bow Street to install larger pipes.

We had a team of seasoned professional exploring every single option, and this one was determined to be the best one. It still gets quite complicated as in order to install a suspended ceiling: our leaky roof needs to be addressed, we will have to deal with heating and cooling issues in the lobby, we will have to build walls in the open walkway up above for our neighbors, and so on.

 

In order to meet all fire code mandates, we will need to raise a minimum of $180,000. This also includes the small portion of remaining work that must be done in the theater itself. We’ve been given a final deadline, which means we start work on this in May and we end the work in late summer. Thanks to our experts - we can do this without missing a single show or rehearsal.

This sounds like a lot - and it is. We’ve decided to take this as an opportunity to make long overdue improvements to our lobby. And now we’re actually all excited about providing you with a lobby experience that matches the quality of the productions you see on our stage every night. Let’s be honest, our lobby has been a point of embarrassment. We’re not particularly proud to have buckets out in our lobby every time it rains, or walls of ice on the inside of our walls every time it gets cold outside.  

When people have been hearing $180,000, after the sticker shock shock, they ask “can you raise this amount in such short a time?” Our answer is that we can because have no other choice. We have to raise these funds by the deadline or we will have to halt programming until we can. That is not an option for us, so we will get this done, one way or another, even if it means incurring more debt. We don’t want to do this, but we will if we have to.

We will be raising funds through multiple sources - grants, individual donations, and sponsorships. We already have raised quite a bit towards our goal.

Making a donation to this campaign is not only supporting our safety benchmarks, but it’s an investment in our future, as money we put into building improvements come off of the purchase price for the space at the end of our 10 year lease. We are a in the third year of our lease.

This $180,000 project doesn’t improve the cosmetics of the space by much. It is a minimum price tag. We’d love to avoid having a boring white suspended ceiling, so we’ve worked closely with DeStefano & Associates, Bob & Sue Thoresen, and Manypenny | Murphy Architecture to price out some aesthetic options. We’ve come up with a plan for some stretch goals once the initial funds are raised.

Stretch Goal One - Raise $280,000

With this stretch goal we would be able to do the following:

  • Re-do our bathrooms with improved ventilation in the men’s room, new stalls, new floors, new fixtures, new ceilings. They’ll look beautiful but they’ll also have more sustainable elements in them like hand blowers to reduce the need for paper towels. We’ll try to make them more ADA friendly where possible. We’ll be proud of how they’ll look and you’ll feel better in them.
  • Install new flooring. Alyssa from Manypenny |  Murphy and Bob Thoresen have been lending us their keen eyes to pick out some commercial grade flooring that will look good, be easy to clean, and it will all be level. We’re kind of really excited about this one. No more gray carpet and faux wood flooring!
  • Remove the glass walling in the lobby back and sides, insulate it, and restore it as a functioning art gallery once again.
  • Install a more attractive suspended ceiling that can tie in a theme of a room while highlighting certain areas such as the bar and box office. There are sleek modern designs that we’d love to incorporate elevating the look, feel, and experience of our lobby.
  • Make improvements to the bar, such as extending it to provide more seating options for our patrons. We’d also work on providing actual shelving and storage area for Mark behind the bar as well, making the area look like a bar that could rival others in town.
 

Stretch Goal Two - $350,000

With this stretch goal we would be able to do all of the above with the following additions:

  • We would be able to expand the footprint of our bathrooms by moving our box office to a different location. Designs have shown we can add two more toilets to each restroom. Did you hear that ladies? TWO MORE TOILETS. That means less time waiting in line during intermission. We’ve been listening to your feedback.

We are excited to launch this fundraiser with a very generous matching donation of $25,000 from one anonymous donor and another $10,000 matching donation from another anonymous donor.

 

Here is how you can help:

  • Make a tax deductible donation through this website.
  • Send in a tax deductible donation to the Seacoast Rep at 125 Bow St Portsmouth NH 03801
  • Offer another matching donation!
  • Share this fundraiser.

If you’re considering making larger gift to the Rep, we ask that you do it directly through us to avoid fees. We would gladly take you through a private tour and show you the work that has been done and the remaining work that needs to be done. Please contact Kathleen to set up a private tour.

 

Thank you.
story_txt:
We’re gearing up for a big renovation to our lobby and we need your help!
The Seacoast Rep has come a long way in the past four years. We’ve settled more than $400,000 worth of debts, repaired relationships in the community, installed a brand new HVAC system that keeps our theatre comfortable and allows us to produce year round, we’ve expanded our programming, not only in number of performances, but in the quality of our productions. We’ve created a new Senior Repertory company that is thriving, re-vamped our Red Light series, and restructured our Portsmouth Academy of Performing Arts and now we’re teaching more students than ever before. We’ve grown our sales, our staff, and our budgets, all while paying down debt. In the past four years we’ve thought a lot about what community means and how important it is to our theater and the role that theater plays in the community. Our community is built right into our mission. During these past four  years we’ve donated over $200,000 worth of tickets for use in local fundraisers and over $100,000 worth of tickets to our community partners such as Amy’s Treat, Krempels Center, The Chase Home, Haven, Cross Roads House, and more - bringing theatre into the lives of those who otherwise might have trouble experiencing it.
During these past four years we’ve employed hundreds of independent contractors, both locally and from around the country. We’re proud to have provided such a great experience that many of them have relocated to the area to work with us. We’ve been lucky to learn from many other great arts organizations in the Seacoast, while mentoring aspiring technicians, designers, and performers.
We consider ourselves a safe and welcoming organization where we strive to set standards in the entertainment industry and upholding those standards, as difficult as that may be at times.
We have more dreams, more goals, and so much more work to do. This doesn’t daunt us. It excites us. Some of these dreams and goals can wait as we prioritize our needs. Some needs, however, can’t wait.
We often get feedback along the lines of “You always seem to be fundraising. It’s a lot.” Believe us, we get it. We are. But the fact of the matter is, our team inherited hundreds of thousands of dollars worth of debt and decades of building maintenance that had, quite frankly, been put off. As much as we’d like to transition out of this sort of fundraising, we aren’t at that point quite yet. Every year we make progress and check things off of our to-do list. We’re now just a few years away from being debt free. We have about $200,000 more to go, and we’re trying our best not to incur any new debts.
We’ve already tackled some serious building issues such as rebuilding three flights of concrete and steel staircases, adding railings, adding emergency lighting, identifying and fixing a major leak in our women’s bathroom, and dealing with so many more tiny and mundane but important details. But the work isn’t done yet. The rest of the work that needs to be done at the theatre, as per the fire departments mandates, needs to be completed this year. Here is where we are at:
We need to have a sprinkler system installed in our lobby. Working with the city, we had set a deadline of December 1st, 2018. However, as our engineers started to dig in, they discovered all sorts of obstacles - as one does with old buildings and old city plumbing. In short, they found that the deadline given, and the the initial estimate would not be feasible - the water pressure just isn’t enough to power all of the sprinkler heads we need to cover the space.
The sprinkler company we are working with, in conjunction with John Destefano from DeStefano & Associates, thoroughly researched all options to bring a sprinkler system in the lobby that would meet code. The least expensive option happens to be the best option for our neighbors as well, as it will not involve tearing up Bow st and wreaking havoc on that part of town. This option includes installing a suspended ceiling in our lobby. We know it sounds strange, but reducing the vertical square footage in our lobby allows us to install fewer sprinkler heads, which addresses a water pressure challenge we were facing before. That means we don’t have to pay the City to tear up Bow Street to install larger pipes.
We had a team of seasoned professional exploring every single option, and this one was determined to be the best one. It still gets quite complicated as in order to install a suspended ceiling: our leaky roof needs to be addressed, we will have to deal with heating and cooling issues in the lobby, we will have to build walls in the open walkway up above for our neighbors, and so on. In order to meet all fire code mandates, we will need to raise a minimum of $180,000. This also includes the small portion of remaining work that must be done in the theater itself. We’ve been given a final deadline, which means we start work on this in May and we end the work in late summer. Thanks to our experts - we can do this without missing a single show or rehearsal.
This sounds like a lot - and it is. We’ve decided to take this as an opportunity to make long overdue improvements to our lobby. And now we’re actually all excited about providing you with a lobby experience that matches the quality of the productions you see on our stage every night. Let’s be honest, our lobby has been a point of embarrassment. We’re not particularly proud to have buckets out in our lobby every time it rains, or walls of ice on the inside of our walls every time it gets cold outside.  
When people have been hearing $180,000, after the sticker shock shock, they ask “can you raise this amount in such short a time?” Our answer is that we can because have no other choice. We have to raise these funds by the deadline or we will have to halt programming until we can. That is not an option for us, so we will get this done, one way or another, even if it means incurring more debt. We don’t want to do this, but we will if we have to.
We will be raising funds through multiple sources - grants, individual donations, and sponsorships. We already have raised quite a bit towards our goal.
Making a donation to this campaign is not only supporting our safety benchmarks, but it’s an investment in our future, as money we put into building improvements come off of the purchase price for the space at the end of our 10 year lease. We are a in the third year of our lease.
This $180,000 project doesn’t improve the cosmetics of the space by much. It is a minimum price tag. We’d love to avoid having a boring white suspended ceiling, so we’ve worked closely with DeStefano & Associates, Bob & Sue Thoresen, and Manypenny | Murphy Architecture to price out some aesthetic options. We’ve come up with a plan for some stretch goals once the initial funds are raised.
Stretch Goal One - Raise $280,000
With this stretch goal we would be able to do the following:

Re-do our bathrooms with improved ventilation in the men’s room, new stalls, new floors, new fixtures, new ceilings. They’ll look beautiful but they’ll also have more sustainable elements in them like hand blowers to reduce the need for paper towels. We’ll try to make them more ADA friendly where possible. We’ll be proud of how they’ll look and you’ll feel better in them.
Install new flooring. Alyssa from Manypenny |  Murphy and Bob Thoresen have been lending us their keen eyes to pick out some commercial grade flooring that will look good, be easy to clean, and it will all be level. We’re kind of really excited about this one. No more gray carpet and faux wood flooring!
Remove the glass walling in the lobby back and sides, insulate it, and restore it as a functioning art gallery once again.
Install a more attractive suspended ceiling that can tie in a theme of a room while highlighting certain areas such as the bar and box office. There are sleek modern designs that we’d love to incorporate elevating the look, feel, and experience of our lobby.
Make improvements to the bar, such as extending it to provide more seating options for our patrons. We’d also work on providing actual shelving and storage area for Mark behind the bar as well, making the area look like a bar that could rival others in town.
 Stretch Goal Two - $350,000
With this stretch goal we would be able to do all of the above with the following additions:
We would be able to expand the footprint of our bathrooms by moving our box office to a different location. Designs have shown we can add two more toilets to each restroom. Did you hear that ladies? TWO MORE TOILETS. That means less time waiting in line during intermission. We’ve been listening to your feedback.
We are excited to launch this fundraiser with a very generous matching donation of $25,000 from one anonymous donor and another $10,000 matching donation from another anonymous donor. Here is how you can help:

Make a tax deductible donation through this website.
Send in a tax deductible donation to the Seacoast Rep at 125 Bow St Portsmouth NH 03801
Offer another matching donation!
Share this fundraiser.

If you’re considering making larger gift to the Rep, we ask that you do it directly through us to avoid fees. We would gladly take you through a private tour and show you the work that has been done and the remaining work that needs to be done. Please contact Kathleen to set up a private tour. Thank you.

story:
What We Need & Why

We need as much money as we can get! With your help, we can seriously fund this incredible project and create some touching and powerful art. 

Our Goal of $8,500 will be used for rentals of rehearsal spaces, set, lighting, costumes and pay for the performers & orchestra! 

 

The Show

Turkeys Go on Strike will be featured as part of a festival held at the world-famous Theatre for the New City, The Hudson Guild Theater and have a special concert version between August 2019 - January 2020. We need your help to make our events & shows happen so we can tell the world our story of love, acceptance and equality. 

 

Summary of the Show

Turkeys Go on Strike: A New Musical is a political satire about love, accepting one another and ending racial discrimination and injustice.

Turkeys Go on Strike is set in a world where Humans and Turkeys communicate with each other within their daily lives. Turk, an outcast, realizes the truth behind his corrupt government and the hate groups whom seem to demonize the hard work and lives of turkeys. In an attempt to find answers for his pack, he uncovers a dirty truth behind their government. Reminiscent of the Black Lives Matter movement and other political demonstrations, Turkeys Go on Strike: A New Musical satirically captures today's society in a way that is very unique and funny for all ages. With music ranging from 60's doo-wop to "Hamilton" styled Hip Hop, this show has something for everyone to enjoy with a message that will get you questioning our society's major social issues.

 

The Impact

Your contribution has a great impact to our show! 

-We will be able to get our beautiful message of love and acceptance to a larger audience. 

-A portion of proceeds of our live concert will be going towards the NYC-based non-profit, Meals on Us.

-With its humor & subjects meant for all ages, we hope this show can inspire and educate youth and adults alike. 

-Be able to present our show to other production companies interested in partnering, investors, producers and more for future productions! 

 

Risks & Challenges

Oh, trust us! While our objective is set, the hurdle to accomplish that objective is a large one!

We know that there are hundreds of campaigns so getting visibility will not only be a challenge, but a huge responsibility for our team. We are ready for the challenge.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help. Make some noise about our campaign! Share our Hashtag along with our link to the campaign using #TurkeysMusical!

Remember you can use Indiegogo's incredible share tools to share on your Facebook, Twitter, Instagram & more!

Don't forget to stay connected with us online at www.turkeysmusical.com or on Facebook, Twitter & Instagram!

 

And that's all there is to it. If you aren't convinced... contact us at info@ckproductionsnewyork.com. We'd love to convince you! Thank you for your contribution, your share(s) and your support!

story:
Workshop performance at Rockwall Studios, Brooklyn. September 2017.

Solarplexus? I thought that was the third chakra of power and wisdom?

You're right. It is. But it's also a sci-fi comedy about the apocalypse, environmentalism, and corporate greed.

With a climate-change apocalypse approaching, Ellen and her corporatized brother seek refuge on their father's sustainable, eco-friendly commune. His plan to save the world? A gender-fluid, pedal-powered bicycle named Mercury Daniels. But you'd better hope they can set aside their differences before the CEO of that mega tech corporation, Syzygy, gets his hands on them. Will the family overcome their clashing beliefs and save the world with the forces of renewable energy?

Outside of the world of the play, Solarplexus is committed to the values of its script through action. One year ago, when we staged the first production of the play at Rockwall Studios in Brooklyn, we partnered with André Feliciano to build a pedal-powered bicycle as a set piece, able to convert mechanical energy (pedaling) into electrical energy (the show’s lighting), and simultaneously function as a central part of the story’s plot. The bicycle stored energy as well, and we are proud to have successfully powered all of the production’s lights through our pedal-powered bicycle, Mercury. We also used solar power and only LED bulbs in lighting the show.

As a group of artists, we believe in the intersection between art and the environment, between storytelling and science, and we are committed to telling stories about these essential relationships. Theater isn’t going to single-handedly stop climate change. But we believe it can and must advocate strongly for social movements, lending its voice to amplify the direct political actions taking place in society. As a company, we see the opportunity in Edinburgh as the beginning of a long-term mission to realize these beliefs.

Model of the pedal-powered bicycle. Photo provided by André​ Feliciano.

Speaking of which, tell me about this "Edinburgh Fringe."

The Edinburgh Fringe is the largest of its kind in the world, selling over 2.5 million tickets in its record-breaking 2017 season. For an emerging theater company, it provides the opportunity for unrivalled exposure to new audiences, fellow artists, and members of the press through 23 performances over the course of a month.

Thousands of shows are accepted into the festival (from theatre to comedy to music). With so many shows performing, the best way to stand out from the crowd is to be selected by a reputable venue. We are excited to announce we will perform in a primetime slot at ZOO Venues, “a premier location for an international programme of dance and physical theatre” (The Herald).

Even with the help of their host venues, companies are responsible for marketing their show and bringing sizable audiences to recoup production costs. Artists spend their days before performances selling tickets by way of innovative street performances, from music, to magic tricks, to pure spectacle. We think our show is a great fit for the festival and know that Mercury Daniels (our pedal-powered bicycle) will turn heads on the streets of Edinburgh.

Link to tickets for our Edinburgh run: https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/solarplex...

 

Who's a part of this?

   

Melissa Mahoney (Ellen) is an actor, singer, and teaching artist from New York City.  She has played title roles in three critically acclaimed productions at the Atlantic Theater Company ("with spunk to spare", says The New York Times), as well as at Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival, Ars Nova, and in theaters across the United States.  She is also a solo performer (Melissa Mahoney is a Robot) and a voice actor (Night Vale Presents' It Makes a Sound podcast).  BFA: NYU Tisch/Atlantic Acting School.  For more info, visit http://melissamahoney.me

Sam Metzger (Frank Jr. / Producer) is an actor and teaching artist living in Brooklyn, New York. He is a company member of the Irondale Ensemble Project and has been in Irondale’s productions of Saint Joan of the Stockyards, 1599 Project, and Life of Galileo. Sam works with high-school STEM students, playing improv games to improve communication, and ensure that our future scientific leaders are able to clearly explain to the public what their work means and why it’s important. Sam is also a facilitator of To Protect, Serve and Understand, a partnership between Irondale and the NYPD. Sam is so excited to be a part of taking Solarplexus to Edinburgh and can’t wait to share this ecologically conscious production with as many people as possible!

​Justin Picado (CEO / Sun God) is a NYC actor and graduate of the first class of New York University's New Studio on Broadway. He has appeared Off-Off Broadway in La Mama E.T.C's production of Frogs. He is thrilled to be a part of the cast of Solarplexus and cannot wait to show Scotland what the passionate cast and crew have been working on. When not performing, Justin enjoys re-watching Twin Peaks and discovering new recipes and cooking techniques.

Michael Galligan (Frank Sr. / Producer / Playwright) is a Brooklyn-based writer, actor and producer. He completed his BFA in Drama from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts in 2014. Since then, Michael has written and self-produced plays, monthly sketch comedy shows, and some web content. Presently, he is focused on creating a series of eco-conscious theatrical productions through which we can examine the society we've built, and its destructive impact on the planet. Michael also teaches with the Irondale Center. 

Jaye Hunt (Director) has worked as a director/assistant/associate/etc. at Transport Group, Classic Stage Company, The Playwrights Realm, Ars Nova, and Undiscovered Countries, among others. She is also the co-host of the podcast One More Thing, which has been featured in People Magazine, Newsweek, Us Weekly, and on E! News. For more you can visit her infrequently updated website http://www.jayehunt.com or catch her on twitter @hayejunt.

Robert Fernandez (Composer) is a composer and musician based in New York City. He received his BA in Music and Philosophy from Columbia University, and performs regularly as a jazz / bluegrass double bassist. Although Robert has written music for the concert hall, film, and theater, he is solar-fired about his first time working on an alternative energy play. 

 

Where is my money going?

Artist payments: 22% ($6,700)

In addition to compensating actors with airfare, housing for the month, and a stipend, we'll need to assemble a team of designers (and a director and stage manager) to help prepare the show for its launch in Edinburgh. 

Marketing and promotion: 17% ($5,200)

The Edinburgh Fringe, with its vastness of shows, relies on performers to do a good deal of self-promotion. And it's not like comedy shows in Times Square - for the month of August, this kind of interaction actually works. The more we can stop passersby on the streets, the more seats we'll fill in the audience.

Production costs: 11% ($3,200)

At the end of the day, the play itself is the most important component to our success over in Edinburgh. Our set will be somewhat minimalist to highlight the pedal-powered bicycle, but we will still need materials for set design, funds for rehearsal rentals, and equipment for lighting and sound design. Thankfully, we're able to reuse resources and equipment from our last run, like the synthesizer Robert plays throughout the show. (Shout Out to all previous supporters!)

Housing accommodation: 17% ($5,000)

We'll be performing the show 23 times in just under four weeks. With such an intense commitment, the need for quiet, comfortable housing is of great importance! 

Transportation: 16% ($4,700)

Scotland is very far! Money is hard to make! In order to make the project more financially feasible for the artists involved, we're offering to cover round trip airfare to Edinburgh. 

Contingency: 17% ($5,200)

Due to the international travel aspect of this project, we will need to reserve a portion of total expenses in case of any unforeseen circumstances.

Woah, that's a bigger budget than you're fundraising for!?

Yes it is. Thanks to personal investments and previous fundraising, we are just under ⅔ of the way towards raising our budget. We’ve come to Indiegogo because we need your help, we need a final push to get that last ⅓ and ensure that Solarplexus: An Alternative Energy Play has as large an impact as possible at The Fringe this summer. (And that we don't go into debt!)

The cast of Solarplexus: An Alternative Energy Play

Environmental Advocacy

Solarplexus looks at direct-action activism, corporate corruption, and the double-edged sword of technology through the lens of a dysfunctional family with radically different life philosophies and political views. Through their different approaches to taking on the climate-change apocalypse at the foreground of the story, we constantly ask our audiences what actions can be taken to ensure that civilization’s activity is more closely aligned with the health and needs of the planet.

We believe that now is the time for live performance to put its spotlight on the extreme danger our planet faces; to tell exciting, powerful stories with an ecological bent, and through them, offer creative solutions.

Our goals at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe include:

  • Sourcing the entirety of our set from materials that we can recycle or reuse at the end of the production.
  • Commission an artist to create easy-to-read cartoons explaining how to build several of the DIY renewable energy projects we learned to build from André Feliciano.
  • Reach a large and engaged international audience with not just our performance, but with street demonstrations of our pedal-powered bicycle and our cartoons explaining how to build several DIY renewable energy projects.
  • Create an exciting, powerful play that demonstrates it is possible, and not inherently a cost-prohibitive venture, to stage a show that is ecologically conscious, not just on the page but in reality as well.

Frank's board of conspiracy theories. Rockwall Studios. September 2017.

Risks & Challenges

Producing a show at the Edinburgh Fringe can be risky business. Since much of the marketing and publicity work will depend on us, we have no way of guaranteeing a certain box office projection. Positive reviews and smart marketing strategies could give way to a successful financial venture, but with over 3,000 shows performing during the same month, it is possible for shows to blend in with the crowd.

With your support, we plan to rise to this challenge and mitigate these risks:

  • While in Edinburgh, a significant portion of our time will be dedicated to on-the-ground marketing. We believe aspects of our production (the bicycle, live music, etc.) will give us an edge over traditional marketing strategies.
  • We plan to aggressively contact UK-based publications and news organizations to generate as much press as possible ahead of the festival.
  • The Edinburgh Fringe Society offers some fail-safes in the case of low ticket sales. Offers like the Half-Price Ticket Hut, Comp Give-Aways for preview performances, and Royal Mile “Street Events” all give performers the chance to draw in audience members when things aren’t going so well.
  • Part of our fundraising accounts for a contingency of 10% of our total projected expenses. We will keep this in reserve to be sure that we can take advantage of any opportunities that come our way, such as printing and distributing reviews, continued interaction with members of the press, and maintaining a consistent marketing strategy.
  • Before performing in Edinburgh we will be staging the show for 3 performances, July 24th, 25th, and 28th at 59E59 as a dry-run before we head East. Buy tickets for those performances here.

Ellen feeling stuck in a box.

Don't Box Me In. How Else Can I Help?

Contributions are always appreciated, but there are certainly other ways you can help support this production:

  • Due to the environmental advocacy component of the project, we're interested in partnering with small business, corporations, and non-profits who could offer anything from financial contributions to product donations. If you know or are connected with an organization interested in the themes discussed, we'd love to be put in touch! 
  • We'll be traveling to a foreign country, so if you know of anyone in Edinburgh who might be interested in helping out on this production, there's plenty to do. Anything from helping us with street marketing to connecting with local businesses to lending us a spare bicycle would all be welcomed with open arms.
  • Lastly, if none of these options are available to you, please consider following us on social media and/or sharing our campaign to your network. You never know who will be interested!
  • If you're off social media, good for you. 

 

 Partners

                                                          

    Irondale                                         Zoo Venues                                    André Feliciano

 

 

Follow us on social media:
