The Edinburgh Fringe is the largest of its kind in the world, selling over 2.5 million tickets in its record-breaking 2017 season. For an emerging theater company, it provides the opportunity for unrivalled exposure to new audiences, fellow artists, and members of the press through 23 performances over the course of a month.
Thousands of shows are accepted into the festival (from theatre to comedy to music). With so many shows performing, the best way to stand out from the crowd is to be selected by a reputable venue. We are excited to announce we will perform in a primetime slot at ZOO Venues, “a premier location for an international programme of dance and physical theatre” (The Herald).
Even with the help of their host venues, companies are responsible for marketing their show and bringing sizable audiences to recoup production costs. Artists spend their days before performances selling tickets by way of innovative street performances, from music, to magic tricks, to pure spectacle. We think our show is a great fit for the festival and know that Mercury Daniels (our pedal-powered bicycle) will turn heads on the streets of Edinburgh.
Link to tickets for our Edinburgh run: https://tickets.edfringe.com/whats-on/solarplex...

 
Who's a part of this?
   
Melissa Mahoney (Ellen) is an actor, singer, and teaching artist from New York City.  She has played title roles in three critically acclaimed productions at the Atlantic Theater Company ("with spunk to spare", says The New York Times), as well as at Hudson Valley Shakespeare Festival, Ars Nova, and in theaters across the United States.  She is also a solo performer (Melissa Mahoney is a Robot) and a voice actor (Night Vale Presents' It Makes a Sound podcast).  BFA: NYU Tisch/Atlantic Acting School.  For more info, visit http://melissamahoney.me

Sam Metzger (Frank Jr. / Producer) is an actor and teaching artist living in Brooklyn, New York. He is a company member of the Irondale Ensemble Project and has been in Irondale’s productions of Saint Joan of the Stockyards, 1599 Project, and Life of Galileo. Sam works with high-school STEM students, playing improv games to improve communication, and ensure that our future scientific leaders are able to clearly explain to the public what their work means and why it’s important. Sam is also a facilitator of To Protect, Serve and Understand, a partnership between Irondale and the NYPD. Sam is so excited to be a part of taking Solarplexus to Edinburgh and can’t wait to share this ecologically conscious production with as many people as possible!

​Justin Picado (CEO / Sun God) is a NYC actor and graduate of the first class of New York University's New Studio on Broadway. He has appeared Off-Off Broadway in La Mama E.T.C's production of Frogs. He is thrilled to be a part of the cast of Solarplexus and cannot wait to show Scotland what the passionate cast and crew have been working on. When not performing, Justin enjoys re-watching Twin Peaks and discovering new recipes and cooking techniques.

Michael Galligan (Frank Sr. / Producer / Playwright) is a Brooklyn-based writer, actor and producer. He completed his BFA in Drama from NYU's Tisch School of the Arts in 2014. Since then, Michael has written and self-produced plays, monthly sketch comedy shows, and some web content. Presently, he is focused on creating a series of eco-conscious theatrical productions through which we can examine the society we've built, and its destructive impact on the planet. Michael also teaches with the Irondale Center. 

Jaye Hunt (Director) has worked as a director/assistant/associate/etc. at Transport Group, Classic Stage Company, The Playwrights Realm, Ars Nova, and Undiscovered Countries, among others. She is also the co-host of the podcast One More Thing, which has been featured in People Magazine, Newsweek, Us Weekly, and on E! News. For more you can visit her infrequently updated website http://www.jayehunt.com or catch her on twitter @hayejunt.

Robert Fernandez (Composer) is a composer and musician based in New York City. He received his BA in Music and Philosophy from Columbia University, and performs regularly as a jazz / bluegrass double bassist. Although Robert has written music for the concert hall, film, and theater, he is solar-fired about his first time working on an alternative energy play. 
 
Where is my money going?
Artist payments: 22% ($6,700)
In addition to compensating actors with airfare, housing for the month, and a stipend, we'll need to assemble a team of designers (and a director and stage manager) to help prepare the show for its launch in Edinburgh. 
Marketing and promotion: 17% ($5,200)
The Edinburgh Fringe, with its vastness of shows, relies on performers to do a good deal of self-promotion. And it's not like comedy shows in Times Square - for the month of August, this kind of interaction actually works. The more we can stop passersby on the streets, the more seats we'll fill in the audience.
Production costs: 11% ($3,200)
At the end of the day, the play itself is the most important component to our success over in Edinburgh. Our set will be somewhat minimalist to highlight the pedal-powered bicycle, but we will still need materials for set design, funds for rehearsal rentals, and equipment for lighting and sound design. Thankfully, we're able to reuse resources and equipment from our last run, like the synthesizer Robert plays throughout the show. (Shout Out to all previous supporters!)
Housing accommodation: 17% ($5,000)
We'll be performing the show 23 times in just under four weeks. With such an intense commitment, the need for quiet, comfortable housing is of great importance! 
Transportation: 16% ($4,700)
Scotland is very far! Money is hard to make! In order to make the project more financially feasible for the artists involved, we're offering to cover round trip airfare to Edinburgh. 
Contingency: 17% ($5,200)
Due to the international travel aspect of this project, we will need to reserve a portion of total expenses in case of any unforeseen circumstances.
Woah, that's a bigger budget than you're fundraising for!?
Yes it is. Thanks to personal investments and previous fundraising, we are just under ⅔ of the way towards raising our budget. We’ve come to Indiegogo because we need your help, we need a final push to get that last ⅓ and ensure that Solarplexus: An Alternative Energy Play has as large an impact as possible at The Fringe this summer. (And that we don't go into debt!)

The cast of Solarplexus: An Alternative Energy Play

Environmental Advocacy
Solarplexus looks at direct-action activism, corporate corruption, and the double-edged sword of technology through the lens of a dysfunctional family with radically different life philosophies and political views. Through their different approaches to taking on the climate-change apocalypse at the foreground of the story, we constantly ask our audiences what actions can be taken to ensure that civilization’s activity is more closely aligned with the health and needs of the planet.
We believe that now is the time for live performance to put its spotlight on the extreme danger our planet faces; to tell exciting, powerful stories with an ecological bent, and through them, offer creative solutions.
Our goals at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe include:

Sourcing the entirety of our set from materials that we can recycle or reuse at the end of the production.

Commission an artist to create easy-to-read cartoons explaining how to build several of the DIY renewable energy projects we learned to build from André Feliciano.

Reach a large and engaged international audience with not just our performance, but with street demonstrations of our pedal-powered bicycle and our cartoons explaining how to build several DIY renewable energy projects.
Create an exciting, powerful play that demonstrates it is possible, and not inherently a cost-prohibitive venture, to stage a show that is ecologically conscious, not just on the page but in reality as well.


Frank's board of conspiracy theories. Rockwall Studios. September 2017.

Risks & Challenges
Producing a show at the Edinburgh Fringe can be risky business. Since much of the marketing and publicity work will depend on us, we have no way of guaranteeing a certain box office projection. Positive reviews and smart marketing strategies could give way to a successful financial venture, but with over 3,000 shows performing during the same month, it is possible for shows to blend in with the crowd.
With your support, we plan to rise to this challenge and mitigate these risks:

While in Edinburgh, a significant portion of our time will be dedicated to on-the-ground marketing. We believe aspects of our production (the bicycle, live music, etc.) will give us an edge over traditional marketing strategies.

We plan to aggressively contact UK-based publications and news organizations to generate as much press as possible ahead of the festival.

The Edinburgh Fringe Society offers some fail-safes in the case of low ticket sales. Offers like the Half-Price Ticket Hut, Comp Give-Aways for preview performances, and Royal Mile “Street Events” all give performers the chance to draw in audience members when things aren’t going so well.
Part of our fundraising accounts for a contingency of 10% of our total projected expenses. We will keep this in reserve to be sure that we can take advantage of any opportunities that come our way, such as printing and distributing reviews, continued interaction with members of the press, and maintaining a consistent marketing strategy.
Before performing in Edinburgh we will be staging the show for 3 performances, July 24th, 25th, and 28th at 59E59 as a dry-run before we head East. Buy tickets for those performances here.



Ellen feeling stuck in a box.
Don't Box Me In. How Else Can I Help?
Contributions are always appreciated, but there are certainly other ways you can help support this production:

Due to the environmental advocacy component of the project, we're interested in partnering with small business, corporations, and non-profits who could offer anything from financial contributions to product donations. If you know or are connected with an organization interested in the themes discussed, we'd love to be put in touch! 
We'll be traveling to a foreign country, so if you know of anyone in Edinburgh who might be interested in helping out on this production, there's plenty to do. Anything from helping us with street marketing to connecting with local businesses to lending us a spare bicycle would all be welcomed with open arms.
Lastly, if none of these options are available to you, please consider following us on social media and/or sharing our campaign to your network. You never know who will be interested!
If you're off social media, good for you. 



 
 Partners
                                                          
    Irondale                                         Zoo Venues                                    André Feliciano
 
 
Follow us on social media:

story:
MANY RIVERS CROSSED

Introduction

Many Rivers Crossed is a new solo play written by Richard Canal, co-directed with George Goodell, and performed by Emeson Nwolie, due to premier at the Landor_Space in London, UK from September 5th to 11th of 2018 and then at the Cockpit (also in London) from September 18th to 23rd. Although some resources are available, we unfortunately do not have enough to cover all the costs; and, thus, we are turning to crowdfunding.

About the Play

It is February 22nd, 2002. Ambushed at breakfast in the open savanna of eastern Angola, Jonas Savimbi—the infamous warlord and leader of the UNITA rebels—has just been killed by government troops. After twenty-seven years of civil war, since independence in 1975, what was one of Africa’s longest and deadliest conflicts has at long last reached its inevitable end. Angolans will soon dance and rejoice in the streets at the demise of the man many condemn as the sole perpetuator of the war: Savimbi’s personal vendetta against the incumbent party, and against Angola as a whole for not having chosen him in the 1992 elections, resulted in the loss of 500,000 lives, and left a country that could have been the continent’s richest among its poorest. He suddenly wakes up—dead, bullet-ridden and surrounded by a tribunal of the ghosts of those killed by his hubris. He is confronted by the pain he has wreaked on Angola; and in an attempt to have his soul depart this limbo in peace, he explains himself—but whether he is willing apologise and repent is unclear.

The audience, when entering the space, becomes an active judicial court reminiscent of those in central African tradition,  sitting around the space and facing both Savimbi and each other, present to judge over his after-death fate. The ideal experience in viewing his madness will be for the audience to feel a stimulant anger—much in the way theatre of the oppressed does—in the name of action against others’ tyranny, but also against that which they might find within themselves.

Many Rivers Crossed explores themes including the crimes of colonialism and the mistakes of decolonisation, war's madness and addictions and depravities, the effects of individuals' decisions and temperaments on history's trajectories, and the ethics of truth and reconciliation. It condemns without demonising, and humanizes without sympathising, the obsessions of a warlord, in order to find a semblance of meaning in humankind’s propensity for power-thirst and pride. It will engage audiences to reflect on war: its nature; its causes; our tendencies towards it. Is Jonas Savimbi a character unique in his megalomania? Was he simply a product of sociopolitical forces, including colonialism, imperialism and the Cold War? Was he an aberration? Or was he an inevitability, even a universality?

About the Production

Many Rivers Crossed aims to be a socially-engaged production. Attendees will become involved not only as viewers of the play itself, but also as attendees to post-show discussions with experts from fields outside of theatre and to a celebration of Angolan history and culture, commemorating not only those gone due to the civil conflict but also those still with us today. We will also be holding a raffle every evening in support of the HALO Trust (https://www.halotrust.org/where-we-work/africa/...), an NGO dedicated to de-mining in post-conflict countries (including Angola, the country with the most mines and unexploded ordnances in the world), so the audience themselves will have an impact on the future of Angola.

Furthermore, the Landor_Space is located around the centre of London's lusophone (Portuguese-speaking) communities, making it connected with those to whom the narrative is most relevant. Many Rivers Crossed will also go through research and development workshops for both exclusively Angolan and also general audiences to ensure that there is full sensitivity and awareness of the real-life experiences of those who struggled and suffered during the civil war.

About the Team

Richard Canal (writer, director and producer) is a theatre practitioner from Spain and the United States. He recently debuted as solo performer and writer of Cry, Blueberry at the Cockpit during the Camden Fringe; then in January 2018 for a sell-out, four-star-reviewed, in-kind run; at the Warren for the 2018 Brighton Fringe; and soon at the 2018 Gothenburg Fringe and the Brighton Open Air Theatre. Combining his equal passions for the humanities and the dramatic arts, Richard obtained his BA in Human Rights and an MSc in Violence, Conflict and Development, and focuses on theatre for reconciliation.

George Goodell (co-director and stage manager) is an award-winning playwright and director from the United States. He was awarded as best director in the 2018 New Short Play Festival for The Ring, which he also wrote. George has written and directed for both theatre and film in the US and the UK.

Emeson Nwolie (actor) is a British-Nigerian singer-songwriter, actor, producer, remixer and writer with extensive film experience in movies such as Jurassic World: Fallen Kingdom, Assassin's Creed, Doctor Strange, Jason Bourne, Avengers: Age of Ultron, Rogue One: A Star Wars Story and Guardians of the Galaxy. Emeson has been part of the Saturn's Children ensemble as singer-songwriter with the producer Karmasound, works collaboratively as singer-songwriter with producer K15 for the Profusion group and is also a singer-songwriter contributor to the Carla Duke music project which includes acclaimed Swedish singer-songwriter Roselie. Emeson has also appeared on numerous compilations such as Freeness, Tokyo Dawn's The Heart 3, BBE BamaLoveSoul and Jazz Cafe Volume 10, both solo and collaboratively. His credits may be found at https://www.imdb.com/name/nm5619937/.

Chris Hislop (press relations manager) is a British-German theatre creative, with extensive experience as a producer, writer and director, including with widespread fringe and Off West End in London (such as the King's Head Theatre and LOST Theatre) and work at the Brighton, Edinburgh and Camden Fringes. He has recently started working on live tabletop role-playing games as a creative producer and live games master. His work may be found at https://www.chrishislop.com/.

About the Costs

The Landor_Space has granted us their theatre facilities for free, with a 60/40 split in our favor, so this fortunately removes that expense. Our focus is on the costume, props, set, marketing materials and team. The costs are listed here in order; as donations come in, each will be ticked off one by one, from least to most expensive. In this way, we hope to be able to cover as much with this campaign as possible!

EXPECTED COSTS
Costume (beret, shirt, pants, and boots): £100
Props (replica revolver, walkie-talkie): £100
Set (benches, dirt, fake grass): £100
Marketing materials (posters, flyers, etc.): £150
Lighting and sound technician (to be considered): £600
Public relations manager (Chris Hislop): £800
Actor (Emeson Nwolie): £2,700
Contingency buffer: £200

TOTAL COSTS: £4,750

INDEPENDENT FUNDING: £1,250

FUNDS REQUIRED: £3,500

 

About the Risks

With Chris's notable expertise in the art of getting people into theatres, and our experience in getting full houses for all five nights of Cry, Blueberry through targeted social media and outreach, we have faith that Many Rivers Crossed will garner audiences. Nevertheless, there are risks that could portend otherwise, as with every fledgling theatre work (especially in a city as theatre-packed as London).

We will be doing the following:

1.) Hiring Chris Hislop, a great freelance PR professional who has worked on many fringe and professional productions, to handle the press release, interviews, promotions and a press night;
2.) Using a customised Facebook page and promoting on a schedule, using personal invites in particular;
3.) Sending out personalised invites to industry professionals, including literary agents;
4.) Reaching out to relevant organisations, including the Angolan Embassy and especially ones that focus on the African diaspora.

Additionally, we believe the most relevant audience groups are Angolans and other lusophone communities in London; people from the sub-Saharan and central African diasporas; theatre-goers interested in solo show, socio-political works and/or historical pieces; and people of British and other nationalities, even if not generally theatre-goers, interested in the Global South.

Other Ways You Can Help

As we understand that not all have the resources to help Many Rivers Crossed by monetary donations, we invite you to help the production flourish in the following ways:

1.) Share this Indiegogo link, like our Facebook page (https://www.facebook.com/manyriverscrossed/?ref...), press "Interested" on the Facebook event (https://www.facebook.com/events/208350963282199/), and join our mailing list by contacting us at manyriverscrossed@gmail.com.
2.) Help us with costumes, props, and set construction.  If interested, contact us at manyriverscrossed@gmail.com
3.) Come see Many Rivers Crossed at the Landor_Space (70 Landor Road, London, SW9 9PH) during its run from September 5th to 11th, 2018! Tickets may be found at https://www.landorspace.com/many-rivers-crossed.

We thank you for your consideration!

story:
Once upon a time there was a girl.

Once upon a time there was a girl who had a dog.

Once upon a time there was Scruff the dog, who belonged to a girl called Carolina.

Tutu Trouble is an exciting new physical theatre performance for children (and grown-ups not ready to grow up yet), based on an original story by Vinicius Salles (www.viniciussalles.co), and written to celebrate acceptance of all gender identities. Performed by multi-talented dancers, the show will bring to life the story of two friends who find an old magical tutu, which sets them off on a fantastical journey of discovery and friendship.

Showcasing Vinicius’ original choreographic style, Tutu Trouble will explore physical theatre ideas through fun, quirky characterisation, innovative technologies, text and dance to demystify stereotypes of gender, and to empower and to celebrate boys’ and girls’ identities. Education on gender equality is becoming a big topic politically, picking up on the 2017 Stonewall schools report, which said that sex education is extremely limited when providing LGBTQ+-related information, while rates of poor mental health are alarmingly high among young LGBTQ+ people. It is also a subject close to Vinicius’ heart. Tackling homophobic, biphobic and transphobic bullying should form part of the school curriculum and be an aim for society as a whole, with a diverse range of identities and experiences represented across all forms of media.

 

Our goal is to raise £4,500 to help us create this exciting new piece of work. Our first aim is to create an illustrated book to accompany the piece, which could be used in classrooms as well as being read at home. Any money we raise beyond the book expenses would go towards paying for professional dancers, a creative team, set, costume and rehearsals. Whatever we can raise towards this goal would be amazing, and we’d love you to help us any way you can. We’re offering some fantastic perks, from a first edition of the gorgeous new book, to a special performance, to an exclusive T-shirt).

If you’re not able to contribute financially to our campaign, we’d love it if you could share it far and wide, via the Indiegogo share tools, to help us reach our target. And please keep up with everything we’re up to via our website (www.errant.org.uk) and our Facebook page.

 

WHO
Tutu Trouble is produced by Errant and choreographed by Vinicius Salles.

Errant was set up in 2017 by creative director Vinicius Salles and associate director Charlotte Price to produce innovative and exciting work that challenges the status quo and showcases Vinicius’ creativity and choreography. Their mission statement is to produce exciting immersive tourable physical theatre that provides meaningful experiences to audiences within unexpected settings. Work so far has included OX (funded by Arts Council England and Croydon Council) and Glitch.

DIRECTOR/CHOREOGRAPHER

Vinicius Salles’ experience includes performing, choreographing and teaching. He graduated from the Brazilian Performing Arts school Martins Pena, and holds a Masters Degree in Documentary Film from University of the Arts London.

Vinicius has performed with leading Brazilian and UK physical theatre and dance companies including Punchdrunk, Gecko and Jasmin Vardimon Company. He currently works as Visiting Lecturer at Royal Holloway University, Surrey, and Christ Church University, Kent, and is an Educational Facilitator for both Jasmin Vardimon Company and Punchdrunk, while also developing his own work.

 

Once upon a time, there was a girl called Carolina and a
dog called Scruff. And they have never stopped dancing.

 

Please help us share this campaign on social media!
story_txt:
Once upon a time there was a girl.Once upon a time there was a girl who had a dog.Once upon a time there was Scruff the dog, who belonged to a girl called Carolina.Tutu Trouble is an exciting new physical theatre performance for children (and grown-ups not ready to grow up yet), based on an original story by Vinicius Salles (www.viniciussalles.co), and written to celebrate acceptance of all gender identities. Performed by multi-talented dancers, the show will bring to life the story of two friends who find an old magical tutu, which sets them off on a fantastical journey of discovery and friendship.Showcasing Vinicius’ original choreographic style, Tutu Trouble will explore physical theatre ideas through fun, quirky characterisation, innovative technologies, text and dance to demystify stereotypes of gender, and to empower and to celebrate boys’ and girls’ identities. Education on gender equality is becoming a big topic politically, picking up on the 2017 Stonewall schools report, which said that sex education is extremely limited when providing LGBTQ+-related information, while rates of poor mental health are alarmingly high among young LGBTQ+ people. It is also a subject close to Vinicius’ heart. Tackling homophobic, biphobic and transphobic bullying should form part of the school curriculum and be an aim for society as a whole, with a diverse range of identities and experiences represented across all forms of media. Our goal is to raise £4,500 to help us create this exciting new piece of work. Our first aim is to create an illustrated book to accompany the piece, which could be used in classrooms as well as being read at home. Any money we raise beyond the book expenses would go towards paying for professional dancers, a creative team, set, costume and rehearsals. Whatever we can raise towards this goal would be amazing, and we’d love you to help us any way you can. We’re offering some fantastic perks, from a first edition of the gorgeous new book, to a special performance, to an exclusive T-shirt).If you’re not able to contribute financially to our campaign, we’d love it if you could share it far and wide, via the Indiegogo share tools, to help us reach our target. And please keep up with everything we’re up to via our website (www.errant.org.uk) and our Facebook page. WHOTutu Trouble is produced by Errant and choreographed by Vinicius Salles.Errant was set up in 2017 by creative director Vinicius Salles and associate director Charlotte Price to produce innovative and exciting work that challenges the status quo and showcases Vinicius’ creativity and choreography. Their mission statement is to produce exciting immersive tourable physical theatre that provides meaningful experiences to audiences within unexpected settings. Work so far has included OX (funded by Arts Council England and Croydon Council) and Glitch.DIRECTOR/CHOREOGRAPHERVinicius Salles’ experience includes performing, choreographing and teaching. He graduated from the Brazilian Performing Arts school Martins Pena, and holds a Masters Degree in Documentary Film from University of the Arts London.Vinicius has performed with leading Brazilian and UK physical theatre and dance companies including Punchdrunk, Gecko and Jasmin Vardimon Company. He currently works as Visiting Lecturer at Royal Holloway University, Surrey, and Christ Church University, Kent, and is an Educational Facilitator for both Jasmin Vardimon Company and Punchdrunk, while also developing his own work. 
Once upon a time, there was a girl called Carolina and adog called Scruff. And they have never stopped dancing.
 
Please help us share this campaign on social media!

story:
Short Summary

Bare: A Pop Opera is an incredibly relevant story in Alberta's cultural and political climate, with impactful themes such as peer and family rejection, acceptance, and what it means to be yourself. This show is not only a powerful story that everyone can enjoy, but it is also an incredible platform for local emerging artists to tell relevant stories and practice their craft. In light of the relevance of this piece, we are looking to invite various Gay-Straight Alliances (GSAs) to further empower community building within the arts, queer, Calgary community as a whole through the medium of musical theatre.

What We Need & What You Get

We are asking $1000 to help cover the cost of our production. Your donation will not only help us cover the cost of our technical equipment, but your donation will help us PAY OUR ARTISTS! Support Calgary's local emerging artists; no amount is too small and every donation counts.

story:
Hello Everyone!

Bonjour tout le monde! (on va suivre en français!)

For those who don’t know us, we are a dance company based out of Montreal Canada.  Tentacle tribe was founded by Emmanuelle Lê Phan & Elon Höglund in 2012 and has since then performed in more than 50 international cities.

 
We create dance works based out of Hip hop concepts with a contemporary twist.
Our new creation entitled “Ghost” will premiere at Place-des-arts, Danse Danse, November 13-17th.  “Ghost" is featuring 6 dancers, some of the best street dancers in Montreal, and our research for this work is rooted in breathing techniques and the awareness of the present moment. Check out the teaser:
 
We are launching our very first annual fundraising campaign, looking for investors that want to support our company. Your support will help with upcoming productions as well as rehearsals and touring of our repertory pieces. Our goal is to raise 5000$ by November 13th and we want to assure you that ANY amount is welcomes and will have an impact on the evolution of our company.

 
Ghost will tour in the next few years and will represent Canadian dance to its fullest, so if you can donate a little something to Tentacle Tribe, you will have helped our art travel across oceans! But also, you will get some pretty rad goodies!
 


We got brand new gear, coming back with the rainbow octopus edition,  white on white, and navy on burgundy. Check them out and help out our Tribe of Tentacles!


EN FRANÇAIS!!!

Pour ceux qui nous connaissent pas, nous sommes une compagnie de danse basée à Montreal. Tentacle Tribe a été fondé par Emmanuelle Lê Phan et Elon Höglund en 2012 et depuis nous avons présenté notre travail dans plus de 50 villes internationales.

 
Nous créons des pièces qui se basent des concepts Hiphop mais avec un twist contemporain.  Notre nouvelle creation est intitulée “Ghost” et va avoir sa première à la Place-des-arts de Montréal avec la saison Danse Danse. Les représentations seront du 13-17 novembre 2018.

“Ghost” met en vedette 6 incroyable danseurs, 6 des meilleurs danseurs de rue de Montreal, et la recherche pour cette pièce est ancrée dans les techniques de respiration ainsi que la conscience du moment présent.
 

Ceci est donc le lancement de notre toute première campagne de levée de fonds. Nous cherhons des personnes qui aimerais investir dans notre compagnie. Votre soutien va nous aider avec nos prochaines productions, aisni que pour nos répétitions et la dissémination de nos oeuvres répertoires en tournée.

Notre but est de lever 5000$ de fonds avant le 13 novembre et nous voulons vous assurer que n'importe quel contribution est la bienvenue et va sans doute avoir un impact sur l’évolution de notre compagnie.
 


"Ghost" et "Threesixnine" vont partir en tournée dans les prochaines années et vont représenter la danse montréalaise à 100%, donc si vous faite un don, vous allez aider notre art à traverser l’océan!  Mais aussi vous allez recevoir des récompenses!

On a de la nouvelle marchandise, on revient avec la pieuvre arc-en-ciel, hoodie et tee, ainsi que blanc sur blanc et bleu marin sur marron. N'hésitez pas, faite un don et aider notre petite tribu des tentacules!

story:
Short Summary

New Industry Dance, formerly Fischer Dance, is currently the only adult modern dance company in South Bend, IN. As a company, we facilitate a safe space for all movers to engage in introspection, discovery, and personal expression. In the past, Fischer Dance has been known for raising the bar of artistic production and dance-making in the area. New Industry Dance will continue to bring high-quality performances, outreach, and open classes to the community. We believe movement is a means to examine ourselves, each other, and the culture around us. Through embodiment practices, we bring intention and personal experience to the forefront of work that is socially aware and emotionally engaging.

As we prepare for our fifth season of dance in South Bend, we need your support. Your contribution will allow us to continue to collaborate and dialogue with voices in our community to create work born of diverse perspectives, art that inspires deeper thought, invites questions, and highlights human experiences rather than performance that tells you what to think and answers all the questions.

What We Need & What You Get

New Industry Dance needs your to help to raise $7500. All funds raised will go toward production costs for the 2018-2019 season and allow us to strengthen our commitment to quality dance work in the community.

 

Your contribution will assist in covering artistic and production costs, including:

Dancer stipends

Venue fees

Costuming fees (design, construction, materials)

Collaborating artist compensation

Marketing (print/web, graphic design, printing costs)

Photography and videography

New Industry Dance is a team of 8 artists: Chloe Ilene (Artistic Director), Anna Greenawalt, Joanna Whitmyer, Maia Sutter, Sharon Sims, Mallory McAfee (dancers), Patrick Quigley (Company Composer), and Johan Godwaldt (Lighting Designer).

Our season contains public performances in the fall and spring.

Depending on your contribution level, you will receive supporter merchandise (sticker or T-Shirt), an invite to visit a rehearsal, mutual benefit support through program mentions or brand visibility on our website. At the highest level, you will enjoy a full-length preview of a work and enjoy a Happy Hour with the artistic director and company dancers.

The Impact

New Industry Dance brings a unique artistic voice to South Bend’s young and rapidly growing arts community. We strive to elevate dance as an important and valued language of creative expression here.

In the past, as Fischer Dance, we brought more than 40 public performances to South Bend. Our work often includes a broad range of voices from the community. A primary way we do this is by inviting everyone to share personal perspectives and engage in movement experiences at our free movement classes. These classes help us build community and deepen our creative research process.

Going forward, New Industry Dance would like to create even more opportunities for engagement and education. Potential opportunities include pioneering a summer intensive program for adults and hosting more movement workshops and mini-series. We also hope to deepen our community impact by developing stronger partnerships with organizations in South Bend who share similar visions.

Risks & Challenges

Historically, Fischer Dance has produced all of its work with the support of fewer than 10 donors. Up until now, our founding artistic director financed much of our production costs. Going forward, we must increase our donor pool. We hope you will be among the needed 50-100 financial backers. Combined, your donations show a community commitment to prioritizing dance as an important language of creative expression.

We want to sustain and build on our modern dance endeavors, but our greatest challenge is to build an audience for modern dance in South Bend. Two standard ways we have confronted this challenge is by prioritizing education on the language of dance and increasing transparency in our creative process. Our Movement Lab is a safe space where you can engage in movement exercises and converse about your own movement experience. And after each performance, we engage in talk-backs where we encourage you to ask questions and engage in dialogue surrounding our work.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot help fund this campaign right now, you can always contribute by sharing our fundraiser with others who may want to help. The Indiegogo share tools make it easy to spread the word!

In the meantime, stay tuned by following us on social media or subscribing to our email list. We hope to see you at a dance event soon!

story:
Bring Back Black Men in Theatre

Black Men in Theatre is a showcase of talented  play creators and performing artists in Toronto (G.T.A.). Created by the PIECE OF MINE  Festival and first presented at 918 Bathurst Cultural Centre in February 2015.  With all of the incredible feedback we received, it was clear that this event needed to be brought back.

Like Hollywood, there are even fewer diverse story-lines/roles in theatre created for artists of colour -  especially opportunities beyond stereotypical plots/characterizations.  That is why PIECE OF MINE prides itself on highlighting black Canadian voices. We are doing our part to fill the gap and platform more black men on stage.

This year we are excited to present Black Men in Theatre as part of Black Fractals at Ontario College of Art & Design (OCAD). We have curated an incredible showcase that runs Friday, February 19 and Saturday, February 20  - and we need you help!

Featured 2016 Line-Up:

Troy Crossfield, Jordan Laffrenier, Dennis Langley, Luke Reece, Tarick Glancy directed by Richard Stewart, Musical Performance, & More.

Here's What People Had To Say

Online Review

"Black Men in Theatre is a glance into the colourful soul of the black male experience." -  Casey Bradfield, Toronto Relationships writer

http://pieceofminefest.com/3/post/2015/02/black-men-in-theatre-a-review.html

Media

G-Team On Location


Facebook Post

"It was quite refreshing to see that it was a full house tonight and that the brothers welcomed us into their reality via the stage, very inspiring."

- Amina Alfred, audience member and artists 


Other Ways You Can Help

Supporting our campaign goes beyond donating. We have a relatively modest amount to raise and word of mouth is the most valuable form of promotion for any crowdfunding campaign. By just taking a minute to share our links on social media, email...texting a friend - we can make this happen within 30 days :)

How to spread the word:

  • Indiegogo link:
  • Twitter: @Pieceofminefest 
  • Instagram: Pieceofminefest

And that's all there is to it.

Thank YOU!

story:
Johnny Shot and the Case of Missing Tibbles by DoctorDoctor wants to come back after it's sell out run at The New London Theatre in 2014 to the Canal Cafe Theatre this February.  But this time we need your help!  We want Johnny Shot to return to this legendary comedy venue and hopefully take over the world!!! 


Three nights at The Canal Cafe is an amazing platform for new comic writing and would enable us to showcase the talent of the members of our company and this brilliant show. We had an overwhelmingly positive response from the audience when we showed it last year at its sell out run at The New London Theatre.  Unfortunately it is far more challenging for small companies like ours to find sponsors and therefore we are reaching out to you.  This run would enable us to market the show to the industry hopefully leading to a London transfer, be produced for radio and perhaps even secure an Edinburgh festival slot next year!  But more importantly to bring excellent comedy and entertainment to the London stage.  And if you don't believe us check out our behind the scenes video!  


Having said that you probably want to know a little more about us and the show….


Johnny Shot is a two-bit PI in a two-bit town. Constantly hired to find missing cats Johnny is in a rut. That is until Samantha Tibbles, a rich heiress and winner of 'most attractive married woman' three years in a row, walks into his office. Cute as hell with an attitude to match, Samantha hires Johnny to find her husband, Felix Tibbles. But as Johnny investigates the disappearance of Felix he uncovers more of his own past. A past he tried to run away from but which is quickly tap dancing towards him.

Think Raymond Chandler! Think AirPlane! Think Gene Kelly's Singing in the Rain!


‘ It was another boring case, another missing cat.

Another high strung spinster with another bee in her

bonnet yelling in my ear too early in the morning.

Where do all these cats keep going, I thought to

myself. Then I realised, I didn’t care I just needed

the money. I had my last swig of whisky to wash away

the night terrors and started walking the sprawling

streets of Scranton-upon-Sea. I went to my first port of

call, Worthington Cattery. It was an abandoned fish

shop, over-run by AWOL cats and one old woman called

Mavis. She was crazy as hell, with a temper to match.

Today she wasn’t giving anything away, apart from the

contents of last night’s bed pan. Looked like all my

usual leads had dried up. The case was going slower

than a slug walking away from the love of his life.…’

  - Johnny Shot



Nick Bulleid and John Robert Davis formed the comedy sketch group DoctorDoctor after working together for many years.They decided to try something new and sexy so created a full length comedy in the form of Johnny Shot and the case of Missing Tibbles. Johnny Shot brings the true meaning of spoof and parody to unsuspecting comedy audiences but also a new found respect for cats.    After an overwhelming positive response they have joined forces with Georgie Morrell , Artistic Director of Poke in the Eye Productions, who will not only be in it again  but this time she's co-producing with them.  Poke in the Productions have just completed there debut show at the Canal Cafe, A Poke in the Eye, to excellent reviews and is now being produced into a radio sitcom and in the process of a London and Edinburgh transfer. 


Every donation will help bring this incredible comedy spoof back to the London stage and hopefully to bigger and better things.  It will be a great conturbtuion to the comedy circuit and bring laughter, fun and farce to unsuspecting audiences.    The cast is made up of 5 brilliant comedy actors.  You would not only be supporting the show but also give unknown comedic actors a platform to be brilliant, hilarious and sexy.  DoctorDoctor and Poke in the Eye Productions are committed to help boost the careers of young actors starting out in comedy.  

The money you will be donating will go to cover the basic costs of putting on a show but also we hope to provide a fee for our cast too.  The cost are for things like rehearsal space so the actors can work freely an in safe envriomant.  Publicity and  marketing so that people know about the show.

Don't Have Any Money But Love Us/This Idea?

NEVER FEAR!

If you still love the sound of us and 'Johnny Shot' and think its sounds funny and sexy as hell  , please SHARE this campaign on your Facebook!  Or if your not on Facebook when tweets us and share the gift that is Johnny Shot…..


Every single donation, no matter how small, is going to get us closer to our goal.

Thank you so much for your time and for your support!


Tickets-http://www.canalcafetheatre.com/EventPage.php?E...

spoof and parody to unsuspecting comedy audiences but also a new found respect for cats.    After an overwhelming positive response they have joined forces with Georgie Morrell , Artistic Director of Poke in the Eye Productions, who will not only be in it again  but this time she's co-producing with them.  Poke in the Productions have just completed there debut show at the Canal Cafe, A Poke in the Eye, to excellent reviews and is now being produced into a radio sitcom and in the process of a London and Edinburgh transfer. Every donation will help bring this incredible comedy spoof back to the London stage and hopefully to bigger and better things.  It will be a great conturbtuion to the comedy circuit and bring laughter, fun and farce to unsuspecting audiences.    The cast is made up of 5 brilliant comedy actors.  You would not only be supporting the show but also give unknown comedic actors a platform to be brilliant, hilarious and sexy.  DoctorDoctor and Poke in the Eye Productions are committed to help boost the careers of young actors starting out in comedy.  The money you will be donating will go to cover the basic costs of putting on a show but also we hope to provide a fee for our cast too.  The cost are for things like rehearsal space so the actors can work freely an in safe envriomant.  Publicity and  marketing so that people know about the show.
Don't Have Any
Money But Love Us/This Idea?
NEVER FEAR!
If you still love the sound of us and 'Johnny Shot' and think its sounds funny and sexy as hell  , please SHARE this campaign on your Facebook!  Or if your not on Facebook when tweets us and share the gift that is Johnny Shot…..Every single donation, no matter how small, is going to get us closer to our goal.
Thank you so much for your time and for your support!Tickets-http://www.canalcafetheatre.com/EventPage.php?E...

story:
Summary

Hi There!  Thank You for taking the time to read about our first event for 2020 with an eye on donating to our project!  I'm Julie Heffner, freelance ballet dancer, choreographer and director.  I am working in Bellevue, Washington with CITY OPERA BALLET, a non-profit organization, to bring an amazing, hard-working and talented group of classically trained ballet dancers to Timber Ridge Senior Living this Valentin's Day.  We are excited about your  support for our budget to bring the rare experience of professional ballet to this arts-loving senior audience while assuring the viability of dance careers in our community!

What We Need & What You Get

All funds go directly to paying six dancers for their work.  Our goal is to raise $1,000 to cover a $200 Director/Choreography fee and $200 for each dancer.  An exciting start of $400 already serves as a generous welcome mat for your participation in our campaign. For the opportunity of a tax deduction, please refer to our website for your donation www.cityoperaballet.org

We offer many levels of fun gifts to thank you for your contribution, including:  Thank You letters from the dancers,  donor mentions in all CITY OPERA BALLET 2020 Season programs, hand-made personalized wood burned Valentines and even help a low income student reivcie a free private lesson!

Should we fail to reach our goal, any funds raised will be used to pay the dancers.

 

The Impact

  Even a small compensation goes a long way in a dancer's life.  We spend hours staying in shape, rehearsing and choreographing to bring our A  game to the sage.  Mastering our art since childhood has lead us to reach now for your hand.  Help us to hold onto our life's mission:  to dance!

Risks & Challenges

  For the past 55 years through unimaginable changes in our City,  our company has "grown like Topsy"  with our firm conviction to Never Give Up!

Other Ways You Can Help

  If you cannot contribute financially, you still have a big role to play!  Help us get the word out by making some noise about our Indiegogo campaign on your social media!  Volunteer your time!  There is a place for everyone at the ballet!

story:
To Make A Simple Donation, Click "BACK IT" Above ^

 

*As a 501(c)(3) Non-profit Arts Organization, All mailed cash contributions are Tax- Deductible.

 

The Philadelphia Dance Company

Founded in 1970, Philadanco! has shaped a legacy of breaking barriers and building bridges across cultural divides. The company has performed a wide range of dance works for an audience who represents, like the dancers, an amalgamation of diverse communities.

 

 

Our goal is to empower youth with crucial leadership and development skills to facilitate achievement and success in the world of dance and everyday life. Philadanco! is widely recognized for its artistic integrity, superbly trained dancers, and electrifying performances.

 

 

With over 4500 alumni members in its 47 year history, Philadanco! has impacted the lives of ordinary people who have ascended into other professional careers such as Philadelphia Councilwoman Blondell Reynolds-Brown, to the likes of film director Lee Daniels (Monster's Ball, The Butler) as well as Hamilton’s award winning Leslie Odom, Jr.

 

Alexander J. Dubé Matching Gift

“Audiences throughout the world have appreciated the artistic excellence of Philadanco! and its preservation of predominantly African-American traditions in dance. One of its biggest fans was the late Alexander J. Dubé, whose passion for the dance community has extended far past his 2014 death. The pioneering New York-based dance advocate and former Career Transition For Dancers president made a $500,000 bequest to Philadanco! — an amount the acclaimed company will receive if it raises a $1 million match by June 29th.” - The Philadelphia Tribune

 

 

 

Philadanco!’s Founder and Executive Artistic Director Joan Myers Brown is widely acknowledged to be one of the “Living Legends” of dance in the USA.  Her undisputed status as a leader in the National and International arts communities was acknowledged when she received the 2012 National Medal of the Arts, the nation’s highest civic honor for excellence in the arts, in addition to the Dance Heritage Coalition’s recognition for being one of America’s Irreplaceable Dance Treasures.

For this reason, a plan for The Joan Myers Brown International Center for African American Dance is being produced to secure and solidify her legacy long after Philadanco!'s 50th Anniversary celebration in 2020.

 

For the Philadelphia Dance Company to secure $1 Million in today’s hard-strapped economy is a challenge indeed,

but not impossible.

 

It costs an estimate of 1.5 Million dollars for Philadanco! to continue providing cost effective classes and performances throughout the year.

Donations to the Alexander Dubé Fund through Indiegogo will go towards the grand total of funds raised throughout the match challenge. The current total fundraised is estimated to be $75,000 and we hope to reach the $100,000 mark soon. 

 

We really appreciate that the Indiegogo platform allows for Philadanco! to return the gift of giving back to our donors. With these perks designed for donors of every level, we are happy to share our thanks for each gift, no matter the size.

 

Philadanco! appreciates all of the love and support we receive from all of our family and friends. By simply reading, and sharing this challenge anyone can help support us and our cause.

Thank you

 

To Make Additional Donations Outside of Indiegogo Visit:
https://npo.justgive.org/nonprofits/donate.jsp?ein=23-7161084

story:
Who we are

The new home for your swing dance and live jazz needs in St Louis:

  • A steady home for dances and classes, brought to you for dancers by dancers
  • Hardwood floors, relaxing atmosphere, drinks and socializing
  • We focus on quality instruction and swing music. Period. 
  • Renowned instructors, djs and musicians. We are coming together to fill the needs of the community, we have an open door policy when it comes to feedback and ideas

 

What We Need 

In order to make the venue what we want and need it to be, there are a few things we need to add to the space (right now it is a beautiful empty room with wood floors):

  • We need to build a small stage for our live music and dj needs
  • In order to play music so everyone can hear it, we need a sound system (not our travel bluetooth speakers)
  • In order to serve beverages and snacks, we need a bar to separate the dance space from the serving space
  • We need coolers and shelves to store alcoholic and non alcoholic beverages
  • Permits, Holy cow so many permits. Business, occupancy, health, liquor. Each of these takes time AND money
  • So that it doesn't feel like a retail store, we need to replace some overhead lights. We want atmosphere and these current babies do not give it.
  • We need some chairs for people to sit in and some tables for people to put their drinks on

What You Get

We have a lot of different perks for helping us get the venue put together for parties and classes. Here are some of the ways we are saying thank you for donating:

  • Lifetime access to classes and dances
  • Class pass for 1 year - access to all SCS classes
  • Dance pass for 1 year - access to all SCS dances
  • Gift card 
  • Entrance to a Saturday Stomp Workshop and Dance
  • Private Lessons
  • Moonshine Rythym Club album digital download

Any extra money earned will go to covering the costs of our musicians, teachers and djs

The Impact

By contributing to this campaign you are not only helping us get the physical venue in order, but you are helping us to pay our instructors, our djs and our musicians. Our goal for weekly live music is easily within reach. We value our team greatly and want to make sure they are taken care of. We want to reach people in the city with quality swing music and excitement about jazz and jazz dancing:

  • Our team wants to connect more people to swing and jazz
  • We want to provide folks with safe, enjoyable social activities
  • We have long term goals of working with different groups in our city, both dance and non-related, and this venue helps make that happen.
  • We can provide a low cost option for other dance classes, rehearsals and other art groups

Risks & Challenges

We of course also have the hard challenge of getting people in the door. We have flyers to make, locations to canvass, websites to build and more. We have staff to pay, and not to mention cost of goods to cover. But, we believe that with hard work and energy we can get it done.

  • If we don't hit our goal, it doesn't mean this won't happen! There is enough money in personal savings to cover these costs, but it does mean we may live off top ramen for a long time, and well, top ramen doesn't have a lot of health benefits.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Spread the word and tell your friends about our campaign.
  • Donate your time - cleaning, managing the door etc are all great ways to help
  • Rent the space for rehearsals
  • Come to our dances, classes and workshops
  • Equipment/furniture donations - make our space pretty

story:
Hey, didn't you already have a campaign?

Why yes, we did! We launched a successful campaign on Indiegogo which paid for our flights to America. We are now launching this new campaign which will go towards our food while we are abroad. If you've already donated to the previous campaign, then we THANK YOU SO MUCH! If you were planning on donating, but waited to pull the trigger, then this is your chance! All of the rewards from the previous campaign are still available and any extra money would be a huge help in making sure the cast and crew are fed and watered on their journey to bring Cimrman to America!

Short Summary

We are the Cimrman English Theatre - a group of English speaking actors living in the Czech Republic dedicated to performing the works of Jára Cimrman. Anyone who has lived here will have crossed the name of Jára Cimrman. He is a fictitious character of a Czech genius, who lived at the turn of the 20th century and who is dear to every Czech heart. Ask the nearest Czech!

Czechs are so proud of him that in 2005 he won a nationwide poll for the greatest Czech. Every Czech we talked to - including the character's creators - insisted his comedy was untranslatable. But we proved them wrong! In 2014 we performed a staged reading of The Stand-In (Záskok). It was a huge success, covered by the media, and our audience was as excited as Zdeněk Svěrák, the last surviving creator of Cimrman. 

Z. Svěrák - Czech national treasure.

We have been playing ever since. We love it and are extremely proud to be spreading the good word about the Czech Republic, which has become our second home. Our audience is mixed Czech and foreign. In a lot of cases Czechs bring along their foreign partners and friends. It's a unique chance to share this comedy, which is so dear, with those they love.

Somewhere along the line we thought, wouldn't it be great to bring Cimrman to America? There are so many Czechs, who have English-speaking partners and families, Czechs, who do not speak Czech any more or simply admirers of Czech culture! Watching Cimrman in English is the perfect way to share this iconic piece of Czech culture with them!

That is how the project began and now we are almost there! With the great support of the Czech Ministry of Foreign Affairs, we hope to perform Jára Cimrman's Stand-in (Záskok) - a witty play about a theater troupe that hires a stand-in at the last minute and hilarity ensues.

Tour dates (2017), all tickets are FREE:

April 19 & 22, 7PM at the Bohemian Hall, the Czech Center in New York, (between 1st and 2nd Avenue) 321 E 73rd Street, New York, NY 10021

April 21, 8PM at the Hostelling International NYC, 891 Amsterdam Avenue, NY

Tickets for New York shows

April 26 & 27 6:30pm at the Abramson Family Auditorium, New York University, 1307 L Street, NW. Washington, DC 20005, USA

Tickets for DC on the 26th Tickets for DC on the 27th

April 28 7pm, Cathedral of Mary Our Queen, 5200 North Charles Street, Baltimore, MD 21210

Tickets for Baltimore show

Watch the Stand-In trailer!

 

 

The Czech diplomatic missions to the USA have been incredibly helpful, they will provide theater space, accommodation for our team and even lend us a bus. We have been incredibly humbled by the overwhelming support we got from our fans who contributed to our airline tickets. Here is a link to our first Indiegogo campaign. Nevertheless, we continue to raise money to cover our meals. If you did not contribute the first time, now is your chance!

 

With your contribution the world will finally be able to learn the truth about this forgotten genius: the man who advised Chekhov that a play about just two sisters wasn't dramatic enough and who invented TNT only to arrive to the patent office two minutes after Alfred Nobel had patented his own version of dynamite. 

J. Cimrman's bust - no one knows what he looked like. 

What We Need & What You Get

The bulk of the money we need to raise will fund our meals while in the US. There will be 8 of us (6 cast members + 2 support staff) and the total sum for the provisions is 3000 USD. As mentioned our accommodation, theater venues and a bus with a driver will be provided by the Czech diplomatic missions. We are also in the process of getting corporate sponsors, whose contribution will help cover transportation and manufacturing of the set. We do not expect to be paid!

For your contribution, we are prepared to welcome you in the fold of science - you may become a cimrmanologist and even an honorary member of the Cimrman English Theatre!

Cimrman's Stand-In is also a love story! Vogeltanz (M. Pitthan) and Vlasta (C. Matthew)

The Impact

During our tour we are hoping to reach approximately 800 viewers during our 5 shows. In addition to that David Smoljak, son of Ladislav Smoljak (one of the co-authors Jára Cimrman's plays) is preparing a documentary about our tour, which will be financed separately. We will be accompanied by him and also by reporters from the Czech Radio. Last but not least, we will be keeping in touch with you in our video journal documenting our trip!

Risks & Challenges

The biggest risk is that we will not be able to raise enough money for our meals. We have thought long and hard about a crowd funding strategy: should we be raising money on a Czech site since Jára Cimrman is a Czech hero? In the end we concluded that all of our audience members speak English after all and we opted for Indiegogo.

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you cannot contribute, please, let your friends and family know about the shows! If they have never heard about Jára Cimrman, explain it to them. As we like to say - Ask the nearest Czech!

Do not forget to share our fantastic videos! And like us on Facebook. 

What Does Our Audience Say? 

"Yesterday was my 3rd time with you guys, and I laughed all over again right from the start. You are making your performance better and better..." (Facebook)

"Great fun, excellent translation and hilarious actors. Great opportunity to finally show this jewel of Czech literature to my friends!" (Facebook)

"Unbelievably good adaptation of Cimrman's plays. A must-see for everyone - especially foreigners who want to understand and enjoy Czech humor and mentality. Wish you good luck!" (Facebook)

What does our audience say?

Read more at our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/CimrmanEnglishStudio/

or our Tripadvisor page: https://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g... 

Our web site is www.cimrman-in-america.com

External Links

If you want to read about the Stand-In in English, read these: 

http://www.radio.cz/en/section/in-focus/english...

http://www.czech.cz/en/Culture/New-English-lang...

If you want to learn more about Jára Cimrman, read these: 

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J%C3%A1ra_Cimrman

http://www.expats.cz/prague/article/czech-cultu...

https://www.kissfromtheworld.com/magazine/blog-...

In the end we concluded that all of our audience members speak English after all and we opted for Indiegogo. Other Ways You Can HelpIf you cannot contribute, please, let your friends and family know about the shows! If they have never heard about Jára Cimrman, explain it to them. As we like to say - Ask the nearest Czech!Do not forget to share our fantastic videos! And like us on Facebook. What Does Our Audience Say? "Yesterday was my 3rd time with you guys, and I laughed all over again right from the start. You are making your performance better and better..." (Facebook)"Great fun, excellent translation and hilarious actors. Great opportunity to finally show this jewel of Czech literature to my friends!" (Facebook)"Unbelievably good adaptation of Cimrman's plays. A must-see for everyone - especially foreigners who want to understand and enjoy Czech humor and mentality. Wish you good luck!" (Facebook)What does our audience say?Read more at our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/CimrmanEnglishStudio/or our Tripadvisor page: https://www.tripadvisor.com/Attraction_Review-g... Our web site is www.cimrman-in-america.comExternal LinksIf you want to read about the Stand-In in English, read these: http://www.radio.cz/en/section/in-focus/english...http://www.czech.cz/en/Culture/New-English-lang...If you want to learn more about Jára Cimrman, read these: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/J%C3%A1ra_Cimrmanhttp://www.expats.cz/prague/article/czech-cultu...https://www.kissfromtheworld.com/magazine/blog-...

story:
Who we are:

Ellen Mandel (composer) has created music for over seventy plays and composed many songs to poems by e.e. cummings, Seamus Heaney, WB Yeats, Charlotte Mew, and others. Scenie Award Top Girls, NYIT and NH Theater Awards multiple noms. She’s released 5 song CDs. NY Times raves: Her songs are “ardent, spiky, and freshly organic.” Dizzy Gillespie called her a “Wonderful musician.” ellenmandel.com

Dee Nelson (librettist) appeared on Broadway in the most recent revival of The Heiress, and in the original productions of Stephen Karam's Sons of the Prophet, Craig Lucas's I Was Most Alive with You, and Ken Urban's The Awake. She has received a Lunt-Fontanne Fellowship for her regional work, as well as Boston's Elliot Norton Award for Outstanding Actress.

The Story:  

Music was very important in the lives of Thomas Hardy and Emma Gifford – They both sang, Tom played the fiddle, Emma played the piano...and music played a part in their falling in love. In a country-dance scene in our musical, they sing:

Love is, yes, a great thing,
A great thing to me,
When, having drawn across the lawn
In darkness silently,
A figure flits like one a-wing
Out from the nearest tree:
O love is, yes, a great thing,
A great thing to me!

We've been working on the musical over the past couple of years, but what we need more than anything now is to have a series of readings so that we can hear the piece out loud, performed by wonderful actor/singers and musicians. We have to make sure that every song moves the story forward and/or reveals character, that every scene is compelling, and that the songs and scenes work together to tell a story of Tom and Emma's blissful early days together, of Hardy's growing success, and of what happens later....

Can it be you that I hear? Let me view you, then,

Standing as when I drew near to the town

Where you would wait for me: yes, as I knew you then,

Even to the original air-blue gown!


What we need and what you get:

Our goal is $7500 for the following:

Funds to pay 6 actor/singers and 2 musicians (and to pay for studio space and other expenses) for a series of readings, to help us get the script and score ready for the next steps of development.

Funds for performer pay and studio time to make demo recordings, which will be needed when we submit the piece to development organizations and share it with potential producers and directors.

Funds for research expenses.

See the Perks boxes for our offer of music and a sneak preview of the show!

Whether or not you can contribute, we hope you might consider spreading the word about our Indiegogo campaign and about our project. Thank you so much!!

 

Last Love-Word (that's the title of another Hardy poem):

Working from the starting point of the Hardys' life together – and using Hardy's own words in the songs – we want to offer a vibrant musical picture of the joys and illusions of the Hardys' early love...of Thomas's realized ambitions and Emma's frustrated hopes...of the intersection of artistic sensitivity and personal callousness...of failure to communicate...and of the love that remains, or revives only when it's too late.

But Time, to make me grieve,

Part steals, lets part abide;

And shakes this fragile frame at eve

With throbbings of noontide.

story:
Who are we?

The New England Center for Circus Arts (NECCA) was founded with the mission to create a school, facility and community where circus arts are available to the general public and to inspire students of all skill levels, ages, abilities and aspirations.  My twin sister, Serenity, and I grew up in the woods of Massachusetts and discovered the circus in our late teens.  We fell in love with all of what circus can mean– team building, unique physicality, artistic expression, good, clean fun and hard, sweaty, rewarding work.   Even when we were on tour with companies like Cirque du Soleil, we realized our passion wasn’t just for creating incredible art with feats of strength and coordination, but for teamwork and collaboration and how circus can bring a community together.

After 10 years NECCA is ready to give our community a real circus home for training and performances.  Working with a dedicated team of coaches, Board members, committee members, architects, builders, and of course, generous donors, we just passed the halfway mark towards our $2.5 million goal to build our new home. The Trapezium building (phase 1) is almost ready for us – we can hardly believe it but we’ll be moving in June!

NECCA Board l to r: Eveline Martin, Junie Pereira, Elizabeth Warner, Kate Anderson and Bill Perry. Missing from photo: Tracy Prentiss, Suzanne Bosek, Linda Schiffer and Kate Law

Staff: l to r, f to b: Casey Haynes, Erin Lovett-Sherman, Melissa Knowles, Victoria Quine, Bethan Kannapell, Jessica Goulas, Bill Forchion, Michael Helmstadter, Jamie Hodgsen, Molly Graves, Annika Frodi-Lundgren, Jordan Polan-Clarke, Michael Manning, Serenity Smith Forchion, Elsie Smith, Alissa Andrews, Pam Kinsmith

Missing from photo: over 20 awesome folks!

Ready to juggle,

Building Committee l to r:  Gordon Bristol, Candace Pearson, Bill Perry, Serenity Smith Forchion, Elsie Smith, Kate Anderson, Gary Fox Missing from Photo: Steve Stone, Patrick Kitzmiller, Margaret Minsky

Juggling Hardhats

And countless other volunteers: Finance Committee, Innovation and Programming Committee, PR Committee, Development Committee, and Sub-committees - many hands gets the work done!

Why this crowdfunding campaign?

We have designed a very beautiful building.  We built space for an in-ground trampoline with a trampoline wall.  There is a big concrete hole awaiting foam blocks for our landing pit.  There are 40’ ceilings waiting for our flying trapeze. 

Please help us bring these spaces to life!

With $91,099 we can purchase this specialized circus equipment and everybody can enjoy our Earth-Mountain-Sky.

EARTH: 

Did you know that a well-designed foam pit, deep enough to keep students safe from a headfirst landing from an aerial apparatus costs $12,852? It is also a great tool for training cool flips, since there is a guaranteed soft landing!

MOUNTAIN: 

Help us climb the walls with a specially designed trampoline and trampoline wall that helps cross training for flying trapeze, tumbling drills and Spiderman Acrobatics, costs $6,994.

Theater curtains will help make our trapezium into a performance venue.  And these fire rated beauties come in at over $15,000.

SKY: 

Look up! Beam Clamps are a rigging device that will give us solid, yet easily movable rigging points anywhere we want them! We need 50, and at around $160 each that’s over $8,000.

We want students and coaches to be able to fly all year round, rain or snow, which is why we planned an indoor flying trapeze rig. We’re working closely with Scott Osgood from AcroSolution and Bobby Bates from Bobby’s Big Top to develop an indoor rig with a suspended net that will raise and lower in a jiffy, letting us offer flying classes any time you want.  The full package will cost $35,505.

Everything we do to move Earth-Mountain-Sky into the new Circus Arts Trapezium will cost $12,748, bringing us to the campaign goal of $91,099.

Risks and Challenges

Our move in day is coming along very quickly.  We need to have all our purchases made, and installed, before June 19.  This huge project will be possible with your support.  

From small donations to larger ones, every gift will enable us to move into our new, custom-designed circus building.  Please help us purchase the Earth-Mountain-Sky and fill Everybody’s Home for Circus.  

Other ways to help us?

Here are some more ways you can help us.

Ask people you know if they’ll match you in your support for this project, or if they would send the link to three of their friends?

Or, help us spread the word!  Tell your friends and family. Share this link on Facebook.

No matter how you help, we are so grateful for all your support. We can't wait to share the results of our crowdfunding campaign with you.

Elsie Smith (co-founder) on behalf of the NECCA team

story:
Who we are

angrybrowngirl productions is coming to the MTL Fringe with Love Painted Brown, a heartfelt piece that paints a picture of race, womanhood, activism, and love – in shades of brown. 

Love Painted Brown is about simultaneity. Grounded in the stories that colour an Indian/Mexican woman's upbringing in an African-American family, the work performs academia and analyzes story. Piece by piece, Shanti Gonzales invites the audience to join her in deconstructing previously held notions of race, gender, class and more. Part performance, part seminar, part RIOT – Love Painted Brown is about getting one's hand dirty in order to sift through what it means to claim brown womanhood in 2017.

We are looking to raise $1000 to put on this show. Your contributions will go toward...

  • The $500 entrance fee for performing at the Fringe. 
  • Paying some passionate emerging female-identified artists for their hard work. Artists like...
    • Sky Erickson for her dope graphic design.
    • Hannah Kirby and Claire Bourdin for their innovation and patience with all things technical.
    • Holly Hilts for the imagination and resourcefulness in her set design.
    • Yasmin Bitar for keeping everyone sane and organized day in and day out.
    • Cara Krisman and Myrna Wyatt-Selkirk for their creativity and wisdom as acting coaches.
    • Shanti Gonzales for digging up old journals and putting a voice to what it really looks, feels, and tastes like to be brown -- in her mission to confront a society's fear of the dark.

The Impact

This project centralizes the realities of brown womanhood in the age of Trump by sharing one woman's lived experience. It is meant to tell the stories that haven't yet been told, to demonstrate caring and practical ways to engage in intersectional feminism, and to call out to the audience and hear their response. The piece talks Black Barbies, cumin, whiskey, academia, social media, Trudeau's hair, and more. 

  • As hate crimes increase and racism rears its ugly head publicly once more, it's stories like these that need to take the stage and assert their presence. We do this not only for the brown adults, but for the brown youth. For us, brown can refer to any POC-identified human. Ours is a project that tackles issues of representation and identity formation, and how the expectations of society, our families, our peers, and our selves influence our very Formation (spoiler alert: we love Beyoncé). 
  • LPB has had two resoundingly successful presentations at McGill University, first as a Bachelor's thesis and then as a featured performance at McGill's Bodies in Difference conference in April. The Fringe stage is the next big step for us! angrybrowngirl productions is led by Shanti Gonzales, previously the director of CoffeeSpoons Theatre Project, a Boston-based theatre company unique for its simplicity and accessibility (all of our shows were in coffeehouses and bars!) and its ability to pay its young artists for their time and energy. Those salaries were paid entirely by Indiegogo contributions, for three years in a row! 
  • If you have any questions about Love Painted Brown, its content, its mission, or its team, let us know! You can send us an email at shanti.gonzales@gmail.com. 
  • Any amount helps. Anything from the cost of a black coffee (or unicorn Frappuccino) to a more sizable sum is deeply appreciated!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute monetarily but are feeling the love, here are some things you can do:

  • Share our campaign and our event page on Facebook and other social media. Expanding the reach of our call is invaluable. 
  • Send us a message (shanti.gonzales@gmail.com) of support and love! 
  • Come see us at the Fringe!

LOVE PAINTED BROWN

June 8-18, 2017

Venue 3, Montreal Improv Espace B. 

  • Thursday 8 June @ 21:30 
  • Friday 9 June @ 23:45 (Volunteer Show! A chance for the volunteers at the festival to see us for free!)
  • Sunday 11 June @ 16:15
  • Monday 12 June @ 21:30 
  • Wednesday 14 June @ 20:00
  • Saturday 17 June @ 15:00

  • Sunday 18 June @ 20:45

story:
The Play: Mary’s husband, Crick, buys a painting with the last of their savings. Mary and Crick have a baby, but they can’t decide on the baby’s name, or the baby’s gender. A story of one woman’s education and her search to find true love outside the box.

Why Late? Why now?: Late: A Cowboy Song embodies our goals as a company: challenging dualities and gender stereotypes, featuring women in roles as prominent and interesting as in real life, and showing complex and meaningful relationships between people of all genders. We feel that these kinds of plays are not produced often enough, in Philadelphia or really anywhere, and are excited to bring this thoughtful story to our community. Philadelphia theatregoers may already be familiar with the playwright, Sarah Ruhl. This celebrated writer has consistently featured a myriad of sincere, funny, interesting women from many different backgrounds in her body of work. Ruhl is one of the most important voices in American theatre right now, and we are delighted to be sharing her work with you for our first full production. 

Our Goal: Producing a play, especially one that is so relevant, requires a solid foundation from which to build. We are asking lovers of the arts, proponents of equality and cowboys at heart to donate any amount to help our young company realize this important piece. 

Plays are Expensive! We need your help to make this the best production it can possibly be. Making great theatre involves a lot of big expenses! Some you may already be able to guess (A suitable performance venue, paying artists for their hard work, set pieces, props, and lights). But many of these expenses are less visible to the average theatregoer: insurance costs, royalties to the publishing company and playwright, advertising, and all that coffee and water to keep us going in the rehearsal room!  By making a donation, big or small, to Late: A Cowboy Song, you are making all of this possible. Just $1 can buy a case of bottled water for the actors to stay hydrated backstage. $1000 can buy the royalties for every night we perform. Any contribution you can spare makes you an essential part of our production! 

Check out the Rewards. You'll see some tangible gifts, but most of the rewards are about getting you involved with the play by showing you exactly what your donation will create. You'll be able to see the show, listen to the music we create, taste Mary's famous clear soup, feel what a mechanical horse is like, and smell....the many smells of backstage. 

You'll also notice that each of the rewards is named after an awesome lady from the history of the Wild West! We love women's history and hope you do too - ask us about any of these women you may not have heard of, or look up the one your reward is named for!

Thank you for your kindness and support. Here's to the lady cowboys!
