story:
Cosplay - The Show

The worldwide phenomenon known as "cosplay" is a Japanese portmanteau of the English terms costume and play. With millions of people both participating and interested in the subculture and the varied themes such as superheroes, cartoon characters, video game characters; Cosplay The Show embraces cosplay with a Las Vegas flare.

The 70 minute production is set to perform in a major showroom on the Las Vegas strip featuring some of Las Vegas' most talented performers and a dizzying number of custom costumes and sets and props designed specifically for this production.

The Creator & Producer, Pete Housley, is no stranger to Las Vegas production shows and showrooms he's been the Director of Operations for Planet Hollywood's Sin City Theatre for the past four years, the Executive Producer of the Award Winning Sin City Comedy & Burlesque; as well as the marketing and creative consultant for Crazy Girls and Xavier Mortimer's Magical Dream.  As a huge fan of Science Fiction, Fantasy and Gaming, Housley has developed a Live Las Vegas show true the nature and culture of Fans and Cosplayers alike featuring many of his own favorite characters re-imagined for the Glitz and Glamour of Las Vegas.

Contributions to this campaign will be specifically used to increase production value of costumes, set pieces and props of the show as it is built and to develop a strong marketing campaign through Advertising and Social Media.  Cosplay - The Show will also participate in the growth of the community with special guest appearances from the actual actors who played in favorite television programs and movies, Cosplay Celebrities, as well as participation in conventions, events and charities.

Two potential venues have been selected for this production which cannot be announced at this time; however both are located on the Las Vegas strip in highly recognized properties and will have the support of these properties.

The sizzle reel here is just a sample of some of the many Cosplay costumes we've been designing; there's a lot more to the show itself from set pieces, choreography, script and music -- but it's true to it's essence and foundation that it's all about the Cosplay.

 

About Cosplay - The Show

Cosplay - The Show is a 70 minute fun roller coaster of vignettes featuring custom made costumes from your favorite fictional characters from television, movies, books, comics and video games.  Don't Panic! While Cosplay - The Show is created by fans you won't need to be a total geek to enjoy this show. But, there will be some insider jokes and fun crossovers that true fans will enjoy.  It's a Las Vegas show so there's a sexy feel to the show; and it's geared for a PG-13 audience.

What about the Perks?!?!?!

Developing a live stage production in Las Vegas comes with its fair share of costs; especially when developing a show that will be scrutinized by some of the most detail oriented fans on the planet.  The purpose  of this campaign is to raise capital for advertising, marketing, production, venue, staff, cast as well as costumes, props and sets.  The goal is to insure that we have an appropriate budget for 6+ months should ticket sales fail to match projections.

We're fans too! So we've created what we think are some awesome and unique perks around our launch that we hope will gain in value as we're successful; or will just make cool additions to collections.  Check out all the perks available at all kinds of levels; each item will be numbered and some signed by the producer, cast and crew. The 2001 perk includes all other perks and a Lifetime VIP Access Lanyard which gives you VIP complimentary tickets to shows and includes post-show Meet & Greet with the cast for photo opportunities.

Like any good Science Fiction and Fantasy we will fight the good fight; we know what we think it will take to get this production to work perfectly - but if we fall short of this goal we're prepared to patch up the ship and make a valiant effort; against all odds because we believe!

We'll be offering a series special "secret" perks throughout this campaign for contributors only; there will be some one-of-a-kind items and very limited edition items -- we'll offer these to all levels of contributors but not the general public - so please contribute early.

Risks & Challenges

Dozens of Las Vegas shows open and close every year; 2016 saw a huge number of large production shows close due to cast and labor costs combined with smaller paid audiences. Creator & Producer, Pete Housley, has been working in the Las Vegas entertainment and nightlife scene for more than 15 years. Housley has developed a number of shows over the years including the longest running Comedy Show in Las Vegas.  He's also had a show fail to connect with audiences; which was a strong learning opportunity.  Bring both success and failure experience to the table Housley is uniquely qualified to insure audiences get an amazing show for a reasonable ticket price that also is balanced with a budget to insure longevity.

Cosplay - The Show will remain true to classics, but not be afraid to grow and morph as new classics are made and fan-base increase. We've been careful to develop a show that's accessible to the mainstream while being fun and funny to the bigger geeks in the world. It's also important when developing a parody to both not be too silly and at the same time not take yourself too seriously.  We believe we've struck a balance there and will continue to change and flex the show based on audience feedback.

About the Creator / Producer

Pete Housley, creator and producer of Cosplay - The Show, owes much of his love and interest in Science Fiction and Fantasy to his brother Chris Golash who was an avid J.R.R. Tolkien reader and introduced him to Star Trek, Space 1999, Doctor Who and writers like C.S. Lewis, Ray Bradbury and Harlan Ellison.  In 1984, the brothers  attended their first ever Fan Convention together at Dixie Trek just outside Atlanta, GA which became an annual tradition into their adulthood. It was while attending the 2001 Creation Events Star Trek Convention in Las Vegas that Pete first learned of his brother Chris' untimely death.

"My love of Science Fiction continues today", said Pete Housley. "I think I'm most passionate about Doctor Who, both the Classic episodes with Peter Davidson and Tom Baker; as well as the more current David Tenant and Matt Smith years.  But Star Trek is a pretty powerful influence too -- Sisko and Janeway are two of my favorite characters."

Housley, 48, lives in Las Vegas with his loving partner and mother to their 3 young children; plus their dog (Toshiko) and cats (Captain Jack and Aladdin).

"Movies, television, and books have always offered me both an escape and hope for the future", continued Pete. "It started as me wanting a connection with my brother when I was little and has turned into a passion that I hope my children will embrace. The concept of Cosplay - The Show comes from these years of love of the genre and the people I've met along the way."

Want to be cast in the show or make Guest Appearance?

Cosplay is as much about the Cosplayers as the costumes and we're looking for the best of the best to join us as part of the cast or even as special guest appearances.  If you're a Cosplayer who wants to be a part of Cosplay - The Show in Las Vegas (or you know someone we should be casting or booking for special appearances) Tweet and follow us on Twitter @CosplayTheShow; message us on Facebook your Cosplay photos are welcome; or email us.

Other Ways You Can Help

We need your help getting the word out too... tell your friends! Post links to this campaign on your social media, on community forums or even join our Thunderclap Social Media campaign.

Follow us on Facebook & Twitter! Then tell us what characters and concepts you'd love to see in the show. In fact send us photos of you and your friends in Cosplay! We love seeing them!

Banners for your website/blog, please link to http://cosplaytheshow.com:

 

On Tour! Before we make our Las Vegas debut we're going to tour the show around the United States! Let us know where you'd like to see us play!

COME SEE THE SHOW! When we open tell all your friends and come see the show! We're going to have a lot of great interactive portions of the show that we've not even begun to touch on here. So grab a ticket, put on your favorite costume and come see the show!

If there's something you think we should be doing to get the word out tell us!

Cosplay - The Show is a Registered Trademark. All images and descriptions herein are Copyright Disaster Productions LLC. All Rights Reserved. Convention footage used by permission.

story:
Dance Animal: Toronto

Dance Animal was founded in Montreal in November 2008 by Robin Henderson.  Inspired by pop culture, pop music, music videos, politics, reality television, fashion, musical theatre, sketch comedy and her own personal travels, Dance Animal:Toronto is Robin’s love-letter to the city of Toronto.  Wanting to reflect the vast spectrum of languages and cultures of her adopted city, Robin deliberately combines the talents of a diverse cast of theatre artists to dynamic results. Our campaign will cover the costs of producing our current Fringe production and raise funds for future shows.

Break it Down

Being rockstar-superheroes takes time and money. Your generous donations will help us to pay for rehearsal space, tights, body suits, tops, leggings, shoes, tights, props and more tights. Have we mentioned how expensive tights are?

To promote our fantastic new show, we hired a photographer for headshots and group shots, a graphic designer for posters, postcards, and programs and a website designer.

Then there's the backstage costs including office supplies, union fees, laundry, transportation, a videographer and staffing costs for our creative and production teams. 

Sparkle!

Since the premiere of their first (and bilingual) production Dance Animal Presents: Dance Animal, Dance Animal has been smashing box-office records everywhere they perform.  They’ve had record breaking sold-out runs at the Montreal Fringe Festival, the Just For Laughs Festival, Zoofest and the Centaur Theatre’s Wildside Festival.  In 2009 they won the Just For Laughs “Best Comedy” award and were short-listed for the Centaur Theatre  "Best Production" award for their first show Dance Animal Presents: Dance Animal.  In 2010 they won the Cirque du Soleil "Best Original Creation" award, were given an Honourable Mention for the Studio 303 "Best Choreography" award and were nominated for the MECCA award for Best Ensemble for their show Dance Animal Presents : Freaks of Nature. 

Dance Animal also believes in supporting their community. They have performed in over 30 events/fundraisers outside of their festival runs including the Toronto Pride Parade, Concordia University’s Garnet Key Society’s Autism Fundraiser, the Toronto Air Guitar Championships in support of Right to Play, the Montreal Rollerderby, Yas Kween, Faggity Ass Friday – fundraiser for Head and Hands, and the UQAM fundraiser for Ligne Parents.

And 5, 6, 7, 8...

Your support doesn't have to be financial, spread the Dance Animal love by sharing this campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, or shouting it from your rooftop. Don't forget to like us on Facebook (facebook.com/danceanimal), Instagram (@danceanimalofficial), Twitter (@danceanimal), check out our website (www.danceanimal.ca) and come see us live! at the Toronto Fringe.

story:
The McTeggart Irish Dancers of North Texas have been offering classes in competitive and performance Irish step dancing in the DFW area since 1984.   Our dancers not only compete locally, regionally, and internationally but they perform throughout the area at schools, retirement homes, and major cultural events to promote and keep alive the art of traditional Irish dancing.  Our dancers truly love this sport for the fun, fitness, and camaraderie it provides, putting in dozens of hours a month to prepare for competitions.  We offer outstanding instruction to help our dancers meet their goals and develop a lifelong love of dance!

In our history of offering classes in the area, we have never had a dance studio home of our own.  Our classes have been taught in churches, fire houses, recreation centers, or rented class space from other dance studios.  As a non-profit school, we struggled with how we could continue to meet the needs of our new and existing students with the limits on our space and schedules that comes with renting from other studios.  We have been on the lookout for the ideal space for a while now and have recently found a location that is a great and affordable fit for us.  We are so excited to finally have a dance space of our very own!

Building a dance studio has a lot of upfront costs and we are hoping to reach our fundraising goal of $5,000.  Our list of basic needs for our new studio include items such as rental deposits, permits, construction fees, window coverings, flooring, mirrors, and a sound system.  Any extra funds raised beyond this amount would go towards improving our studio for use over the long term to guarantee the continued success of our school; things like signage, interior improvements, workshops, equipment, and choreography.

We want everyone who chooses to help support our school to know how much we appreciate them.  We want to thank you by rewarding our contributors with a variety of perks.  Even if you can't make a large gift, every bit helps.  Because we are a 501C3 non-profit, your contributions are also considered a tax-fee donation.

Even if you can’t contribute, you can still help us by spreading the word about the McTeggart Irish Dancers of North Texas!  Please share our fundraising campaign with your friends and family by forwarding this email and help us on our journey!

You can also:

Share our website:  www.danceirish.org

Like us on Facebook:  

https://www.facebook.com/groups/342178849169590/

https://www.facebook.com/mcteggartnorthtexas/

Follow us on Instagram:

https://www.instagram.com/mcteggartntx/?hl=en

Check out our Twitter feed:  

https://twitter.com/McTNTXID
Thank you for supporting us in this new adventure!

story:
La Llorona, the Weeping Woman

Writing Our Legacy is producing a new site-specific theatre production of the Mexican myth La Llorona, in association with Tanglehead Productions.

In our new theatre production, La Llorona is a Mexican woman who is exploited as she tries to follow the American Dream. She leaves behind her children, as so many do, to survive. A timely tale in the current global political climate.

We tell our story with the poetic poetry of the Latin American tradition of dream-like magical realism and surrealism. Our figure meets both real and desert characters on her journey.

How You Can Help....

We need your help to raise £5,000 to cover production costs for a show in Brighton Fringe in May 2017. 

We will be staging our show at a very secret venue, which will only be revealed once the crowdfunder is finished. We can't wait to share this with you! 

The £5,000 crowdfunded money will be used on the following production costs: 

- build materials (£2k)
- costumes (£1k)
- rigging for indoor & outdoor lights (£1k)
-  performance venues (£500)
- transport costs (£500)

We have some incredible prizes to thank you for your support....

We have put together 19 unique supporter packages to say thank you for your donation.

These include a range of items:

  • La Llorona merchandise (t-shirt, poster, tote bag, keychains)
  • Tickets to our Fringe show
  • La Llorona perfume, jewellery & music created especially for our show
  • Meal for 2 at La Choza 
  • Theatre workshops
  • Invitation to a VIP Cocktail Party with the production team
  • and more.....
About Our Production Team
 

Writing Our Legacy is a literature organisation that has been reaching out to diverse writers and audiences across Sussex and the South East since 2012. 

We are passionate about bringing authentic Mexican culture and mythology to UK audiences.

Director Rikki Tarascas and writer Amy Zamarripa Solis draw on their Mexican heritage to give a real voice to this modern retelling of La Llorona, which explores political, economic and environmental issues. 

In 2012, we started Brighton's first festival of Latin culture, Latin Voices Live! Festival.

We work with the vibrant Latin American & Latin community and artists to produce cultural events every year. 

Our partners include MEXSAS, the Mexican and Latin American Society for University of Sussex and Eden Perfumes, a Mexican-owned vegan perfume shop in Brighton.

Why Your Support Is Needed

Your support will help us raise the match-funding we need to unlock funding from Arts Council England. Without your support, we will not be able to stage our R&D performances in 2017. 

Any extra money raised during this crowdfunding campaign will be re-invested into the La Llorona theatre production as we continue to develop the show. 

This is a development project, so we will take our supporters on our journey…..our plans include taking the show on tour in the UK and Europe.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you like our campaign, please share it with your friends, family and social networks https://igg.me/at/lalloronabrightonfringe2017

Join La Llorona on Facebook
http://bit.ly/LaLloronaFacebook

Follow Writing Our Legacy on social media:

http://bit.ly/WritingOurLegacyTwitter
http://bit.ly/WritingOurLegacyFacebook

To learn more about our work, see our website
 http://bit.ly/WritingOurLegacywebsite

Any extra money raised during this crowdfunding campaign will be re-invested into the La Llorona theatre production as we continue to develop the show. 
This is a development project, so we will take our supporters on our journey…..our plans include taking the show on tour in the UK and Europe.
Other Ways You Can Help
If you like our campaign, please share it with your friends, family and social networks https://igg.me/at/lalloronabrightonfringe2017
Join La Llorona on Facebookhttp://bit.ly/LaLloronaFacebook
Follow Writing Our Legacy on social media:
http://bit.ly/WritingOurLegacyTwitterhttp://bit.ly/WritingOurLegacyFacebook
To learn more about our work, see our website http://bit.ly/WritingOurLegacywebsite

story:
NO U-TURNS A. D. Has been accepted to perform in The New York Theatre Festival's WINTERFEST!

 

How did No U-Turns come to be

I'm Francine Mancini the writer of No U-Turns. I've been singing all my life and at this point that is a long time! I love musical theatre and Rock N Roll.  I've been through my ups and downs like everyone has. When I went through divorce which was probably the most difficult time of my life I turned to my creativity and to friends. Writing songs and spending time with friends led me to forming the story about these women who bond in a particularly difficult time in their lives. When you go through a divorce you are then part of a "club". Anyone who is divorced bonds with you therefore I've heard many stories of divorce which helped me to write this piece.  Strong, vulnerable sometimes broken women who get through it  when the dreams they had were shattered. They pick themselves up and go on. I wanted to tell that story through songs and that is  what became NO U-Turns A. D.

History

After 10 years of writing and developing we did a cabaret production  in 2013 which was well received but unable to continue financially. We now have been accepted to the New York Theatre Festival giving us the opportunity to bring it into a theatre and continue developing. This is a very exciting opportunity! this is another step in the journey to creating a show that we are hoping could have a longer run in a theatre. 

But we cannot do it alone, we need your help! To put together the best show we can we need supporters like you. We need to pay our cast, our musicians,  our staff ,  there's rehearsal space to rent and advertising. Unfortunately this takes funds which we do not have. 

We need YOUR SUPPORT!!

You can be part of an exciting new show that tells women's stories!

  • Ideally we would raise $20, 000 which would cover salaries, rehearsals, advertising, costumes, props and sets. 
  • For your support Check out our perks!!
  • If we don't reach our entire goal the show will go on but we will have a bare bones production, we will have to pay the cast and musicians a pittance. We will have no advertising to boost the show and our audience which is necessary to help the show continue and grow. This all compromises the quality and the ability to continue. 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Get the word out!
  •  Use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • Volunteer in some way
  • If you have rehearsal space or talents that could enhance our production then let us know!

story:
Who We Are

We are a growing group of artists in our second year of production, passionate about asking life's big questions and engaging in meaningful dialogue with the community.  Last year, our production of Freud's Last Session won the 2016 Hawaii State Theatre Council Po‘okela Awards for Outstanding Overall Production, Outstanding Director, and Outstanding Guest Artist.  This year, we are excited  to bring you The Last Days of Judas Iscariot.

What's the Story?

Set in a time-bending, seriocomic world between heaven and hell, The Last Days of Judas Iscariot is a meditation on the conflict between divine mercy and human free will that takes a close look at the eternal damnation of Judas Iscariot – the Bible's most notorious sinner.

Presented as a taut and riotous courtroom drama in the depths of Purgatory, Judas features a wild cast of characters – Mother Teresa, Pontius Pilate, Sigmund Freud, even Satan himself – to ask the question, “What happened to Judas Iscariot?”

What We Need 

The total amount that we are looking to raise is $25,000.  Some of that need has already been met by those who are committed members of our team.  However, we still have a long way to go. Specifically, our largest need is making sure we have the professional acting talent to fill 15 roles.  Our total budget for actor expenses (including wages, travel, and lodging) comes to $16,000.  Right now, we would like to focus on raising at least $15,000 before May 1st, but we are hoping to see our full $16,000 if not even the full $25,000!

To show our appreciation of your generosity, we will be offering some great perks, including: free beverages at concessions, a book about the original Off-Broadway production, complimentary tickets, a sneak peak of a dress rehearsal, and even an invitation to our gala celebration.

Risks & Challenges

Some of the risks that we face stem from the fact that this is a much larger production than what we attempted and accomplished last year.  We are coming upon a quick deadline to raise all of our funds.  As with Freud, we hope to fly in some of our professional talent from the mainland, which means we need to know if we can pay for their expenses far enough in advance to allow them to clear their calendars to commit to a production so far away from home.

Other Ways You Can Help

We are also looking for people who might be able to volunteer their time during the production process itself.  We will need ushers and front of house staff.  We will need extra hands to get our space ready for the show.  We would absolutely love people to bring us food!  They don't call us "starving artists" just for fun.

story:
Within This Dust at 9/11 Memorial & Museum at the World Trade Center New York City

We need your help to make something really special happen! We are asking for your support to help us take our critically acclaimed dance theatre production, Within This Dust to the 9/11 Memorial & Museum at the World Trade Center in New York City.  

But who are we? Well, we are a charity based in Dundee, Scotland and we present the critically acclaimed work of Thomas Small, our multi award winning choreographer and the first ever Artist in Residence at BBC Radio 2.  We tour dance productions to theatres and interesting spaces around the world.  We also deliver creative learning workshops in partnership with brilliant partners such as NHS Tayside where we deliver a smoking awareness project called Well Good in 116 primary schools in Scotland; a project in care homes working with people living with dementia and Alzheimer's; and an upcoming project bring young and old LGBT people together to creatively talk about the process of coming out 50 years apart.   

We regard art as a powerful agent for change in the world. 

Within This Dust explores the events surrounding 9/11 and is inspired by the iconic series of photographs by Richard Drew that capture a man falling from the World Trade Center during the 9/11 attacks.

Within This Dust balances sumptuous movement and subtle storytelling to explore themes of impact, loss, survival and humanity in relation to the stark horror of the day.  The work is performed within a backdrop of 2,977 pieces of white paper that symbolize the lives lost that day and serves as a dynamic, ever-changing landscape to evoke the memories from and since the day.  Within This Dust combines beautiful filmic moments and striking physicality. The show was part of the 2012 Made in Scotland Showcase enjoying a sold-out run of performances at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe and featured on the BBC Culture Show.  Within This Dust has toured internationally to New York City, Sao Paulo & Berlin, and received 4 stars from The Scotsman saying ‘So beautiful, I had tears pouring down my face’.

We are delighted to have been invited to present the work at the 9/11 Memorial & Museum at the World Trade Center on 21st April.  We are over the moon to have been given this amazing opportunity to share the work at such an important site.  We are asking you for some support to take the show on this once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to present the work at this important museum.  You can read more about the show here on the museum's website.

The show features 2,977 pieces of paper and we are asking you to sponsor and help us take one piece of paper to NYC.  We’d love you to feature in the show by telling us about your memories of 9/11.  Your accounts will feature in the pre-show exhibition. 

You can sponsor as many pieces of paper as you wish and we will acknowledge your support on the official programme for the performance and also on our website to say Thank You, and recognise that you have played an important part in helping us stage this piece of work at the museum.

Photo: Maria Falconer.

 

What We Need & What You Get

To take the show to NYC, we need £2500 to cover the costs of bringing the dancers together in Dundee to rehearse and prepare for this unique performance.  We have applied for funding from Creative Scotland, our national arts council, to help us cover the costs of flights and accommodation and fees for the cast and crew. Our charity's own very limited funds will be used to contribute towards these costs.  However, even with this support, we still need to fundraise to cover the costs of rehearsing and preparing for the show.  Here are a breakdown of the costs:

£1000 - Rehearsal studio venue hire in Dundee

£900 - Fees for the 2 dancers for the rehearsal week (each dancer earning £450 for the week)

£350 - Travel costs to bring dancers to Dundee for the rehearsals (one lives in Belgium and the other in Glasgow)

£250 - Accommodation costs for 2 dancers for the rehearsal week

 

In return for your generosity, we can offer some unique perks! Have a look and see what you fancy!

If we don't reach our entire goal then funds raised will be used to cover the fees for the dancers and we will source alternative ways to host the dancers and rehearse.   If we raise more than we anticipate then we will produce a short film that documents our NYC trip and including interviews with the creative team and those affected by the attacks.  The aim of this new filmic work would be to capture people’s evolutionary perceptions of the issues regarding terrorism since the 9/11 attacks. 

The Impact

As a dance company that regularly engages in issue-based productions and inclusive Creative Learning work, we strongly believe that our work is socially committed and worth of a shared experience through watching shows, participation, consultation and co-creation. The piece that we are presenting at the 9/11 Museum and memorial is based on the 9/11 attacks, with terrorism being an issue that unfortunately is not disappearing form the International Politics agendas.

We think that artists have a duty to present work that acts as a catalyst for shared discussions, reflections and debates at grass-roots levels. 

All the people contributing in this campaign will help to support a new film that incorporates new thinking, new reflections, new questions, and perhaps new solutions for the times ahead. 
As societies develop, and we deal with vertiginous changes and adaptations, artists have the wonderful duty to reflect and comment on present affairs as well as imagining new ways of existence, supported not necessarily by institutions but by individuals that likewise, believe in art as a human right and its powerful transformational force. 

The show has already built a successful track record through performances at venues internationally in Sao Paulo, NYC and Berlin; and received critical acclaim (4 star reviews) from major newspapers such as The Herald and The Scotsman.  

Photo: Caroline Tosin.

Risks & Challenges

As a small charity, we are fully aware of the current economic climate and are therefore diversifying income streams by resorting to micro-funding campaigns. We acknowledge the power of movements and are appealing to individuals who, like us, feel strongly about supporting causes with a social impact, in this case, through art. 

We understand that part of the challenges regarding this campaign could be that a section of the public may get upset, as this is a sensitive issues with regards to different aspects. 

In addition, as the financial situation seems to be a strain for most people, we accept that this may not be a highly participatory campaign. 

We do, however, as artists, feel strongly about the need to collaborate in cultural, cross-borders, supportive artistic movements that have social change at their heart, and so with this campaign are humbly appealing to like-minded individuals. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't afford to contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Please share this campaign to help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

Please share this campaign to help us get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
Please use the Indiegogo share tools!

story:
In a world parallel to our own, where humans evolved from dinosaurs the rich lineage of the Mushroom Kingdom passes down a valuable secret - the 1-Up Mushroom, granting the possessor eternal life. When the evil King Koopa, descendant of the T-Rex vows to conquer the Mushroom Kingdom, the good King Pear sends his daughter to safety through the mysterious Warp Zone linked to our world. 

In present-day Brooklyn, the Super Mario Brothers, a pair of plumbing paisanos bite off more they can chew when a young archaeologist, Daisy calls upon their assistance. With a mysterious emerald gemstone as the only clue to her past, she's kidnapped by a set of inconspicuous workers, and the Mario brothers give chase, winding up in another world unlike that they've ever seen.

Based on the cult classic 1993 film starring Bob Hoskins, in turn based on the wildly popular series of video games, A Mariokart Named Desire combines humor, suspense and romance with five toe-tapping original songs from lyricist Bryn Tanner, writer of last year's "Pocahontas (Or How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Mouse)" - chosen for Freshwater Theatre's annual Fringe remount in 2015 - and composer Zach Miller. A fun musical for all ages, gamer and non-gamer alike! Do the Mario!

story:
CRADLE SONG

A Musical

THE STORY

When teenager Tom Dawley mustered up the courage to come out to his deeply religious parents, the reception to this news was everything he feared. Before long, his father kicked him out of their home and told him not to return until he'd mended his "wicked" ways.

Now, years later—amidst the turmoil of 1980’s America—Tom is alone and diagnosed with AIDS, and the only people he can turn to in his final days are family.

After a short stint living with his sister Katie, Tom soon finds himself back under the roof of the parents who scorned him:  his father, George, a pious, self-righteous man, and his mother, Louise, whose desperate need to connect with her son directly conflicts with her faith and her husband’s stubborn dogmatism.

Their road isn't an easy one, but with the help of Sammy Emmanuel—an unapologetically upbeat hospice nurse who pulls no punches—Tom, George, Louise, and Katie learn lessons in love, acceptance, forgiveness, and the importance of family in a less than tolerant world.

Here's a composer's demo of the title song:

 

THE TEAM

Writer/Composer/Lyricist — Robert Gregory Browne is an award-winning multi-published novelist, screenwriter, playwright, and a lifelong musician and composer. In addition to his bestselling novels, Rob is the recipient of the AMPAS Nicholl Fellowship in Screenwriting, was nominated for best novel by the International Thriller Writers, and has written teleplays for Showtime, Fox and Marvel Productions.

Lead Producer — Beth Rudetsky, a student of music since the age of seven, studied under renowned concert pianist Morton Estrin and composer Herbert Deutsch at Hofstra University. Beth was the vocalist on numerous pop recordings, has performed on Broadway and in clubs in and around New York City, and was the resident singer-pianist for composer Burt Bacharach's restaurant for many years. She has also written and performed music for film and has written and produced the music for a number of book trailers for authors. The sister of producer/writer/performer and SiriusXM Radio host Seth Rudetsky, Beth is well-connected in the Broadway world and has a keen eye for up-and-coming talent.
 

WHY WE NEED YOUR HELP

Launching a new musical in New York is an enormous undertaking. We need to hold workshops and staged readings to help develop CRADLE SONG, get it in shape for the stage, and allow potential Broadway investors to see the play on its feet with hopes of an Off-Broadway or even Broadway production.

Some of our main areas of funding are: 

  • Rehearsal Venue — Space to hold developmental readings and showcases in New York City is expensive, and grows ever more expensive as the readings become more complex and larger rehearsal spaces are needed in order to present the work for Broadway investors.
     
  • Actor/Director Salaries — While “starving artists” are a romantic notion, our director and actors have already donated time out of their busy schedules to do a reading of the play for nothing more than a $10 Starbucks card. Going forward, we’d like to offer a financial incentive on top of the artistic one. People can’t live on coffee alone…
     
  • Musician Salaries — My song demos will only go so far. As development progresses it'll become necessary to hire musicians and a copyist to bring them to life.
     
  • Food — Rehearsals take many hours and we want to ensure that everyone who participates in the development of the play is fed. A happy stomach makes for a happy cast and crew. But, again, we're talking about New York City here, and food is costly.
     
  • Lead Producer Fee — Thanks to her fervent belief in this play and its music, my lead producer has been working entirely out of her own pocket, and I'd like to offer her a small token of compensation for her time and transportation costs.
     
  • Contingency Funds — In the first reading alone, expenses cropped up that were unexpected. With any creative endeavor involving multiple people, things can and often do go wrong, and the strain on the wallet can be considerable. 

As a result of these costs, we're calling on the community—especially those of you who love great plays and musicals—to help us raise $15,000. Any contribution is truly, truly appreciated.

Let's work together to bring CRADLE SONG to life!


PROMOTION

We would also greatly appreciate your efforts to spread the news about CRADLE SONG and this campaign. Tell your friends and family, and be noisy about it on social media. Every tweet and Facebook post counts. And be sure to use the link: https://igg.me/at/CradleSongMusical along with the #CradleSongMusical and #IndieGogo hashtags!
 

THANK YOU

Seeing this play on the Off-Broadway or Broadway stage would be a dream come true. We can't do it without you!

Thank you so much for your help.

Check out our website at: http://cradlesongmusical.com

 

Video Photo Credits:

  • Family hands ©  Jakub Jirsák / stock.adobe.com
  • Dysfunctional Family © EJ White / stock.adobe.com
  • Hug © Photographee.eu / stock.adobe.com
  • New York City © bruno135_406 / stock.adobe.com
  • Jar © lemontreeimages  / stock.adobe.com
  • Broadway Street Sign © Delphotostock / stock.adobe.com
  • Investor Angel © adam121 / stock.adobe.com
story_txt:
CRADLE SONGA MusicalTHE STORYWhen teenager Tom Dawley mustered up the courage to come out to his deeply religious parents, the reception to this news was everything he feared. Before long, his father kicked him out of their home and told him not to return until he'd mended his "wicked" ways.Now, years later—amidst the turmoil of 1980’s America—Tom is alone and diagnosed with AIDS, and the only people he can turn to in his final days are family.After a short stint living with his sister Katie, Tom soon finds himself back under the roof of the parents who scorned him:  his father, George, a pious, self-righteous man, and his mother, Louise, whose desperate need to connect with her son directly conflicts with her faith and her husband’s stubborn dogmatism.Their road isn't an easy one, but with the help of Sammy Emmanuel—an unapologetically upbeat hospice nurse who pulls no punches—Tom, George, Louise, and Katie learn lessons in love, acceptance, forgiveness, and the importance of family in a less than tolerant world.Here's a composer's demo of the title song: THE TEAMWriter/Composer/Lyricist — Robert Gregory Browne is an award-winning multi-published novelist, screenwriter, playwright, and a lifelong musician and composer. In addition to his bestselling novels, Rob is the recipient of the AMPAS Nicholl Fellowship in Screenwriting, was nominated for best novel by the International Thriller Writers, and has written teleplays for Showtime, Fox and Marvel Productions.Lead Producer — Beth Rudetsky, a student of music since the age of seven, studied under renowned concert pianist Morton Estrin and composer Herbert Deutsch at Hofstra University. Beth was the vocalist on numerous pop recordings, has performed on Broadway and in clubs in and around New York City, and was the resident singer-pianist for composer Burt Bacharach's restaurant for many years. She has also written and performed music for film and has written and produced the music for a number of book trailers for authors. The sister of producer/writer/performer and SiriusXM Radio host Seth Rudetsky, Beth is well-connected in the Broadway world and has a keen eye for up-and-coming talent. WHY WE NEED YOUR HELPLaunching a new musical in New York is an enormous undertaking. We need to hold workshops and staged readings to help develop CRADLE SONG, get it in shape for the stage, and allow potential Broadway investors to see the play on its feet with hopes of an Off-Broadway or even Broadway production.Some of our main areas of funding are: 

Rehearsal Venue — Space to hold developmental readings and showcases in New York City is expensive, and grows ever more expensive as the readings become more complex and larger rehearsal spaces are needed in order to present the work for Broadway investors. 

Actor/Director Salaries — While “starving artists” are a romantic notion, our director and actors have already donated time out of their busy schedules to do a reading of the play for nothing more than a $10 Starbucks card. Going forward, we’d like to offer a financial incentive on top of the artistic one. People can’t live on coffee alone… 

Musician Salaries — My song demos will only go so far. As development progresses it'll become necessary to hire musicians and a copyist to bring them to life. 

Food — Rehearsals take many hours and we want to ensure that everyone who participates in the development of the play is fed. A happy stomach makes for a happy cast and crew. But, again, we're talking about New York City here, and food is costly. 

Lead Producer Fee — Thanks to her fervent belief in this play and its music, my lead producer has been working entirely out of her own pocket, and I'd like to offer her a small token of compensation for her time and transportation costs. 

Contingency Funds — In the first reading alone, expenses cropped up that were unexpected. With any creative endeavor involving multiple people, things can and often do go wrong, and the strain on the wallet can be considerable. 
As a result of these costs, we're calling on the community—especially those of you who love great plays and musicals—to help us raise $15,000. Any contribution is truly, truly appreciated.Let's work together to bring CRADLE SONG to life!PROMOTIONWe would also greatly appreciate your efforts to spread the news about CRADLE SONG and this campaign. Tell your friends and family, and be noisy about it on social media. Every tweet and Facebook post counts. And be sure to use the link: https://igg.me/at/CradleSongMusical along with the #CradleSongMusical and #IndieGogo hashtags! THANK YOUSeeing this play on the Off-Broadway or Broadway stage would be a dream come true. We can't do it without you!Thank you so much for your help.Check out our website at: http://cradlesongmusical.com Video Photo Credits:
Family hands ©  Jakub Jirsák / stock.adobe.com
Dysfunctional Family © EJ White / stock.adobe.com
Hug © Photographee.eu / stock.adobe.com
New York City © bruno135_406 / stock.adobe.com
Jar © lemontreeimages  / stock.adobe.com
Broadway Street Sign © Delphotostock / stock.adobe.com
Investor Angel © adam121 / stock.adobe.com

story:
Please Join Pulse Theatre Chicago this summer as we embark on our landmark production of the controversial, critically acclaimed play ‘Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf’. We've assembled a diverse cast of talented, working professional artists to truly bring this show to life!

Pulse Theatre Chicago productions are produced and funded by it's ensemble of performers and independently out-of-pocket, but we can't do it alone. We are asking friends and family of Pulse as well as the entire artistic community to help us reach our goal of $2,400!

We have the pleasure to announce that we are a registered 501 (c) (3) Non-for-profit theatre company and all of your generous donations will be tax deductible.

Oh yes!

 

 

Don't be! Pulse is 100% committed to bringing groundbreaking work to the City of Chicago.

Our mission is to ambitiously tell stories, old and new, with a unique outlook and visceral honesty to the human experience. We look to reverently break out of the convention and barriers of archetypes and provide an artistically progressive environment for our collaborators and audiences alike. 

This production of Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf will be directed by Pulse Theatre's artistic director Chris Jackson! 

Chris Jackson, a Chicago native, is a graduate of Columbia College Chicago. Jackson holds a Bachelors of Fine Arts in Musical Theatre Performance. He is Co-founder, Producing Artistic Director and  Resident Director of Pulse Theatre Chicago. He is a recipient of such awards as the Louis Armstrong Top Jazz musician award, CCC Achievement award among others. Christopher had the pleasure of being in the ensemble of the 2012 Pulitzer Prize finalist for music 'Death and the Powers', an opera directed by Tony Award Winner Diane Paulus. He has also been featured in other award winning musicals such as Ain't Misbehaving' and Golden boy at Porchlight Theatre as well as The Wild Party at Bailiwick Theatre. Most recently, he can be seen on television for his first national commercial with Wal-Mart/Verizon.

The Story: George, a professor at a small college, and his wife, Martha, have just returned home from a late night faculty party. Martha announces she has invited a young couple—Nick, a  new professor at the college and Honey his wife—to stop by for a nightcap. As the drinks flow, suddenly inhibitions melt and it becomes clear that underneath the edgy banter lurks an undercurrent of tragedy and despair. George and Martha's bitterness toward one another is provoked by the enormous personal sadness that they have pledged to keep to themselves: a secret that has seemingly been the foundation for their relationship. In the end, the mystery in which the distressed George and Martha have taken refuge is exposed, once and for all revealing the degrading mess they have made of their lives.

List of accolades 

Winner of the 1963 Tony Award for Best Play

1962–63 New York Drama Critics' Circle Award for Best Play

The film was nominated for thirteen Academy Awards, including Best Picture and Best Director for Mike Nichols, and is one of only two films to be nominated in every eligible category at the Academy Awards. All of the film's four main actors were nominated in their respective acting categories.

The film won five awards, including a second Academy Award for Best Actress for Elizabeth Taylor and the Academy Award for Best Supporting Actress for Sandy Dennis.

It was famously selected for the 1963 Pulitzer Prize for Drama by that award's drama jury. However, the award's advisory board – the trustees of Columbia University – objected to the play's then-controversial use of profanity and sexual themes, and overruled the award's advisory committee, awarding no Pulitzer Prize for drama in 1963.

Meet the cast of Pulse Theatre's Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf?

Nicholia Q. Aguirre, is honored to be working with Pulse Theatre Company in its production of Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf as Martha. She attended Loyola University of Chicago, where she received her B.S. in Education. She studied at Piven Theatre Workshop and is currently a teacher on staff. Recently seen in Steel Magnolias (The Arc Theatre), Vagina Monologues & Gee’s Bend (Fleetwood Jourdain Theatre), Constant State of Panic (Clockwise Theatre) (Fleetwood Jourdain Theatre), and Little Shop of Horrors (Devonshire Theatre). She is represented by Big Mouth Talent and is proud to be working with such a talented cast and director. 

Lewis R. Jones is honored to be in his third production with Pulse Theatre Chicago, after appearing in A Streetcar Named Desire and Fabulation. He recently portrayed Nathan Detroit in Wilmette Center for the Arts' production of Guys and Dolls. Lewis has been Don Quixote in Man of La Mancha; Steve in August: Osage County, and even "God" in Early One Evening at the Rainbow Bar and Grille. But George is by far the most challenging role of his career. Lewis studied at the Acting Studio Chicago and Second City. He thanks director Christopher Jackson for his faith in him. And, of course, he is always grateful for Renya, the true love his life, and his friends and family for their endless support.

Adam Zaininger is thrilled to be once again working with Pulse Theatre Company Chicago. He previously performed in their production of A Streetcar Named Desire (Stanley Kowalski). His most recent performance was with Organic Theater Company in their production of Out of the Blue (Andrey). He will also be performing in their upcoming production of King Ubu (Ensemble). Adam received his BFA in Acting from Northern Illinois University School of Theatre and Dance. There he studied the Meisner acting technique along with voice and movement styles derived from Catherine Fitzmaurice and Lloyd Williamson. Past productions with NIU include Marat/Sade (Cucurucu), Love's Labour's Lost (Ferdinand), Almost, Maine (Steve/Phil), The Caucasian Chalk Circle (Simon), and Not About Nightingales (Shapiro). He is truly grateful towards Pulse Theatre Company Chicago for yet another opportunity to work with so many talented and passionate artists.

Kate Robison is completely delighted to be working with Pulse Theatre Company Chicago for the first time. As a recent transplant to the city, recent Chicago credits include Women, Politics, and Murder (Clock Theatre) and A Prayer For The Sandinistas (Subtext Theatre Company), opening May 19. Most recent regional credits include Waiting for the Paint to Dry (Theatre Battery; Seattle, WA) and Grapes of Wrath (Oklahoma City Repertory Theatre; OKC). Kate currently trains at Black Box Acting Studio (Meisner technique and Viewpoints), and received her BFA in Acting from Oklahoma City University. In addition to acting, training, and having a whale of a time, Kate has worked as a Court Appointed Special Advocate (CASA) in Pierce County, WA and is looking forward to doing the same advocacy work here in Chicago. Thank you to Pulse, Chris, her wonderful family, and lovely friends. 

The number one question we are asked about this production is "Do you think the play is still relevant"?

The answer is a resounding YES! In an age where looking good could essentually be a career, the biggest theme of in the play really makes us ask the question: "How achievable is the American Dream"? American relations with the Soviet Union were often extremely tense in the early 1960s, the era in which this play was written, which made it all the more important for families to portray the widely accepted American values. Albee, and other absurdest playwrights of that time were some of the first popular successes to articulate these undercurrents of dissatisfaction and unease about America - critically analyzing institutions and values that Americans held dear: family, marriage, and success - and suggested they might have been created in part to escape from reality. 

Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf is the epitome of our mission. Our company's goal is to provide a safe place for artist to be able cultivate their talents with other like minded artist. Pulse was created out of frustration due to the lack of inclusion of voices of color in the Chicago theatrical community and this production keeps those ideals fresh in our minds.

This production of 'Woolf' will be one of the first productions that will feature a multi-racial cast.

Pulse Recently raised over $3000 for its inaugural production of A Streetcar Named Desire by Tennessee Williams Directed by founders and artistic directors.

People like you keep Pulse going. With your help, Pulse will continue to make a definitive mark on Chicago Stages.

Even if you feel you cannot support us financially at this time it would be a great help if you could share the link for the campaign to help us spread the word and get more donations! Thank you for your support of Pulse Theatre Company Chicago

Our goal is to raise $2,400 for this production! 

It seems simple, but a donation of any kind really does go a long way. In addition to our rehearsal and performance space, your financial support will cover stipends for our entire team including actors, designers and stage  managers. You will also help us cover the cost of marketing costume rental and setbuildingbuilding , both to reach artists from every corner of the city and to build a strong, excited audience to come see them!

Funds raised through our Campaign will go towards the essentials of our production.

-Rehearsal Space  

-Performance Venue

-Set Building and Props

-Costume Rental

- Actor and Designer Stipends        

Show Budget

The numbers and the pie chart listed below reflects the amount we need to raise and what they are  allocated for. The numbers listed do not reflects the total  out-of-pocket expenses made to the production thus far. 

Set and Supplies: $1,200.00

Lights: $400.00

Sound: $100.00

Advertisement : $500

Costumes: $200.00

 
 
 

The only risk that this production of Who's Afraid of Virginia Woolf is facing is the possibliity that the estate of Edward Albee could attempt to revoke the rights from us do to our choice of casting actors of color as the leading roles.

​In recent news, the Albee Estate revoked the rights of another production of "Virginia Woolf" that choose to cast a black actor as the role of Nick. Although the news is a huge shock for us, we know that our show is a go!

You can't afford to donate, but you still want to be involved?

You sure can! If you are interested in working with us, either as an artist or in an administrative capacity, please visit www.pulsetheatrechicago.com or e-mail us at pulsetheatrechicago@gmail.com.

You can also be a big help by spreading the word! Please consider sharing our website and our campaign with anyone you feel would be interested in helping this company continue to create groundbreaking work.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Steve Coker, I been writing since 1987 where I began writing children’s plays for Clark College’s Touring Children’s Theatre. In 1991 I decided to write my first full-length stage play, “Looking for Olivia.” “Olivia” got a lot of attention in Europe where it was entered into the Swansea Bay Film Festival as a screenplay by mistake. 

"Looking for Olivia” heralds the arrival of the next generation of American writers in the tradition of Neil Simon and Woody Allen. Steve Coker is seriously good. I look forward enormously to his future works." -Binda Singh  Swansea Bay Film Festival.

I quickly realized I was more of a screenwriter than playwright and began to focus my attention on writing for film. Several of my screenplays were locally produced; “Crackin’ The Code,” “Thomas and theTrain Master,” (both currently available on Vimeo) and the upcoming features, “Giant Killers,” and “Hello, I Love You!”  But now, several years later I have return to my first love, Theatre... and have now adapted two of my film scripts into successful stage plays; “Varsity Cheerleader Werewolves From Outer Space,” and “The Adventures of Dex Dixon: Paranormal Dick” which I adapted with my composer KJ McElrath and Arranger Pete Petersen.  The show played to audiences in Portland to stunning review and “Dex Dixon” has had it’s world premier as a brand new main-stage musical production with Stumptown Stages as part of the 2016 Fertile Ground Ne Works Festival in January 2016  and was nominated for several PAMTAs(Portland Area Musical Theatre Awards;)  including; Best Original Musical, Best Original Orchestration, and Best Original Song :"You Pull My Strings" 

We were lucky enough to receive the award for Best Original Song and this has refueled my interest in creating an original cast album. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are currently looking to raise $8500.00 to record the original musical with a 16 piece orchestra and some of the amazing singers from the World Premier Production. 

The money will be used to rent a recording studio, hire an engineer, musicians and pay a small stipend to the performers.  Any additional funds will be used to produce the art and packaging and to post to online distribution sources. 

To those generous enough to donate to our cause, you will receive some cool Dex Dixon prizes and merchandise; from Posters, and original character design art pieces, to the soundtrack CD or digital tracks themselves.  And you will be part of making our show visible (audible) across the country.

The Impact

Once we have the recording, we will be able to market the show in a much more professional and focused way... reaching out to regional theaters and seeking production partners.  We will gain grass roots fans that can help promote the music and a desire for actual full stage productions.  We will be able to approach publishing houses so that the show can be made available for theatre companies to produce and perform the show nationwide. 

Here are some of the amazing things said about our show (full reviews available upon request or through google search;)

“A dizzily entertaining new musical!”      “One of Fertile Ground’s most captivating shows.”

“Dex Dixon… is predicated on delicious pulp-poetry and puns.”

“I seem to always come to the same conclusion about shows I love:  It comes down to IQ and this is one of the smartest teams I’ve seen in a long time.”

"Dex Dixon: Paranormal Dick" is doubtlessly the most bizarre show currently running on a Portland stage.”

“(possessing the) nuance, technical sophistication and unvarnished authenticity we've come to expect from Steve Coker.”

“…a creative vision, forged by immersion in the excesses of schlock culture, that honors the workaday artists who fueled show business well before the monsters took over.”

“…silliness moving at maximum flow, with enough comic pauses to let the puns and double-entendres sink in. You laugh. You groan. But you respond. Loudly.”

“…imaginative and impressive.”

“The monsters and the music make this Portland-grown parody anything but "Grimm."

Other Ways You Can Help

I understand that money can be tight and you may not be able to contribute right now... But if you could share this with your friends and family or people in your circle of influence who are supporters of the arts, that would be a wonderful help to us.  And be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!

Thanks and see you at the show!!!

We are currently looking to raise $8500.00 to record the original musical with a 16 piece orchestra and some of the amazing singers from the World Premier Production. 
The money will be used to rent a recording studio, hire an engineer, musicians and pay a small stipend to the performers.  Any additional funds will be used to produce the art and packaging and to post to online distribution sources. 
To those generous enough to donate to our cause, you will receive some cool Dex Dixon prizes and merchandise; from Posters, and original character design art pieces, to the soundtrack CD or digital tracks themselves.  And you will be part of making our show visible (audible) across the country.

The Impact
Once we have the recording, we will be able to market the show in a much more professional and focused way... reaching out to regional theaters and seeking production partners.  We will gain grass roots fans that can help promote the music and a desire for actual full stage productions.  We will be able to approach publishing houses so that the show can be made available for theatre companies to produce and perform the show nationwide. 
Here are some of the amazing things said about our show (full reviews available upon request or through google search;)
“A dizzily entertaining new musical!”      “One of Fertile Ground’s most captivating shows.”
“Dex Dixon… is predicated on delicious pulp-poetry and puns.”
“I seem to always come to the same conclusion about shows I love:  It comes down to IQ and this is one of the smartest teams I’ve seen in a long time.”
"Dex Dixon: Paranormal Dick" is doubtlessly the most bizarre show currently running on a Portland stage.”
“(possessing the) nuance, technical sophistication and unvarnished authenticity we've come to expect from Steve Coker.”
“…a creative vision, forged by immersion in the excesses of schlock culture, that honors the workaday artists who fueled show business well before the monsters took over.”
“…silliness moving at maximum flow, with enough comic pauses to let the puns and double-entendres sink in. You laugh. You groan. But you respond. Loudly.”
“…imaginative and impressive.”
“The monsters and the music make this Portland-grown parody anything but "Grimm."

Other Ways You Can Help
I understand that money can be tight and you may not be able to contribute right now... But if you could share this with your friends and family or people in your circle of influence who are supporters of the arts, that would be a wonderful help to us.  And be sure to use the Indiegogo share tools!
Thanks and see you at the show!!!

story:
We believe this piece deserves to be done properly, and as such are not pulling any punches with our design or staging! This means, however, that we need help to make our vision a reality. 

For example, the film industry is integral to the heart of this play, but even more so as we are combining live action with original film - but to do this we need to cover the costs of our expert filming crew!

Then, of course, what would the 1930's be without the suits, the dresses and the spats? We also need to cover the costs of set and costume, so 3 backers (Costume Designer) will get the chance to select a piece from an available collection of costumes used in the show!

But ultimately - YOU choose your award. We want you to be a part of this journey in whatever way you can and ensure you get the credit you deserve.

Of course, there is the option just to anonymously back the project – any amount you like with nothing in return apart from the satisfaction of knowing that you helped to fund something rather magical & enabled us to bring our vision to life.

 

"THE LAST TYCOON" - The tragedy of a man obsessed…

“He has the power to make anyone’s dreams come true… except his own.”

Monroe Stahr, the “Boy Wonder” is a man obsessed: with movies, with illusion, with the memory of his dead wife and with Shakespeare. When an earthquake nearly destroys the studio, an enigmatic and mysterious Englishwoman steps out of the wreckage.

Is she the one to save Stahr? Or will his latest obsession finally destroy him?

Like the titular hero of the novel, F Scott Fitzgerald died before he completed his masterly study of Hollywood in its heyday. It is his final, poignant farewell to the Great American Dream – a bittersweet love affair set in a never-never land: 1930’s – The Golden Age of Hollywood.

 

A suitable follow on from Ruby in The Dust’s acclaimed musical version of The Great Gatsby, "The Last Tycoon" is set underneath the truth of the Hollywood lights of the 1930’s with all the action taking place inside a studio lot - and inside the characters' minds. It may sound glamorous & glittering, but all is not as straightforward as it seems...

 So this is your chance to help create that gritty, art-deco atmosphere with your contribution – which we hope you’ll join us to witness first hand!

https://artstheatrewestend.co.uk/whats-on/the-l...

story:
Short Summary

We, Bex Ehrmann and Nikki R. Veit, are curating a 10-minute play festival, which will explore queer heroism -- or “Queeroism.” Queer theatre often focuses on hardship: heartbreak, illness, shame, discrimination, and oppression. These difficult stories need to be told and they need to be heard. With this festival, however, we make it our mission to honor queer pride through stories of heroism, tenacity, strength, community, and individuality. The festival will run July 8th and 9th at Collaboraction and will feature the following plays and artists:

Almost Immortal by Rex McGregor, directed by Leah Cassella

Background Hero Seeks Same by Michael Trottier, directed by Nick Thornton

The Birthday Boy by Roy Proctor, directed by Lexi Saunders

Faking Glory by Allie Costa, directed by Georgette Verdin

Formerly Known As by Alyson Mead, directed by Jeri Frederickson

Nouns of Assemblage by Lauren Yee and Philip Dawkins, directed by Charlie Marie McGrath

Unconventional by Theresa Masters and Marc Pruter, directed by Conner Wilson

What We Need & What You Get

We believe that artists and theatre technicians deserve to be paid for their work and we are offering a small stipend to each playwright, director and crew member involved in the festival. We also have some fees associated with the space we booked. Here is where your money will be going:

$50 x 2 (playwright + director) x 7 plays = $700

$50 x 1 (technical director) = $50

$50 x 1 (stage manager) = $50

$500 (space rental) = $500

$100 (Indiegogo fees) = $100

Total Ask:      $1,400


All funds raised beyond our minimum goal will be donated to the Broadway Youth Center. We aim to fully fund this festival through Indiegogo so that all ticket proceeds can be donated as well.

The Impact

This festival will provide an avenue for queer voices and queer stories to be shared with the greater Chicagoland community. All proceeds will benefit the Broadway Youth Center whose mission is as follows:
"For more than 1,500 teens and young adults, the Broadway Youth Center (BYC) of Howard Brown Health is a haven to seek refuge, medical care, social services, clothes and other much-needed care. All of our services are FREE of charge for youth, ages 12 to 24." 
To find out more about this organization follow this link: http://howardbrown.org/byc/

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share our page on social media and attend the festival in July!

story:
Musical theatre based around the epic songs of the metal band Týr. 


Týr is a metal band (in the sub-genre of Viking folk metal), beloved worldwide. They are from the Faroe Islands,  where they follow a musical tradition going back a thousand years.


It's been a long time coming. 


In 2011 Erika Warecki wrote the original script for "Northern Gate"  She has worked diligently for years to drum up enthusiasm and support for her dream project. She even got Terji to design the logo!  She eventually went to Figment Theatre with her script and asked if they could look into staging it.  

Northern Gate will tell the story of The Færeyinga Saga


The Færeyinga saga is around 1000 years old, yet the theme (a society on the verge of losing its ancient beliefs) is surprisingly relevant to the present day. It has action, drama, and a sense of humor.

It takes place on the jagged shores and green plains of Foroyar, a dangerous island chain in The Faroes where no trees grow. Its two main characters are Thrond, chieftain of the village of Gate and defender of the old ways, and Sigmund, a vengeful expatriate.



Financials

With our minimum goal, we will be able to finish pre-production and produce a small version of Northern Gate at an off-off Broadway theater for a couple weekends next spring. 

 

                                          Northern Gate Indegogo proceeds



Our Kickstarter campaign was originally for $20,000.  Although we did not reach our goal, we have been able to figure out a budget to get it off the ground with $10,000.  We have kept our stretch goal at $20,000 and in the event that there is enough interest in the project, we will do more with the production - from more musicians and singers, up to and including a full-sized dragon appearing onstage in the finale!



We are joined by Figment Theater who has staged over 20 original plays, musicals, and cabarets in Manhattan since 2008.  Their productions include 2015's Night of the Touching Zombies (a comedic horror),  2012's Preston Stagger (a lyrical pulp novel), 2010's Barbarian! (one of New York's first rap musicals). and 2008's sci-fi festival Robot Uprising.  They make fun theater for the thoughtful.

To explore how Týr's songs would work in a staged play, we brought in the talented and versatile Ted Stafford as musical director. Ted has been transcribing and arranging a series of Týr's songs, creating supporting choral sections, and conceiving the instrumentation for a theatrical run. While the songs won't sound like the heavy metal that fans are used to, the lyrics and melodies will stand strong.


We can't do this without you AND your friends!  Please help spread the word!


*video promo made by Pamela Jones, Viking scenes filmed by and starring Jason Ellis, Evelyn Sullivan and other actors from Figment Theater.
story_txt:
Musical theatre based around the epic songs of the metal band Týr. 
When Christian crusaders arrive on his shores, a Viking chieftain must make a life-or-death decision that will affect his community for a thousand years. The story is told interspersed with the songs of Týr, which drive the plot.
Týr is a metal band (in the sub-genre of Viking folk metal), beloved worldwide. They are from the Faroe Islands,  where they follow a musical tradition going back a thousand years.

Our show’s creator Erika Warecki has had an outpouring of love and support from the metal community in regards to this project. Also, Heri Joensen who is the singer/songwriter and founder of Týr  has given the thumbs up to use his music in this show.


It's been a long time coming. 

In 2011 Erika Warecki wrote the original script for "Northern Gate"  She has worked diligently for years to drum up enthusiasm and support for her dream project. She even got Terji to design the logo!  She eventually went to Figment Theatre with her script and asked if they could look into staging it.  





Northern Gate will tell the story of The Færeyinga Saga

It takes place on the jagged shores and green plains of Foroyar, a dangerous island chain in The Faroes where no trees grow. Its two main characters are Thrond, chieftain of the village of Gate and defender of the old ways, and Sigmund, a vengeful expatriate.








Financials
With our minimum goal, we will be able to finish pre-production and produce a small version of Northern Gate at an off-off Broadway theater for a couple weekends next spring. 
 
                                          Northern Gate Indegogo proceeds



Our Kickstarter campaign was originally for $20,000.  Although we did not reach our goal, we have been able to figure out a budget to get it off the ground with $10,000.  We have kept our stretch goal at $20,000 and in the event that there is enough interest in the project, we will do more with the production - from more musicians and singers, up to and including a full-sized dragon appearing onstage in the finale!



We are joined by Figment Theater who has staged over 20 original plays, musicals, and cabarets in Manhattan since 2008.  Their productions include 2015's Night of the Touching Zombies (a comedic horror),  2012's Preston Stagger (a lyrical pulp novel), 2010's Barbarian! (one of New York's first rap musicals). and 2008's sci-fi festival Robot Uprising.  They make fun theater for the thoughtful.
To explore how Týr's songs would work in a staged play, we brought in the talented and versatile Ted Stafford as musical director. Ted has been transcribing and arranging a series of Týr's songs, creating supporting choral sections, and conceiving the instrumentation for a theatrical run. While the songs won't sound like the heavy metal that fans are used to, the lyrics and melodies will stand strong.

We can't do this without you AND your friends!  Please help spread the word!

*video promo made by Pamela Jones, Viking scenes filmed by and starring Jason Ellis, Evelyn Sullivan and other actors from Figment Theater.

story:
play collaborative arts opened its doors in 2014, collaborating with hundreds of artists and welcoming thousands of audience members into our uniquely creative world. After two amazing years of programming, VICE (yes the police! not the subversive media outlet!) shut down performance at play. 

Fair enough, we were hosting tons of awesome underground art events. We didn't ask for permission, took some risks and committed to creating and hosting dynamic experiences across those two years. We knew one day the money guys or the authority guys would show up and tell us to "comply." Although we've found that going legit can be expensive, bureaucratic and confusing, we are excited about what this process means for our community. 

After months of meeting with public officials, permitting and building code experts, we have an iron-clad plan for legitimizing play. We've received an amazing amount of support from our local community in the arts district. Local contractors, architects, sister art spaces and the Arts District Cultural Council are on our side and have all lent a hand in getting us to where we are today. Legitimizing play will give us the freedom to elevate the programming we curate, create, and host. We are thankful for the space we've been able to hold for artists as an underground venue, but we're even more excited to be able to shout "play!" from the rooftops.  

WHERE DOES THE MONEY GO?

legitimizing our performing arts


$15,000: building plans, permitting for cafe, & live entertainment license
$30,000: beer & wine permit
$40,000-$60,000: construction of cafe & ADA bathrooms
$5,000-$10,000: other fees (indiegogo's 5%, etc.)


Each one of the major arcana has their own special abilities ranging from a shout out on social media to a lifetime of unlimited access for you and a friend. Choose which unique experience is for you. 

The Heiro, Sun, and Empire cards unlock special, immersive experiences that we're creating with you in mind.  These cardholders will receive access to the inner workings of play.  Each card includes it's own bounty of perks, which one will you choose?

TinyRhino: That's right, its a theatrical drinking game! 

TinyRhino is our take on the ten-minute play festival. We commission six playwrights to write new plays, each including the same five dramatic elements. You’ll be given a list of these elements. They might show up at any time, in any order, and with any frequency. When they do show up - WE DRINK! 


FUTURErotica: A wildly innovative, slick and surprising investigation into the eroticism of utopian future.  

Using a series of short-form plays, film, and interactive vignettes - FUTURErotica is a cross section of ideas about how humans will relate in future societies. 


party/play: An evocative experiment in performance and nightlife created with you in mind.
party, play, party!, CONTROL, obsession, money!, love, taboo, FREEDOM, passion-excitement-obsession! You are invited to the otherworldly affair, a lucid dream of a party where everyone knows your name. You are free. You are free. Join the party. 


The High Priestess Sound Bath: We will be hosting a soundbath focused on creative voice and abundance, especially for our High Priestess backers! Join us for a late night ritual with the symphonic gong and crystal singing bowls. The vibrations will take you on a journey of creativity and healing to release mental, physical, and emotional blocks.

THANK YOU FOR COLLABORATING ON THIS NEW CHAPTER WITH US

Indiegogo credits
Campaign management: Noah Nelson, Cole Rosner, Meredith Treinen, & Scott Monahan
Graphic design: Beth Barbaglia
Video: Kris van Genderen
with clips from: PRISM, NOISE REVOLT, Pete Heron, Steven Fine, Ruth B, & Chad Schultz
Copy: Cole, Meredith, Scott, Christopher Adams-Cohen, Rachel Rivera, & Matt Crowley
SPECIAL THANKS: play collaborators & ambassadors, Shawn Everett, Ian Dickinson/LOHA Architects, E-lectric Inc & Barling Construction

story:
Who are we?

The Mad Muse: Lori Howsare:  With 30+ years of active theatre in my life, I've done a few things. Currently, I am a Stage Manager and Performer in Morose and Macabre's Atrocity Exhibition( City Paper/Best Production 2015),  I also SM for other fabulous performers in the city, like Steel City Kitty Burlesque, Smokin' Betties and Kabarett Vulgare. But my roots are in Shakespeare, Classical Literature, and Performance Art. I love to use Theatre as the 'hammer' to shape reality, and look forward to bringing many artists and visions of madness! 

Lilith DeVille: Art Barker:

Multi talented Cabarista and Human Marvel. Lilith is the true essence of a vaudeville entertainer, and her talents span from the treacherous to the taboo. She is the founding member of Kabarett Vulgare (NC, PA), and the official narrator for Morose and Macabre's Atrocity Exhibition (Pittshburgh, PA). When she's not running her mouth, taking her clothes off, or hammering things into her face, she's making sweet, sweet music. A classicaly trained mallet percussionist playing since the age of 10, she has carried her musical discipline over to her other crafts. In 2014, she picked up the accordion, and hasn't put it down since. If that wasn't enough, she is the self-proclaimed master of the Manongahela Kazoo.She has toured with The Purgtory Roadshow, The Cut-Throat Freakshow, and The Coney Island Rock and Roll Roadshow, just to name a few. She can also be seen in the documentary film "House of Oddities" by Brian Cottington, and the music video work of the band Anders Manga. 

 

 

 

So, why do we need money?

Theatre is the greatest tool for raising Empathy in people and we're out to hit you in the feels. Beyond the horror of the Grand Guignol was the message that these were everyday horrors. With LE GRAND we have classic texts to introduce you to, along with modern stories about human monsters. So you could have a little serial killer with your human torture, an acid attack to compliment your envy, and so on...

Also bringing theatre to you! Doing theatre in a BAR is nothing new.  As venues are becoming more expensive and inaccessible to independent artists, we need SPACE! And space in places people might actually go. Putting theatre in front of a regular bar crowd can actually spread the exciting artform theatre is. We're not only here to entertain you, we're here to make you love our art form. Every theatre artist should be engaged in the ideal that we need to perpetuate our art into the future, any way we can. Part of that is making it affordable and accessible to everyone. 

Also we will be teaching the craft of performing Grand Guignol and offering audience talk backs along with the shows. Education is EVERYTHING!

Risks and Challenges

 

This is our first year in production, historically most independent theatre companies don't make it past five. The biggest challenge is getting to the audience that wants to experience live horror. Advertising.

Making theatre is a risk in general with the decreasing interest in the arts in our society. To produce new work, or work that is not the 'guaranteed' hit is a risk all theatre makers should take.

And the challenge of creating traditional theatre in a non-traditional venue.
