The biggest challenge is getting to the audience that wants to experience live horror. Advertising.Making theatre is a risk in general with the decreasing interest in the arts in our society. To produce new work, or work that is not the 'guaranteed' hit is a risk all theatre makers should take.And the challenge of creating traditional theatre in a non-traditional venue.

story:
Preview: Nov. 21 

Shows: Nov. 22, 23, 24, 25, 26, 27

Gabriella Colavecchio - Scott Farley - Jeannette Lambermont-Morey 

We are Haus of Casati!  A fledgling company interested in contemporary plays that deal with urgent contemporary issues, expertly written by playwrights that don't pull their punches. 

Why Mike Bartlett? There is clearly an appetite for Bartlett in this city! We want to give Toronto what Toronto wants. Bartlett writes fierce, unyielding, social dramas with such an unusual flare. He is anything but conventional, relishes in absurdity and the surreal, and will carry you away to bizarre worlds that feel all too familiar. 

My Child deals with a fracturing relationship. Two self-absorbed parents are competing for the ownership of their child, and their struggle is bruising everyone around them. 

What do we need? It is difficult for struggling young companies to have any access to funding, even to cover the most basic expenses. We need help raising operational funds to cover royalties, rental space, insurance, and material costs, to name a few. Spoiler Alert! There is a fabulous puppet in the making!

In keeping with Bartlett's request that this play be "inappropriately public," we have chosen to set it in an actual coffee shop, where the actors are indistinguishable from the patrons. While you're enjoying a latte or a scone, the performance will seem to unravel in front of your eyes.   

  

What do you get? There are perks to helping fund us! $5 Donors will receive a glorious thank you in the programme. $25 Donors will receive a glorious thank you AND a ticket to our preview performance. $50 Donors will receive a glorious thank you, a ticket to our preview, AND your choice of one of our "Master"class videos. $75 Donors will receive a glorious thank you, a ticket to our preview, and your choice of TWO "Master"class videos. For a generous $100, Donors will receive a glorious thank you, a SHOW ticket, and ALL THREE "Master"class videos.

PAUSE.

What's a "Master"class video, you ask?  We have made three playful tutorial videos, teaching the things we know best. "Master"class Gnocchi will show you how to make beautiful, soft gnocchi pasta. "Master"class Pie will teach you the ins and outs of pie making, and "Master"class Vegan Acting will teach you how to perform ham-free! 

All videos will be sent to you after the campaign closes!

Why is this money important to us? We are an artist-driven collective, and our only payment will be a split of the limited box-office. For this reason it is paramount that we fundraise enough to cover our production costs in advance so the burden doesn't fall on the artists involved. Even small donations are extremely valuable to us. Bernie Sanders ran a campaign, after-all, on modest donations. Donate 27 dollars today!

Are you broke? No problem! We understand! Believe me... we UNDERSTAND! You can help by simply sharing this campaign with your friends and family. Use the social media share buttons. OR just come to the show in the Fall! Having an audience is extremely helpful after all. Do you know someone who is a theatre virgin? Bring them too! This would be an exciting way for them to be introduced to what live theatre has to offer!

Thank you very much for your generosity and support!

Much love,

Haus of Casati

story:
My name is Tony Lawry for those that do not know me. I have been working in theatre professionally since 1999, with youth in theatre since 1995 & the theatre bug bit me in 1990. After moving to Chicago in 2002 with the goal of opening my own theatre I had to take jobs teaching theatre and improv to middle schoolers in after school settings, residencies and at Summer camps to make ends meet. All the while continuing to learn. After only 3 years of teaching for one camp I took it over as its director. I did start a very successful, one of a kind teen improv ensemble "Underage Sugar Addicts" as a result. In 2011 I left that position to create the education department for the Piccolo Theatre and be its Education Director. Just this past January the perfect storm happened that led to me leave that position and take over a theatre space and finally begin Theatre Above the Law.

 

The result of this campaign will allow me to bring productions to a community that needs a live entertainment night life and be able to cater the plays chosen to that community and not be forced into putting on the "money makers" for financial reasons only but shows that will be relatable to the audiences coming to see them. It is most important so that I may pay actors, crew and educators what they deserve while still keeping a reserve of funds for the next program. And more important still to give the youth of the community the opportunity to learn & hone their craft without putting a financial burden on their family. My ultimate goal would be to make all our youth education free for all.

In the intimate setting Theatre ATL is located and for the type of theatre we will do it costs roughly $6,000 of just production costs to put on 3 shows for the season. This amount would let the funds that come in from ticket sales and classes go to pay the people that are responsible for the shows and not bills, pour some of the profits into the education and be and be able to start next season with a cushion instead of starting from scratch.

Depending on the amount of donated funds per individual they will receive anywhere from free tickets (transferable) with cast meet & greet, to free enrollment in classes (transferable), autographed show posters, insider access to rehearsals and private performances

If we do not reach our goal the funds will continue to be used towards production cost for current production of "Matt & Ben" and some will then need to be used for rental of the theatre space.

I have spent years working with and observing some of the most successful theatre creatives in Chicago. I have successfully directed shows for Chicago area theatres and gave the world a unique improv group like no other. All to much success. That knowledge and success has brought me to this point & your help will get me past it. I Don't do things that won't work.
 
In the event this campaign does not succeed to the point I need it to. I have already begun applying for small business loans and have paid for most of the production costs for our first production of "Matt & Ben."
 
Of course the best way to help is come to see our productions and let others know about it too. Please send folks, including yourself, to our website theatreatl.org and like us on facebook.com/theatreatl but of course use the Indiegogo share tools!
 
Thanks so much for taking the time to read thru this. Hopefully if you got this far I'll be thanking you again soon for your donation.

story:
Folk Dance Remixed believes in diversity, creativity and spreading joy. Our shows and workshops show off the best that can be achieved when people work together, sharing their cultures, their music, their dance moves - their positivity! Our inspiring workshops get families up and dancing together and strangers holding hands and laughing within minutes, our work truly touches all that come into contact with it!

Our current show, Step Hop House, depicts the coming together of diverse travellers to new land and how they work and play together – mixing together folk, hip-hop, live music, Bollywood, capoeira, African, contemporary, beatbox and maypole traditions into a funky folkyness!

What We Need & What You Get

We need £2250 from our crowdfunding appeal to help us devise new shows and participatory workshops for children, young people, families and adults.

Your help will enable us do more education work with young people and artists – training them and dance leaders with new choreography, devising new approaches of teaching, and working with musicians to make great accompaniments.

Your help will secure the creativity and research needed to bring new ideas and formats to rehearsal, and enable the company to spend valuable time developing our innovative brand of funked up folkyness to delight audiences across the country. It will contribute to studio time for the artistic directors to experiment and devise; rehearsal costs for the company; costume development; technical experimentation and equipment (those maypole ribbons need to be shiny and perfect each time you see them!).

Every £1 donation helps make our grants and support go further and helps secure our hard work and innovation. Our crowdfunding donations will be combined with our current Arts Council England grant, and our in-kind support from partners East London Dance and the English Folk Dance and Song Society.
Please donate what you can to keep this joyous and eclectic company pushing forwards into the ground breaking territory. Every £1 helps keeps us creating! THANK YOU!

The Impact

Our work brings people together – it creates connections, makes people laugh and enjoy a dynamic and colourful spectacle. Don’t take our word for it – here’s some comments from people that have worked with us and seen our work themselves:

 “It was wonderful to see so many young people from across the North West performing at the beginning of U Dance 2016.  The blend of traditional folk dance and contemporary hip hop clearly enabled all the young people to express their individuality.  The piece seemed to bring folk dance to life for a new generation and the energy and obvious enthusiasm of the performers was infectious!  It was great to see traditional folk dance embraced as a vibrant part of young people’s dance in the UK.” 

Ginny Brown, Head of Education & Training, Imperial Society of Teachers of Dancing

 

We received some wonderful comments about your performances and workshops and how they were engaging and inclusive as well as visually stunning!

Rachel Wood, Arts Development Officer, Oldham Council

 

The dancers were wonderful, as were the musicians, and I was thrilled to see the fantastic ceilidh take-up at the end, bought a lump to my throat as these things always do when done so well.

Michael Hambridge, Arts and Cultural Development Officer, Hastings Borough Council

 

Street Dance the Maypole was a brilliant visual focal point, filling the space with colours and energy. The teachers were quick to adapt the level of the workshop to the ability of the participants ... everyone really enjoyed themselves!

Lina Johansson, Joint Artistic Director of Mimbre

 

Thank you again for making the show energetic and dynamic – everyone enjoyed your performance!  

Rozina Ahmed, Senior Events Officer, Events for London, Mayor’s Office

 ‘I just wanted to say how much I enjoyed the show last night – a great mix of dance styles blended into a cohesive performance full of energy, skill and a real sense of joy!  Lovely costumes and colourful props created a terrific environment in which to perform.  All the elements worked well (I loved the “mumming” reference!) and I can see the potential (as you surely can) for this to grow into a bigger show with educational aspects and huge workshop potential.’  

Barry Goodman, President of The Morris Federation

Opportunity to see cutting-edge real/ genuine “folk dance” of today. The sensational performance – when it finished I wanted to see it again, immediately. Loved the mix, meld and marriage of styles that is creating a new tradition.

Jacqueline Beattie, audience member 

Fabulous creative performance. The workshops are fun.

Dodie Lambminder, audience member

Risks & Challenges

We are always ducking and diving – being efficient and nifty with all our expenditure, reusing and revising our resources, our costumes, our admin and management, our sets and equipment… and ideas! We believe this is fundamental to our creativity and keeps us on our toes – but we also need additional support to have valuable time to think, plan, devise and develop into the future. This is where we need your support!  If we get the planning and devising right then we’re confident we can produce some stunning new ideas and performances – we’ve got so many great ideas, and just need some support to make those a reality.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know that money is tight. If you can’t contribute the hard cash you can still really help and support us by putting the word out to local event and festival promoters, schools, dance groups and dance agencies and tell them about our work. And you can pass on the news about this campaign and encourage people to join us!  THANK YOU!

story:
BFAB Dance Crew: 

The crew formed in 2013. BFAB consists of dancers, who are young bunch of talents in various dance forms with more than 6 years of professional dance experience. We believe, this is the core strength of our crew. This makes our crew more stronger and look professional with disciplined features.

BFAB Dance Crew
Champions of Power Of Desi Streets
(PODS 2017)
Held at Mumbai
*Competed with top 200 crews across the country*

 

OTHER MAJOR ACHIEVEMENTS
* We are the semi finalists of KINGS OF DANCE,
Reality dance show on vijay tv
* We placed 4th out of 1800 teams participated in
7UP dance pattalam in 2013
* We placed 2nd in Techofes 2014 conducted by
Anna university- College of engineering- Chennai
*We placed 2nd in Power Of Desi Streets- PODS
2015 hosted by Dynamic Dance Crew- Mumbai
*We placed 2nd in Instinct 2015 conducted by SSN
Engineering college-Chennai
* We are silver medalist in Hiphop UNITE- 2015
National championship held in Mumbai and
qualified to represent India in Hiphop UNITE-World
championship held in Martinque, France .
* Weplaced 2nd in Hiphop Esctacy season 2- 2015 ,
organised by Graphic Wood Media – Chennai.
* We got shortlisted among top 45 contestants out
of 10000 contestants who appeared for the
auditions for the new TV reality show Dance+

 

BREAKDOWN of the Expenses
Travel (To & From) - USD $14000/- for
8 people (flight charge)
Hotel - USD $2400/- for 8 people
Visa - USD $1600/- for 8 people
Team Registration - USD $400/- for 8
people
Costumes - USD $1300/- for 8 people
Food - USD $800/- for 8 people

story:
What we are doing

The festival exists because people want it to exist. We're a, friendly, slightly unruly bunch who work really hard (mostly on goodwill) to make it happen and welcome every single person who passes our way into our world.

We know that puppetry is an artform that should be for everyone - and we're committed to that journey. The fifth Bristol Festival of Puppetry is happening 1 - 10 September 2017 across Watershed and Tobacco Factory Theatres, and is packed with shows, films, parades, workshops and talks. Our small team of volunteers and crew are going to make it the best one yet, but we just need a financial boost to get us where we want to be so that we can set our beliefs in motion.

We’re so excited about the festival and our future, and are overjoyed that you might help us get there. We’re very grateful for every penny and thank every single person who donates or shares this campaign  - because we’re all about people getting together and making beautiful and great things happen.

What We Need & What You Get

This year, we’re focusing on expanding our audiences and creating new opportunities for them. We want accessibility and diversity to be part of our DNA, and we're committing to that right here, right now offering signed and relaxed performances at this year’s festival and setting up Interchange - 3 days of panel discussions and labs exploring how puppetry can offer diverse people platforms to tell their stories and how diverse practitioners can help us to develop puppetry. Your money will make the festival and Interchange as big as possible and  help create a legacy of accessibility and inclusion for the future.

We’ve got some amazing perks on offer for you generous people. All exclusive and all strictly limited.

  • Peter Lord, signed, one off drawing. - SUPER EXCLUSIVE AND VERY RARE
  • Group tours of Puppet Place
  • Festival Pass - super cheap for those that want to see as many shows as possible.
  • Festival Family Passes - flexible family passes for all our shows
  • Stop Motion Workshop - ONE OFF
  • Become a puppet  - ONLY TWO AVAILABLE

We’ve got some very exclusive rewards and amazing festival perks - or you can always just donate a few pounds to the cause, because like us, you simply believe that puppets make the world that little bit better.

The more we raise, the better  Interchange and the festival will be, if we don’t hit our target then Interchange will still happen, albeit at a smaller scale.  Your support will help us make all of our dreams for Interchange, Puppet Place and the festival into a reality. No matter what we raise, we’ll be able to go bigger than we would without your generous support.

The Impact

The festival is largely funded through a Grants for the Arts bid to Arts Council England and we need your support to help us take our plans to the next level. This year's festival has a specific focus on Diversity and Puppetry and accordingly, we are writing to ask for support towards the important work we are doing to widen participation in puppetry among all our communities. This year's diversity-focused events fall within Interchange; a three-day long mini-festival in which we will work alongside leading organisations (Diverse City, Doing Things Differently, Bristol Physical Access Chain, etc) and other individuals who work with disadvantaged people across Bristol and further afield.

To ensure that any legacy from this work is carried into future Puppet Place activity and especially the next festivals in 2019 and beyond, we have created a Diversity Focus Group, comprising learning disabled and non-learning disabled professionals, health care workers and specialists, who will document and evaluate all  Interchange activity. Their findings will help Puppet Place to ensure the legacy of Interchange and its new partnerships, and to identify and articulate a Call to Action towards implementing real change in our sector.

Risks & Challenges

Puppet Place is a registered charity and has been a UK hub for puppetry and animation since 1984. We have a professional and experienced team behind the festival. The risks here are low, the challenges are the ones we face in increasingly competitive environment for public funding. We've partnered with key disability and community groups to ensure that we can achieve realistic and long lasting connections with the people we're setting out to engage.

This is the 5th edition of the Bristol Festival of Puppetry and your investment will help us to take our work to new communities and improve accessibility across the festival. Your money will help us capitalise on years of reputation and trust building.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, you can still help. Tweet, facebook, instagram, tell you friends. You can share our campaign, link to it on your website, embed our video on your blog https://youtu.be/wSDXfAz9QNQ

Look at the perks, do you know someone who would jump at the chance to get one of them but might not be aware of what we do? Let them know all about what we're doing.

What We Need & What You Get
This year, we’re focusing on expanding our audiences and creating new opportunities for them. We want accessibility and diversity to be part of our DNA, and we're committing to that right here, right now offering signed and relaxed performances at this year’s festival and setting up Interchange - 3 days of panel discussions and labs exploring how puppetry can offer diverse people platforms to tell their stories and how diverse practitioners can help us to develop puppetry. Your money will make the festival and Interchange as big as possible and  help create a legacy of accessibility and inclusion for the future.
We’ve got some amazing perks on offer for you generous people. All exclusive and all strictly limited.

Peter Lord, signed, one off drawing. - SUPER EXCLUSIVE AND VERY RARE
Group tours of Puppet Place
Festival Pass - super cheap for those that want to see as many shows as possible.
Festival Family Passes - flexible family passes for all our shows
Stop Motion Workshop - ONE OFF
Become a puppet  - ONLY TWO AVAILABLE

We’ve got some very exclusive rewards and amazing festival perks - or you can always just donate a few pounds to the cause, because like us, you simply believe that puppets make the world that little bit better.
The more we raise, the better  Interchange and the festival will be, if we don’t hit our target then Interchange will still happen, albeit at a smaller scale.  Your support will help us make all of our dreams for Interchange, Puppet Place and the festival into a reality. No matter what we raise, we’ll be able to go bigger than we would without your generous support.

The Impact
The festival is largely funded through a Grants for the Arts bid to Arts Council England and we need your support to help us take our plans to the next level. This year's festival has a specific focus on Diversity and Puppetry and accordingly, we are writing to ask for support towards the important work we are doing to widen participation in puppetry among all our communities. This year's diversity-focused events fall within Interchange; a three-day long mini-festival in which we will work alongside leading organisations (Diverse City, Doing Things Differently, Bristol Physical Access Chain, etc) and other individuals who work with disadvantaged people across Bristol and further afield.
To ensure that any legacy from this work is carried into future Puppet Place activity and especially the next festivals in 2019 and beyond, we have created a Diversity Focus Group, comprising learning disabled and non-learning disabled professionals, health care workers and specialists, who will document and evaluate all  Interchange activity. Their findings will help Puppet Place to ensure the legacy of Interchange and its new partnerships, and to identify and articulate a Call to Action towards implementing real change in our sector.

Risks & Challenges
Puppet Place is a registered charity and has been a UK hub for puppetry and animation since 1984. We have a professional and experienced team behind the festival. The risks here are low, the challenges are the ones we face in increasingly competitive environment for public funding. We've partnered with key disability and community groups to ensure that we can achieve realistic and long lasting connections with the people we're setting out to engage.
This is the 5th edition of the Bristol Festival of Puppetry and your investment will help us to take our work to new communities and improve accessibility across the festival. Your money will help us capitalise on years of reputation and trust building.

Other Ways You Can Help
If you can't contribute financially, you can still help. Tweet, facebook, instagram, tell you friends. You can share our campaign, link to it on your website, embed our video on your blog https://youtu.be/wSDXfAz9QNQLook at the perks, do you know someone who would jump at the chance to get one of them but might not be aware of what we do? Let them know all about what we're doing.

story:
Who We Are

The LA Sirenes are a group of artists and performers from all over the Los Angeles area. We seek to provide entertainment that is not only thrilling and fun, but that also has a message. For years, the Sirenes have had amazing opportunities to perform for numerous companies, events, and fundraisers. But now, for the first time, we are excited to be telling our OWN story. 

In DICHOTOMY, the fully immersive theatrical 'A-list' nightclub experience, we will explore the connections between opposites, on the multifaceted wings of heavy to comedic subject matter. Combining the magic ritual of dance, world class actors, aerial artists, stilt performers, and live painters (to name a few) the LA Sirenes will be creating an experience designed to propel the guest into a personal Ascension. An experience for all who seek to find. 

But we need YOUR help to do it!

Why We Need Your Help

Making one-of-a-kind theatre is not easy....or cheap. We have an amazing team of builders and creators behind us and we want to give them the chance to stretch their wings. Undertaking an event of this proportion takes a TON of effort, and funds. 

From making heavy-duty custom metal grind gear, compensating our world class circus performers, and creating unique and spectacular costumes and make-up, to creating immersive hands-on experiences for our audiences (walk-through vaginal canal, anyone?) Our dreams take that green to produce. 

And that's why we are reaching out to you, our community. 

How You Will Help

With your generous contributions, you are helping us ensure that we have the resources to create the most entertaining, beautiful, awe-inspiring and resounding experience we can. As our inaugural production, the success of this show will help determine how far we can expand our imaginations for shows similar to this in the future. First and foremost, creating this work is a labour-of-love. We are each and every one of us performers and artists to our deepest core. But without a financial foundation from which to spring our creative endeavors, we will likely be unable to continue sharing our voice in a manner we choose. 

The LA Sirenes have big dreams, and your contributions will help make those dreams a big glittering reality! 

We understand that contributing financially is not something everyone is able to do. Trust us, we understand! And so, if you would like to help us in another way, we would love to hear from you! Do you have a performance or rehearsal space we could use? Are you a builder wanting to help us bring to life the weird and wonderful creations we are imagining? Are you a Fire Marshall who wants to get involved? (We  *really* need a Fire Marshal on board!)

Even by simply sharing this page, you will be helping us ENORMOUSLY. Tell your friends, use the share tools, and help us get the word out!

And so, with love, light, and glitter....we thank you.

story:
What we are doing

Staging William Shakespeare's OTHELLO using an all-female cast. Our goals for the production are as follows:

  • To create a bold and engaging performance for our audience.
  • To provide a new lens through which the story and its themes can be viewed.
  • To build a new kind of classical theatre.

This is a production we deeply believe in and want to share with the world. That includes you, and we would be honored if you would become a part of it.

What we need & what you get

This production has been carefully budgeted, with specially tailored perks:

  • We are asking for a total of $1500, which will be used to pay for a venue, publicity, and stipends for our incredibly hard-working cast and crew.
  • All levels of donation are deeply appreciated. No amount is too small, and each generous contribution gets its own special reward.
  • Even if we don't reach our goal, every cent raised will go towards helping this production reach its potential and everyone who gives will receive our thanks.

Why we are doing this 

The work we are doing is focused on using classical text to explore modern issues:

  • Our casting helps us use intersectional feminism to probe the play's themes.
  • Our approach brings entirely new dimensions to the forces that drive this story.
  • Our passion shows our audience what this play has to say.

Risks & Challenges

We are not naive, and living in the greatest theatre city in the world makes standing out hard. Thankfully, we have two traits to help us shine:

  • Our company is made up of artists not only of the highest caliber of talent, but also ones supremely dedicated to their cause.
  • No one has ever done what we have with this script before, and the audiences who have already seen it are proof at how strong an impact our show has.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute financially, we understand. This is a company made up of artists after all, and there are plenty of valuable ways to show your support. Sharing this campaign online will always be appreciated, and social media could probably use a break from the horrors of modern politics.

All of our campaign videos can be viewed at our Youtube page, https://www.youtube.com/channel/UCm8PSnSrbINLlP....

story:
Quick Summary

  • DEXTER for more than 13 million people has lived as one of the greatest and most addictive and delicious blood spattering shows in television history. Unfortunately, for so many of those 13 million+ fans, the show's Series Finale also lives as one of the most disappointing and frustratingly uncompleted  endings to a series in tv history. 

The Story

I'm Cooper Jordan, one of the youngest entrepreneurial theater producers in New York City and I am an avid fan of the series. I watched it from beginning to end, Having never watched any full series from beginning to end in my life, needless to say when the ending came I was devastated. I was extremely angry. For days I was upset, from punching walls to commiserating about it over blood orange tea. I did not know what to do about it to be effective. The thought I was thinking most about was to write Showtime Network a letter. But what would that do? I would go in to their office (I knew where it was as it is on a floor in an office building above my basement college). Then I logically came to the conclusion that wouldn't do much either. So how would I and millions of others live with this incompletion of ending to a vigilante we had grown to love,  sympathize with, and cheer on for 8 years? Then it came to me - I would do what I do best - I would create....A MUSICAL!!!, and about this very subject no less - subject that of the incomplete ending.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Like any big project or New York Musical, it needs money to be created to its full potential. My team and myself are committed to creating the most professional musical on a high level.
  • We have all sorts of perks of everything from show logo magnets to a DEX tshirt, to a personal tour of the theater in Times Square where it all began, led by Cooper.
  • If our goal here is not 100% met, the funds will go towards a very short limited run or tryout run in Brooklyn or New Jersey to raise more funds to open in Manhattan and run a following National Tour.

The Impact

We are committed to creating an world of completion for what Dexter fans lost.
If our is contribution goal here is 100% met, We promise this will be done for two years time, to include a New York, and National Tour across America.

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help. There are other ways you can help in addition to giving a bloodslide from your cheek (hehe, #thatwasajoke).

  • Make some blood spatter. Publish your blood spatter or DEXTER related pic to your own facebook profile. Use our logo and share it to our DEX Fan Page and we'll mail you a DEX magnet of your own. Post twice, We'll send you three.
  • You can also spread the word about DEX! A Killer Musical by utilizing the Indiegogo share tools or by visiting our anticipated future Off-Broadway home in Times Square: Times Scare - 669 8th Avenue @ 42nd Street.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
Short Summary 

We are a new start up based theatre company in Toronto. Our first show will be in October 2-4th 2015. (Which is BEYOND exciting for us).
In school we were drilled to "make your own work" instead of waiting by the phone . Go out and do things for yourself! Which is what exactly we plan on doing.
The company was created to make more work for performers and writers that are looking to do shows and work on their crafts. There are so many talented people in Toronto and we need to start creating more opportunities for them.
Help build theatre resumes. Help build artists. Help build US!

-

What We Need & What You Get

  • Rehearsal space is EXPENSIVE. You're easily looking at $15-25 per hour to have a place you can run around, be creative, and get loud. If we could do that in a place that wouldn't be disrupting others, it would be AWESOME.
  • We'll need to buy props, costumes, set pieces, supplies for the bar. All those things that will really add up in our budget.
  • Funds to go towards booking our next production space
  • We will be giving out perks to those who support the company! "you do one for mamma, mamma will do one for you" ;)

The Impact

  • We are all "Starving Artists" not only in the sense that we are all poor starting off in this industry, but that we are always hungry for more! Our plan is for this to just be the beginning and give many opportunities for artists in the years to come.
  • You'll feel awesome about yourself. Seriously. 
  • You'll get to see what amazing work has been created by your wonderful help

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help:

  • like us on Facebook! and share our page https://www.facebook.com/pages/Small-but-Mighty...
  • You can also use Indiegogo share tools to let others now about our campaign!


ps. I do not own the rights to the photo above as I grabbed it off google.
This is the artists website if you wanted to see more of their work.
http://redmeg8.typepad.com/photos/alltaglich/index.html

story:
LifeDream Productions is very excited to be bringing Melissa Skirboll''s new play "Blizzard: A Love Story" to the stage this summer. In this serio-comic look at love and letting go, an epic snowstorm shuts the city down. With no way to get home, Ian shows up at his ex-girlfriend’s door looking for a place to crash and a chance to revive their relationship. With the weather forcing them together, Ian and Lacey rehash the past. And though it’s clear they love each other, they are unable to find any shelter in each other – for them the storm outside reflects their love; beautiful and oh so destructive.

At the helm as director, Lori Kee returns to Planet Connections following her 2014 win for Outstanding Director for her work on "Vacation! All I Ever Wanted". Lori has also won best directing awards for her work on "Death, it Happens…" (2012 Frigid Festival) and "Male Man" (Medicine Show.) At the 2013 Planet Connections Gala event "One Acts for A Cause", she directed "Tennesee by" John Patrick Shanley. She is Resident Director at Nylon Fusion Theatre Company and teaches acting at BMCC CUNY. Find out more about Lori: http://www.lorikee.com/

Playwright, Melissa Skirboll is excited to be taking on the role of Lacey in this production. This is Melissa's fourth time participating with Planet Connections. She won Outstanding Direction for her work on Amy Gray Piper's "The Closet" in 2012, Acted in her play "Hell is Where the Heart Is" in 2011 (both produced with her company LifeDream Productions,) and directed Mark Jason WIlliam's "Straight Faced Lies" in 2013.

The role of Ian will be played by the very funny, sexy, and talented GARY LEE MAHMOUD! Gary has had the pleasure of playing a principal role in The Bourne Legacy and was a series regular on the Nicktoons live action show Alien Dawn. Amongst his more noteworthy roles, he has hosted the Onion News Network’s mock debate show “In The Know,” appeared as the featured dancing businessman in the Saturday Night Live music video “Boombox,” and had the privilege of performing in a staged reading of the screenplay "Mona’s Dream" with Oscar nominee Shoreh Aghdashloo. He is proudest of writing, producing, and performing in his multi-million view web sensation "Panhandler's Party".  Check him out at: www.serfgary.com/

Steven Albano returns to LifeDream Productions and Planet connections as Stage Manager. So happy to be working with him again -- he was my right hand on The Closet and having him involved allows me to breathe easy knowing that everything will be handled expertly!

Andy Evan Cohen has joined the team as Sound Designer. Andy is a multi-talented, composer, musician, sound designer, music director and all around boon to the production team. His theatrical compositions have been performed in numerous venues in New York City and in the Northeastern U.S. region. His works have been played in such venues as Lincoln Center, Fordham University, The Public Theater, off-Broadway at Theatre Row, 59E59, La Mama, HERE, the Ohio Theatre, Theater for the New City, Expanded Arts, and the New York International Fringe Festival, where he was a 2000 "Excellence" Award Winner. More about Andy here: http://www.andycomusic.com/

Funds raised will cover the basic expenses of putting on this show:

Stipends: Director, Actor, Stage Manager and sound designer will be receiving stipends. If donations exceed budget; they get paid more. (And they are worth it! Anyone involved in a festival is not doing this to get rich - the stipends cover transportation and not much more. It would be great to be able to give each of these people more than a token of my appreciation!)

Rehearsal Space: This tends to be the biggest expense for these types of productions. A good rule of thumb when budgeting rehearsal time is 1 hour per page. Blizzard is 30 pages - which means about 30 hours of rehearsal. There are some discounts and special rates available to Festivity participants, but it still will likely average a minimum of $20/hour. That's $600 if we are able to keep to the minimum. Because this is a one act and we are playing in conjunction with two other pieces, we are also budgeting in some shared rehearsals so that we can smooth out the scene changes and running order so that the audience will see a show that runs seamlessly from start to finish. Being conservative and allowing for some extra time I'm budgeting $800 to rehearsal space.

Audition space: Same pricing structure as rehearsal space. Since we are only auditioning for one role we think we can do this in 4-6 hours total. Budget: $100-150

Marketing/Postcards/Posters/Etc: $200

Props/Set/Wardrobe: $250

Planet Connections Theatre Festivity is a GREEN theater festival, we will be sharing set pieces when possible, scavenging, borrowing and seeking out used things whenever possible.

Fees/Insurance/etc. Submission fee: $25, Entrance Fee $250 (Split with the two other one-acts that are sharing the bill; so $81.33) And depending on whether the actor we cast as Ian is Equity or not, supplemental insurance policy may be required (around $150.) Budget: $100-$250.

Other expenses

I'm hoping that I can bring out my inner Scrooge and find ways to pinch the pennies till they bleed - so hopefully there will be some wiggle room in this budget. However, There are probably a few things that will need to come out of pocket. budget: $0 up to $200.

Oh yes - that all adds up to more than $1800. So don't stop just because you think we raised what we need! I'm low-balling because I'm hoping to find some creative ways to make ends meet.

You may remember from past years that Part of the commitment to Planet Connections is to choose a charity and help raise funds and awareness. This Year we are working with Planned Parenthood.

www.plannedparenthood.org

For nearly 100 years, Planned Parenthood has promoted a commonsense approach to women’s health and well-being, based on respect for each individual’s right to make informed, independent decisions about health, sex, and family planning.

Part of the ticket sales will be going to this worthy cause and we will be asking for donations at the theater to go towards WIN as well. However, if this fundraising campaign becomes WILDLY successful, we will be adding the excess to the pot.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute right now you can help make this show a success. Please share the link with your social networks, friends and family. If you're in the New York area and want to volunteer your time - get in touch we'll put you to work! If you want to donate props or set pieces let me know what you've got and if our production can't use it, I'm sure one of the other productions can! (You're moving and have things heading to the dumpster? Don't throw it out - theatre companies can use that stuff!)

Plus feel free to give directly to Planned Parenthood.

Oh and just so you know - if you come to see Blizzard you will also get to see these two shows:

"Years May Go By" by Julie Hayes and "Trust in Chariots" by Roderic Wachovsky. (YES that's THREE PLAYS for the price of ONE!!!)

So happy to be working with him again -- he was my right hand on The Closet and having him involved allows me to breathe easy knowing that everything will be handled expertly!Andy Evan Cohen has joined the team as Sound Designer. Andy is a multi-talented, composer, musician, sound designer, music director and all around boon to the production team. His theatrical compositions have been performed in numerous venues in 
New York City and in the Northeastern U.S. region. His works have been 
played in such venues as Lincoln Center, Fordham University, The Public 
Theater, off-Broadway at Theatre Row, 59E59, La Mama, HERE, the Ohio 
Theatre, Theater for the New City, Expanded Arts, and the New York 
International Fringe Festival, where he was a 2000 "Excellence" Award 
Winner. More about Andy here: http://www.andycomusic.com/Funds raised will cover the basic expenses of putting on this show:Stipends: Director, Actor, Stage Manager and sound designer will be receiving stipends. If donations exceed budget; they get paid more. (And they are worth it! Anyone involved in a festival is not doing this to get rich - the stipends cover transportation and not much more. It would be great to be able to give each of these people more than a token of my appreciation!)Rehearsal Space: This tends to be the biggest expense for these types of productions. A good rule of thumb when budgeting rehearsal time is 1 hour per page. Blizzard is 30 pages - which means about 30 hours of rehearsal. There are some discounts and special rates available to Festivity participants, but it still will likely average a minimum of $20/hour. That's $600 if we are able to keep to the minimum. Because this is a one act and we are playing in conjunction with two other pieces, we are also budgeting in some shared rehearsals so that we can smooth out the scene changes and running order so that the audience will see a show that runs seamlessly from start to finish. Being conservative and allowing for some extra time I'm budgeting $800 to rehearsal space.Audition space: Same pricing structure as rehearsal space. Since we are only auditioning for one role we think we can do this in 4-6 hours total. Budget: $100-150Marketing/Postcards/Posters/Etc: $200Props/Set/Wardrobe: $250Planet Connections Theatre Festivity is a GREEN theater festival, we will be sharing set pieces when possible, scavenging, borrowing and seeking out used things whenever possible. Fees/Insurance/etc. Submission fee: $25, Entrance Fee $250 (Split with the two other one-acts that are sharing the bill; so $81.33) And depending on whether the actor we cast as Ian is Equity or not, supplemental insurance policy may be required (around $150.) Budget: $100-$250.Other expensesI'm hoping that I can bring out my inner Scrooge and find ways to pinch the pennies till they bleed - so hopefully there will  be some wiggle room in this budget. However, There are probably a few things that will need to come out of pocket. budget: $0 up to $200.Oh yes - that all adds up to more than $1800. So don't stop just because you think we raised what we need! I'm low-balling because I'm hoping to find some creative ways to make ends meet.You may remember from past years that Part of the commitment to Planet Connections is to choose a charity and help raise funds and awareness. This Year we are working with Planned Parenthood. www.plannedparenthood.orgFor nearly 100 years, Planned Parenthood has promoted a commonsense approach to women’s health and well-being, based on respect for each individual’s right to make informed, independent decisions about health, sex, and family planning. Part of the ticket sales will be going to this worthy cause and we will be asking for donations at the theater to go towards WIN as well. However, if this fundraising campaign becomes WILDLY successful, we will be adding the excess to the pot.Other Ways You Can HelpEven if you can't contribute right now you can help make this show a success. Please share the link with your social networks, friends and family. If you're in the New York area  and want to volunteer your time - get in touch we'll put you to work! If you want to donate props or set pieces let me know what you've got and if our production can't use it, I'm sure one of the other productions can! (You're moving and have things heading to the dumpster? Don't throw it out - theatre companies can use that stuff!)Plus feel free to give directly to Planned Parenthood. Oh and just so you know - if you come to see Blizzard you will also get to see these two shows:"Years May Go By"  by Julie Hayes and "Trust in Chariots" by Roderic Wachovsky. (YES that's THREE PLAYS for the price of ONE!!!)

story:
Established in 2015, Propel Dance was born from the desire to offer superior professional training to aspiring performers, with a strong emphasis on conditioning and injury prevention.  Our goal is to nurture our students and lead them to become as technically exceptional and versatile as possible, all the while encouraging honest and authentic performances.  In addition to a strong professional  program, Propel Dance offers a wide variety of recreational dance and fitness classes.

In order to anticipate scheduling needs and enrollment, students must be able to register. As Propel Dance continues to create a dynamic web portal for dancers and families to use to manage everything dance, we need to offer a spot for dancers to register early for our upcoming dance year.  Enter Indiegogo.com. This site allows us to accept early registration (at a discounted rate) while offering exciting perks such as one of a kind Propel Dance swag and an invitation to the Grand Opening party in September.

At Propel Dance we understand that not everyone who views this campaign is going to register, because not everyone dances.  If you would still like to help us meet our registration goals:

  • Like or share our page on Facebook (www.facebook.com/propeldanceinc).
  • Follow and retweet us on Twitter (@propeldanceinc).
  • Watch for us on Instagram (@propeldanceinc) and like our awesome photos.
  • Share this campaign with your friends... especially those who are interested in or support dance.
  • Finally, don't forget to always use the Indiegogo share tools!

All of our supporters will be invited to a private Grand Opening Celebration to celebrate Propel Dance's 2015/16 dance year!

Thank you all who supported us!

The Propel Dance Team

story:
EDIT: WE NO LONGER NEED $3,000: ONLY $2,500! PLEASE DONATE!

The Show!

Adam Long, Daniel Singer, and Jess Winfield created and performed the Complete Works of William Shakespeare (Abridged) in 1987 with only Renaissance Faires under their belts. In August 2015, a group of talented local artists will do the same, only their experience comes from the Renaissance Faire of life. 

And several other shows. They aren't untrained actors, that'd just be ridiculous.

Please see The Team below to find out more information about their artistic pursuits and why they actually can put on good theatre.

Please Sir, Can I Have Some More?

That's not even Shakespeare: it's Dickens.

To complete the project, we need a place to jump off from. Our funding goal is $2,500, but if you pay in British Pounds it's only 1601.54! To help explain ourselves, we've provided a brief Q&A section below:

How expensive can putting on a play really be?

Well, we have a lot of people to pay. There's royalty fees to give to the publishing company, rent costumes, buy props, build a set, and rent a space. It's not all caviar and lavish hotels. As a matter of fact, what does caviar taste like? I'm curious.

It's delicious, plebeian. Wow! That sounds like a lot! But why $2,500?

I'll split it up (last edit 7.16.15):

  • Five days of rehearsals in the space and two performances will cost roughly $1,400. Time is money, as they say!
  • Two performances with our ticket prices and expected audience size will cost $100. We've gotta pay Adam Long, Daniel Singer, and Jess Winfield for writing their fantastic show otherwise we'd be criminals like THE MERCHANT OF VENICE! Right? ...Right?
  • Drafting, building, and painting our set will cost roughly $450, since the set is a rather simple one. That doesn't mean our TD doesn't have a lot on his hands! Well, hand... He broke the other one recently.
  • Costumes and Props will be difficult to acquire and costly to hold onto. An early estimate puts that amount around $550, as the show requires 38 props, 3 wigs, and more costume changes than Shakespeare wrote sonnets! (Note: there are not 154 costume pieces. There are about 20.)
It seems like you've planned this all out!
We have, yes. In order to put on a quality show, we have to! We very much hope you'll contribute so we can bring great theatre to Denton.

The Team

There are several people putting their heads together for this production, and we'll be sure and update this page as we go! Please keep a lookout on our Facebook page for updates and specific announcements about each team member as we put this project into motion!

  • Reagan Wallace will be Directing the production. A recent graduate from The University of Evansville, Reagan earned his BFA in Theatre Performance and wishes to get more directing experience under his belt before moving to Los Angeles in the fall to pursue a career in film. Reagan worked under Kurt Tofteland on a production of As You Like It and assistant directed under R. Scott Lank in UE's fall 2014 production of Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street.
  • Oshane Smith will be playing the role of Adam. A comedic actor that graduated from Newman Smith High School in 2012, Oshane hopes to use this performance as a chance to hone his comedic skills and become the next Wayne Brady... Or the first Oshane Smith. Oshane's favorite roles include Toby in Twelfth Night, Officer Dudley in Rumors, and Donald from You Can't Take it With You.
  • Daniel Magden will be playing the role of Jess. Having recently graduated from Billy Ryan High School, Dan hopes to earn credit hours at NCTC and transfer elsewhere to major in film production. Daniel's short film, Tick Tick Boom  placed 18th in state competition this year: he directed and wrote the show himself, along with three other shorts, during his time at Billy Ryan. The show would help him put experience under his belt and get into a decent film school.
  • Jason Julian Perez will be playing the role of Daniel. A 2014 graduate from Newman Smith High School, Jason is currently attending Brookhaven College and majoring in Theatre. Jason hopes to use this performance to further hone his acting skills, and is the perfect third member of our production. His favorite past shows include The Seagull and How to Compete in Business Without Really Trying.
  • Shelby Weems will be the Stage Manager for the production. Shelby has been taking time to gain additional experience in theatre before she goes off to school to earn a BFA in theatre. Her favorite roles include Catherine in The Heiress, Hedy Larue in How to Succeed in Business Without Really Trying, and Serafina De La Rose in The Rose Tattoo. The show will help Shelby apply and get accepted to a school of her choosing.
  • Bobby Wallace will be Technical Directing the production. Bobby is currently a junior at Billy Ryan High School and hopes to use the show in order to quite literally build his skill set as an artist and designer going into his senior year at Billy Ryan.
  • Rane Renshaw will be designing the posters for the production. Rane recently graduated from Carnegie Mellon University.

Challenges

At this point in time, we need money to do a show. We desperately want to do a show. The biggest problem, as stated above, is getting a space to perform in. We can get by with $1,500 and a bare stage, but a full production needs at least twice that.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you don't have any money, that's perfectly fine. If you would like to help us with costuming, construction, or props, please contact Reagan at Reagan.Wallace@me.com and he can provide you with a list of items that are still needed to get the show up and running.

Please also share the link on your Facebook/Twitter/other social media sites so that your friends can help us too!

Thank you all very much for your contributions! We hope to see you in August!

story:
JP Dance Group's Dance The World Nutcracker Festival is a curated world dance festival within a Jazz Nutcracker. This unique adaptation of the holiday classic aims to expose and educate the audience about all different kinds of cultural dance and world music, promote fair business practice and diversity in dance, and celebrate the unique cultures that all call New York City home.

SHOW SYNOPISIS

Set to Duke Ellington's jazz arrangement of Tchaikovsky's Nutcracker suite, Act 1 opens on a hoppin' holiday party in a Harlem Brownstone at the height of the roaring 20's. At the party, Clara receives a nutcracker doll from her mysterious uncle Dross L. Myer. Little does she know that the Nutcracker has a magical spell cast upon it. Later that night the Nutcracker tethers a magical snowstorm that carries Clara on a magical adventure to the 1922 World's Fair in Rio De Janiero.

In Act 2, the world's fair, guest performances by New York City's top cultural dance companies bring  traditional dance and music of their cultures to the stage.

HISTORY OF THE PRODUCTION

Dance the World Nutcracker Festival is now three years in the making. It began as 1/2hour show for school children (then titled Nutcracker on Lenox Ave) that  was commissioned by Riverbank State Park in Harlem in 2013.  Petrusak decided to rework The Nutcracker in order to pay homage to rich artistic history of Harlem, and to create a platform on which to teach the children about all types of dance; jazz, tap, modern, and a variety of cultural dances.  Wanting to expose the children to authentic cultural dance and traditional world music rather than ballet inspired by cultures, Petrusak decided not to choreograph the second act herself. Instead she turned to her very diverse company of dancers to perform traditional dances from their countries such as Taiwanese fan dance, Brazilian Samba, and Dunyavi Roma (world Gypsy).

The show a success and was invited back to Riverbank for a second year and additional performances for the general public. In two years of presenting at Riverbank, the show has reached over 5,000 school children, senior citizens, and families.

Now, in its third year, Petrusak is premiering the performance as she originally envisioned it; an evening length production with a world dance festival embedded into the 2nd act. The first act and supporting roles in the second act are choreographed by Petrusak and will be danced by JP Dance Group. The second act will feature the festival of professional cultural dance groups.

This Production and Fair Business Practice in the Arts

JP Dance Group advocates fair business practice and will implement fair business practice in the production Dance the World Nutcracker Festival. This means that:

  • Box office proceeds will be split fairly with all participating artists
  • No application fee will be charged to applying guest artists
  • All applications will be granted fair reviewed by a panel of dance professionals
  • All technical professionals (lighting designers, videographers, photographers, etc..)will be compensated
  • The festival will be professionally promoted in an effort to gain worthwhile exposure (i.e. potential presenters, new audiences, press reviews) for all artists involved

What the show needs:

    Dancers. Dancers will be compensated fairly each nigh they perform. JP Dance Group advocates fair pay in dance.

    Technical staff. A professional lighting designer, stage manager, videographer, and photographer will be hired for the production

    Marketing. The show will be marketed to the general public, the press, and local organizations. We need help in spreading the world and creating professional marketing materials

    Programs. The programs will not just outline the Production, but will also provide background information on the participating guest artists, the cultural significance of the dances they are performing. This extra information is expensive but will deeply enhance the audiences experience and appreciation of what they are viewing.


The Impact

Supporting this production will help expose audiences to all different kinds of traditional world dance, promote cultural understanding, and celebrate diversity in dance.

Risks & Challenges

Part of JP Dance Group's mission is to provide affordable access to the arts and thus we are keeping tickets under $30 and are offering student and senior discounts. However, this also means that our projected costs of the production out-weigh the projected box office proceeds.  We are seeking the help of individual donors, sponsorships, and grants to help make this production the best it can possibly be.

The proceeds of this campaign are  specifically earmarked to provide fair compensation for our hardworking dancers and technical staff. If you would like to sponsor another need of the show, visit our direct donations link with our fiscal Sponsor, The Field: http://thefield.org/form/donate-artist and select Julie Petrusak/JP Dance Group form the menu.


Other Ways You Can Help

  • Share this campaign with others who would want to support this production and diversity in dance
  • Volunteer. We need volunteers to help with behind the scenes and pre-production of the show. Interested volunteers can contact jpdancegroup@gmail.com put "volunteer" in the subject line
  • In-Kind Donations. JP Dance Group can accept in-kind donations and will provide a letter of receipt of services or items that are tax-deductible.
  • Attend. Come see the show in December to experience the magic, applaud the artistry, and support this production.



JP Dance Group is a Sponsored Artist with The Field, a non-for-profit, tax-exempt, 501(c)(3) organization serving the New York City performing arts community. Contributions made to The Field and earmarked for JP Dance Group are tax-deductable to the extent allowed by law. For more information about The Field contact: The Field, 75 Maiden Lane, Suite 906, New York NY 10038, 212-691-6969, www.thefield.org. A copy of The Field’s latest annual report may be obtained, upon request, from The Field or from the Office of the Attorney General, Charities Bureau, 120 Broadway, New York, NY 10271.

story:
Short Summary

My name is Sylvie Bouchard, I am the founder and Artistic Director of BoucharDanse, a Toronto-based contemporary dance company that is celebrating its 10th anniversary in 2020. As an artist, I am especially interested in new artistic concepts and projects that are collaborative in nature and where a journey can be witnessed.

At the moment, I am working on a very special project, a visual and kinaesthetic installation titled très loin. très loin brings together my two passions: dance and the art of psychotherapy. Besides being a dancer and choreographer, I have also practiced psychotherapy and I am still involved in the field. I know first-hand how important it is to have support when we go through difficult times and très loin speaks about this. 

très loin explores how psychological trauma affects one's psyche and how resilience plays a role in journeys of recovery. The piece looks closely at how our mind and body deal with the consequences of trauma, but most importantly, it portraits the incredible strength, courage and perseverance needed to surmount these experiences. With très loin, I am attempting to tell this story through dance.

In order to bring très loin to life with my team of outstanding collaborators, I need your help. We need to fund two more phases of creation before the work premieres, in Toronto, in the spring of 2021.

The team working on this production is as follows:

  • Acclaimed visual artist Ed Pien with whom I am collaborating closely. Ed is creating the incredible visual art that inhabits the space;
  • Brilliant theatre artist and director Anne-Marie Donovan who is our dramaturg and with whom I have a very strong artistic connection;
  • Accomplished composer Phil Strong who creates the sound scores and musical compositions and with whom I have a long history of working;
  • Exceptional lighting designer André du Toit who will bring magic to this installation;
  • Four incredible dancers Meredith Thompson, Molly Johnson, Luke Garwood and Michael Caldwell who are also active co-creators of the movement material.

From left to right, top to bottom: André du Toit, Anne-Marie Donovan, Ed Pien, Luke Garwood, Meredith Thompson, Michael Caldwell, Molly Johnson and Phil Strong.

I am honoured and proud to be working with these amazing artists and very generous people, and I thank them wholeheartedly for their artistic and creative contributions.

 

What We Need & What You Get

très loin has a very specific creation process - working collaboratively with all the art forms means that all collaborators are required to be in rehearsal almost all the time. Additionally, because the dancers interact with Ed Pien’s art pieces (the art pieces are raised and lowered to and from the stage at different times in the piece), it is crucial for us to create the work in a theatre space, which is costly. All of us believe in this work very strongly and we want to make sure that we have a proper amount of time to create it. 

BoucharDanse is a charitable organization. We receive a small amount of operating funding each year from the Ontario Arts Council and the Toronto Arts Council. A small percentage of these funds go towards the creation of très loin and so we need to raise the rest of the revenue through other sources, one being fundraising and donations. 

The reasons above are why we are asking for your help - we are aiming to fundraise $5,000 CAD through this campaign to help us go ahead with our next creation phase that is scheduled for December 2020.

The funds received through this campaign will be fully spent on the next creation period of très loin and within the four categories below:

  • Fees for the artistic team (choreographer, dramaturg, composer, visual artist and lighting designer)
  • Fees for the dancers
  • Fees for the technical team
  • Theatre and equipment rental

By supporting us, you become part of the creation process! Check our perks, join us for the invite-only showings, become our honorary producer, or simply contribute with a monetary donation by clicking on "Back It."

For more details on the financials, please feel free to contact us at marketa@bouchardanse.com.

 

The Impact

Mental health is more important than ever. Discussions and conversations about mental health are now surfacing, which is a huge and crucial step in our society. The creation of this work means a lot to me because it is a way to give voice, through the body, to survivors of trauma, for the incredible amount of courage that they need, day in and day out, to build (or rebuild) trust, connection, joy and a feeling of freedom.

My most recent choreographic works look at the unconscious and at its disconcerting course. In très loin, we also look at dissociation, a normal response to an abnormal situation (abuse, violence, danger, etc.). This state lingers in the body and mind of the survivor. With the creation of très loin comes the desire to touch on a more personal theme, and the strong desire to celebrate our humanity, strengths and vulnerabilities while demonstrating how emotional support is essential to chart new ways of being after surviving a major trauma. One of the goals of undertaking the creation of this installation is to bring the impact of trauma to the forefront and hopefully create more awareness and understanding.

 

Risks & Challenges

With the excellence of our artistic team, the work that has been done so far, and BoucharDanse’s solid reputation and experience in producing, we are confident that this project will be successful.

However, funding can sometimes take longer than expected. If this happens with the creation of très loin, we will take longer to create the work, but we will for certain still bring the project to completion. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to support us financially, share your support in other acts of loving kindness by:

  • Share our campaign with your friends, colleagues and relatives
  • Share online on your social media
  • Follow BoucharDanse on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter
  • Sign-up for our newsletter
  • Contact us about volunteering opportunities with BoucharDanse

All photos by John Lauener.
story_txt:
Short Summary
My name is Sylvie Bouchard, I am the founder and Artistic Director of BoucharDanse, a Toronto-based contemporary dance company that is celebrating its 10th anniversary in 2020. As an artist, I am especially interested in new artistic concepts and projects that are collaborative in nature and where a journey can be witnessed.

At the moment, I am working on a very special project, a visual and kinaesthetic installation titled très loin. très loin brings together my two passions: dance and the art of psychotherapy. Besides being a dancer and choreographer, I have also practiced psychotherapy and I am still involved in the field. I know first-hand how important it is to have support when we go through difficult times and très loin speaks about this. 
très loin explores how psychological trauma affects one's psyche and how resilience plays a role in journeys of recovery. The piece looks closely at how our mind and body deal with the consequences of trauma, but most importantly, it portraits the incredible strength, courage and perseverance needed to surmount these experiences. With très loin, I am attempting to tell this story through dance.
In order to bring très loin to life with my team of outstanding collaborators, I need your help. We need to fund two more phases of creation before the work premieres, in Toronto, in the spring of 2021.
The team working on this production is as follows:

Acclaimed visual artist Ed Pien with whom I am collaborating closely. Ed is creating the incredible visual art that inhabits the space;
Brilliant theatre artist and director Anne-Marie Donovan who is our dramaturg and with whom I have a very strong artistic connection;
Accomplished composer Phil Strong who creates the sound scores and musical compositions and with whom I have a long history of working;
Exceptional lighting designer André du Toit who will bring magic to this installation;
Four incredible dancers Meredith Thompson, Molly Johnson, Luke Garwood and Michael Caldwell who are also active co-creators of the movement material.


From left to right, top to bottom: André du Toit, Anne-Marie Donovan, Ed Pien, Luke Garwood, Meredith Thompson, Michael Caldwell, Molly Johnson and Phil Strong.

Share online on your social media
Follow BoucharDanse on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter

Sign-up for our newsletter

All photos by John Lauener.

story:
A new opera company; and an exciting production of Britten's amazing chamber opera, The Turn of the Screw.

Kirsten Z Cairns (that's me!) is a stage director who has been working in the field of opera since 2002. Now my network in this business is extensive enough that I feel ready to set up my own opera company; and I have a production idea for one of my favourite operas, The Turn of the Screw, to launch us. Enigma Chamber Opera has one major backer already, but we need to raise the rest of the funds to give the company a strong start, and to make this show happen; and that is where YOU come in!

I've got together a team of incredible professionals - singers, conductor, designers, musicians - and hired a theatre in Boston, for performances in January 2020.

With your help, we can create an amazing production of this exciting work, staging innovative opera, and exploring Britten's masterpiece in an entirely new interpretation -​ with an entirely new company.

Creating art and making music are more important than ever, in this tumultuous world. Be an angel and help us to create something profound and beautiful! 

What will be different about Enigma Chamber Opera?

The plan is that Enigma Chamber Opera will be a rep company; a  group of artists (singers, conductors, designers, and director) who know each other, from whom will be drawn the company for each show. These artists are all experienced, highly skilled, established professionals, all of whom can work quickly to create the highest standard of work in a short time frame. Shows will be chamber repertoire (small cast, small orchestra) from any period, and staging will be innovative and flexible. Though our base will be Boston, the intention is that Enigma will be a multinational company, performing in venues and at festivals around the world. We'll be a travelling troupe of players, coming together for short periods to inspire each other and our audiences.  

Why this show?

The Turn of the Screw (based on the Henry James novella) is a fascinating story, which raises many questions. It appears to be a ghost story, but one is never quite sure if the main character is imagining the phantoms. A woman who is hired to look after two children begins to believe that they are being haunted by a former governess and valet; but is it her own mind which is summoning up such visions?

A conversation some years ago with a friend who has some mental health concerns, about how she sometimes 'saw' things which she knew were not real, but which haunted her, made me wonder: what if the entire story is in the mind of the 'Governess'? Perhaps not only the 'ghosts', but indeed even the children and the housekeeper, are figments of her imagination. What begins as an enjoyable fantasy, a daydream to escape her unhappy life, turns on her and becomes a waking nightmare which she cannot control. 

Thus Britten's powerful opera, and James' compelling story, becomes an exploration of mental health, and of the power - and fragility - of the mind.

The Turn of the Screw is an ideal piece for a fledgling chamber opera company to stage. The cast is small (six people), the orchestra a chamber ensemble, and in this interpretation of the plot, we can use cleverly designed production elements to make it relatively affordable and manageable. But we need YOUR HELP to make it happen!

What We Need & What You Get

All the artistic elements of this production are already in place - this production is happening! We have the venue, the performers, the players, the designers. All we need is the funding. Every single dollar we raise will be spent making OPERA!

We are also looking for backers who would like to be associated with Enigma Chamber Opera going forward; be founder supporters of our company, and help us to plan for future productions!

We have some exciting perks for our backers (reception with performers! a private voice performance just for you!), including a way to access the LIVE STREAM, so you can see the final show even if you can't be in Boston in January. This will be the only opportunity to see our inaugural production: watch it live, in Boston or via streaming. 

Why crowdfund?

Creating art is infinitely rewarding, but even with careful planning, it isn't cheap. We do it because we are passionate about it - but finding the money to make it happen is hard. In recent years, many small opera and theatre companies have closed down, unable to make ends meet. The grants and arts programs that used to be out there to help small companies have all but disappeared. We at Enigma Chamber Opera are fortunate to have secured one major donor, but we need to raise more. Of course we hope to sell out both performances! - but it would be prohibitive to cover costs with ticket sales;  we want people to be able to afford to come and see the show! 

Our fabulous creative team is committed to putting on a successful and professional production on a tight budget.  We hold to the highest standards in all our work, so you can trust your donations will be used carefully.  

Here is the outstanding team:

Conductor                             Kristo Kondakci (Kendall Square Orchestra, Eureka Ensemble)

Set and lighting designer  Peter Torpey (MIT Media Lab)

Costume designer                 Rebecca Butler (Costume Director, The Boston Conservatory at Berklee)

Matthew DiBattista            as Peter Quint 

Aliana de la Guardia             as The Governess

Janna Baty                                as Mrs Grose

Michelle Trainor                      as Miss Jessel

Erin Matthews                         as Flora

Matvey Soykin                      as Miles

Plus of course we will have an extraordinary orchestra; and I'll be directing.

Ways You Can Help

Every single dollar makes a difference - no donation is too small! We are excited to offer perks to donors who give $20 or more; please check out the tiers and donate according to your comfort level, and to what takes your fancy!   

If you can't donate, please help us to spread the word! There are Indiegogo 'Share' tools you can use to let folks know about this campaign. Encourage your friends to support the arts! And don't forget to buy tickets and come and see the show in January; or pledge to get the Live Stream access if you can't be in Boston! 

Please note: The Live Stream password is only included in the $50, $100, $200 and $250 perks.

Any pledge $20 and up will mean your name goes up on our 'supporters list' on our Facebook page. All pledges of $100 and up will also be listed in our printed programme for the show.  If you'd prefer to remain anonymous, please let us know!  

Finally, we are happy to tailor a 'perk' for YOU, so far as is possible. If you'd like something in particular in return for your donation, such as supporting our after show reception, or sponsoring a particular cast member, please email Kirsten and make your request:  kzcairns@hotmail.com

Perks do NOT include tickets to the opera performances, unless specifically stated. Please call the New England Conservatory Box Office to book tickets: 617 585 1260

This production is a sponsored project of Guerilla Opera, a 501(c)3 non-profit organization. These means that your donations are tax-deductible to the extent permitted by law. We are very grateful to Guerilla Opera for supporting us in this way!

 

THANK YOU for helping us to make opera's newest company, Enigma Chamber Opera, a success!

story:
My name is Alberto Vazquez and I have a been and actor (45 years), an acting teacher since 2004, and a screenwriter for many years.  I have directed and produced shows in my career.  Doing this play (Ellie, Mom and Me) would be the topper in my career.  Contributors will help me achieve my career ending dream.

 

In order to create a really great production, I know a $10,000 fund raiser would make this happen.  This will include front row seats to opening night (or any night you choose to attend), and being invited to the wrap party, which is exciting to mingle with all the creative people involved.

 

If I don't reach my goal, I will donate the monies to my favorite charity, The March of Dimes.  This show is important because it makes us reflect about our family, our shortcomings as humans, and our character flaws that hinder our personal growth.  

 

I know their are risks involved here: and show business is an industry driven by rejection, but I am never one to let that affect me.  After forty-five years in this business, I am well armed with (great) contacts to achieve my goal.  Nothing will stop me from getting the show up!!!

 

Maybe you won't contribute to my project, but you can pass the word around and help me that way.  "Six degrees of separation" always works.  Use Indiegogo (share tools) to help me in that way.  I really would appreciate that.
